description:
Ive always heard the third time is the charm. On my personal tour de San Francisco almond croissants, looks like we have struck gold(Hoping someone catches the history reference here). 

The exposed brick, the rustic furniture...its likehome n Country magazine come to life. Parking is somewhat of a challenge(yes some people actually drive around here), but it's so worth the struggle! 

Thorough bread and bakery is a picturesque cafe featuring mostly French inspired pastries and freshly baked breads. There are also lunch items like salads and sandwiches.

Almond croissant - super flaky, buttery, and straight up delicious. The almond filling is not too sweet, featured inside the croissant, and brace yourself for this one...ON TOP of the croissant. Let's marinate on that for a few seconds....

Ham and cheese croissant - again with the buttery flakiness. I have no idea what the filling is, but it's certainly not simply ham and cheese. I would guess some sort of bechamel? Either way, simply delicious! 

San Fran is loaded with world class bakeries, but with Thorough, Ive landed on my favorite thus far. One can say that I thoroughly....enjoyed. See what I did there?!
author: Donald S.

description:
Ok, I just read this one review before I'm starting my own review of this place & I'm unpleasantly surprised to learn that they use day old croissants to make their almond croissants? Why?

I've visited this place twice while I'm currently working in the area, and I think both visits were good. The pastries that I got were pretty yummy. 1st time I got the Almond Croissant & The Rustic in which I liked the Rustic more. Then 2nd time I got a Mocha, The Rustic, and Apple Frittata (?) in which I liked the Apple one more because it reminds me kinda like an apple pie. 

Overall this place is pretty rusticly cute, and it's cool they have a patio/backyard area for people to enjoy their pastry & coffee.
author: Amy C.

description:
Many weeks later, I'm still dreaming of the savory scone I spontaneously got at Thorough Bread. You see, I usually find scones dry and tasteless, but there was something about this one that called my name. It made me want to give more scones a chance. (Or maybe I should continue to eat Thorough Bread scones only.)

The space inside is pleasant. It's nice to be able to sit close to where the magic happens, and the display of breads and pastries is very inviting.

There's an outside patio in the back that has almost as much seating as inside. It feels like a nice oasis in the middle of SF.
author: Jess L.

description:
My husband gets a loaf of fresh bread wherever he can and this was his favorite loaf of bread ever, including what we've gotten at farmer's markets, acme, whole foods, etc. It's surprising this place doesn't have more of a wait since we waited in line on the same day at Tartine forever and thought the pastries and bread here were much better!
They have a cute little cafe garden in the back too.
author: Sharon H.

description:
I have not reviewed this place... How is this possible? First of all, they have the best ham and cheese croissants that I've ever tried, and Lord knows I've tried a lot (including wonderful ones in Paris and Buenos Aires). Do yourself a favor and have some, warmed up. Their carrot cake is divine, as well as their cream puffs, and everything else on display looks wonderful. Their coffee is always delicious and unassuming, this isn't Starbucks after all. Oh! Their almond croissanttttt. Get some of that and thank me later.

I've always wanted to sit in their back patio and read a book, but it would appear that I'm not the only person who's had that idea. Every time I have gone it's booked to capacity. Highly recommend this bakery. It makes me and the husband happy and we always stop by when in Castro, once a month. Love!
author: Joanna R.

description:
If you're looking for a good cup of coffee, some lovely pastries and an amazing backdoor patio then this is a great choice! Before I get too far into this review I should note, it was not written from the location as they don't offer free wifi. Kinda strange for a coffee shop but, hey maybe they don't want people overstaying their welcome :) 

Anyway, I ordered a tall cup of joe (drip coffee) and a plain croissant. The coffee was tasty and the croissant was above average, not spectacular. I will say that the other pastries in the case looked delicious and the baked bread was on point. 

The best part of the space was the backyard garden area. It's peaceful, well lit and are tough to come by in SF. My advice...grab a coffee, disconnect and enjoy the scenery.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
5 Star bakery based on America standards. French style pastries and breads by folks who pay attention to technique. And sightglass coffee to boot!

On the other hand, 4 Star bakery based on SF standards. You have two tiers above, new American superstars like Jane and Neighbor, as well French stalwarts like Tartine and B Patisserie.

I would come here weekly were it not to be in SF. Recommend the almond croissant with a nice crunchy top and croissant layers. The coffee is decent but not as good as sightglass does itself.
author: Aakash G.

description: More affordable than other bakeries and worth it for the quality. The croissants are great. I personally think they have the best ham and cheese croissant in the city - they top theirs with a mornay style sauce and it is SO good. Ample seating - their back patio is awesome - lots of trees and shade creating a peaceful, beautiful space to work or enjoy coffee/pastries. Definitely will be back again.
author: Cindy L.

description:
The almond croissant here is spectacular. It is the perfect amount of crispy and soft. It's not too sweet either. Wow I'm salivating already.
Recommendations:

drip coffee (from sightglass I believe)
brown batter chocolate chip cookie
Carrot cake - very carroty 

They have reasonable prices for their pastries and it's a nice place for brunch or catching up with friends. 

They don't have free WiFi but I would still come back for that almond croissant!
author: Alicia L.

description:
Amazing food. I still have flashbacks to my wife, friend, and their young kids running from this spot in tears years ago after being verbally assaulted by another customer who couldn't stand kids. He thought he could be abusive  when it was just women and five year olds he was yelling at out back.
Owners saw them leave crying, but didn't want to get involved as the guy was a regular.  
Still, lovely cakes and bread.
author: Neil C.

description:
Pulled Pork Sandwich 

Wow!! First of all the sandwich is huge. I came on a recommendation from a friend for lunch and I was blown away. This isn't a sandwich that comes on a small bun that's all bread and no meat. 

It's served on what tastes like a homemade roll with a HUGE portion of pulled pork. It's actually hard to keep the meat from falling out with every bite. Extremely flavorful packed with sauce as well. The side salad that comes with it was crisp fresh and had a great balsamic on top. 

If the weather is nice I would say sit outside. Grab a carafe of water and sit in the back patio on an eclectic mix of tables and chairs. Very well outdoorsy woodland vibe that makes you forget your in the heart of the city.
author: Michael P.

description:
Thanks for the sourdough starter!! 

I bought sourdough starter for $5 and made homemade sourdough bread, turned out great.
author: Shruti D.

description: I just love this place.  A very local feel with a tranquil back patio.  No wi-fi so it attracts folks looking to chill and read a book rather than work remotely.  Not enough places left like this in the city!  The sandwiches make a great lunch and staff is super friendly.
author: Matt V.

description: Best bread pudding in the Bay Area hands down!!! Loved this place! Their outdoor patio is very zen and the perfect place to enjoy their delicious coffees and teas! Everything is fresh and the staff is very friendly.
author: Meg C.

description:
I ordered and paid for a pulled pork sandwiches.  A few minutes later, I was told they don't have it for the day.  Cashier was unable to give me a refund from my credit card transaction.
I asked a on site manager and had to waited close to 10 minutes for my refund which was verbal, since he could not generate a receipt.

I think it's not cool that you didn't notify your cashier in advance that certain item is not available, no sign stating so, waiting up to 10 minutes to get a verbal credit card refund, .....not even an apology!!

Do you guys seriously think this is how customers should be treated!
author: Tkd K.

description:
My roommate had been raving about this being her favorite cafe for a while now. So we finally got around to visiting together before work the other day. My reason for giving this place 4 stars is solely on the cafe itself. I would definitely come back here to enjoy a cup of coffee (while I didn't have any this visit, it is Sightglass coffee, so I know it will be decent). I believe this place could become my new "work" cafe, especially on a nice day. There is ample seating inside or on the front "patio" and the cutest courtyard in back. I imagine this place could get busy but unlike other coffee shops in the area, I wouldn't need to be on my computer with my elbows tucked in or with it on my lap. 

This was a quick visit. So I got a brussel sprout/poblano quiche to go. While it was very very good, the crust was perfectly buttery and flakey, it was a bit rich for my liking. It was so rich I couldn't even finish it. I really appreciated the unique vegetarian options and look forward to coming back to try more of the offerings on the menu.
author: Tarah P.

description: I'm on a quest to visit all the places I have bookmarked and this place was conveniently located near Market for me to knock off my list. I got the Almond Croissant and Chocolate Bread. There was plenty of open seating inside so I sat down at a table to enjoy my pastries. The croissant was as delicious as everyone have said it is. It had a multitude of thin, buttery layers and a tasty filling. I think the chocolate bread was made from sourdough. It had that distinct sourdough flavor and tasted pleasantly of chocolate. There were even small pieces of chocolate embedded in the bread. It was a bit hard gnawing on the exterior but the inside was soft. They were out of their savory turnovers which I would have liked to try.
author: Lauren H.

description:
The Almond Croissant: BUTTERY, FLAKY, CRISPY DELICIOUSNESS  

Maybe order a drink with it and grab a table to enjoy. Lots of people bring their laptops to work from here.
author: Jen Y.

description:
I was going to give this place 4 stars but changed my rating to 5 stars halfway through writing my review when I realized I was starting to get hungry just thinking of their food.

Came here based on two separate recommendations and got the almond croissant. Super tasty! I ended up coming back the very next morning and got a savory turnover (think it was spinach and artichoke) and some cinnamon sticks. A friend who comes here regularly likes their sandwiches which I plan on trying next, although honestly I expect to have tried everything on the menu soon enough. Everything looks incredible! To the point where you can practically taste things with your eyes. I could've prefaced that sentence with a disclaimer about how I love pastries so take what I say with a grain of salt, but honestly I feel like most people would agree with me.

A word of warning though: even though individual items are reasonably priced, it's hard not to buy multiple things and end up with a meal-sized bill of muffins and cakes. Ask if they'll warm your order for you!
author: Dennis C.

description: Absolutely killer bread. I gave some to Friend and she had another friend try it and they were dying to go back and get some more
author: Linda S.

description:
Possibly the best croissants in San Francisco. So flaky and messy in their buttery, well, flakiness. Yum. The almond and chocolate ones are good too but I love the plain ones. 

Cakes are tasty. Cookies are good. Really nothing is bad. Have yet to sample a salad or sandwich though I always intend I do so -- next time. 

I'm in love with their mochas. But today I went with a plain old cafe au lait. And it is exceptional in its creaminess.
author: Tim P.

description:
Desserts: 3/5
Service: 4/5
Ambiance: 4/5
Overall:  id come back if I were in the area.

The extended review...

Desserts:

Apple galette - standard in taste and a good layer of apple on the pastry.  

Rustic Berry tart - a standard tart.  Crispy pastry and a good filling. 

Service: friendly and attentive staff.

Ambiance: it's a nice neighborhood spot where people come to work and chat.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
Usually love this place and would have given it a 5 star rating but today I had a shitty experience and will be taking a break for a bit. 

Got a ham and cheese croissant - the ones on display looked really good. While I wasn't paying much attention the employee ringing me up grabbed a croissant from the back instead that was obviously sitting out for a long time. How do I know? It was the last one on the tray. It was sad, crushed and soggy. The employee tossed it on the plate (literally tossed it on) without asking whether I wanted it heated up, which is usually what the employees here always ask, but today wasn't the case. I of course didn't notice any of the above until I sat down and took a bite. What was it like? Sad, cold, soggy croissant that had half the flavor of what everyone else is raving about. Cold béchamel sauce sucks. 

Things I love about this business:
Yummy pastries
Great bread 
Great patio
Reasonable prices 

Things that I don't like:
Today the service sucked, I got an old and cold croissant and it made me sad. I hope it gets better
author: Ivan R.

description: Delicious fresh baked croissants.  Unbelievably good.  Crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside.  Vast variety of sweet and savory baked goods.  Well worth a visit.  Enjoy.
author: Ali C.

description: Excellent pastry, good sandwiches, good coffee and a warm, cozy atmosphere. Open air garden in the back, ideal for hot summers.
author: Ionut G.

description: Went in at 5pm for an evening pastry and the almond croissant was still very delicious and fresh.
author: Alejandra B.

description:
One of my favorite cafes/bakeries with the best ham&cheese croissants I've yet to encounter in SF. Their croissants in general are super flakey with buttery dough without being greasy.

Great patio area in the back that has a chill vibe.
author: Ka L.

description:
For the record, I am bothered by cafes with droves of students lingering about for hours, using their Macbooks, after buying a single Vitamin Water. I am not one of those customers - I buy food and coffee, and if I do linger in order to do work, I typically buy something else.

Having said that, this place is such a tease. An outlet is under nearly all the tables along the wall indoors. But when I went today, none were working. The bathroom was out of order, so I could only remain so long in the cafe.

The food and drink is pretty well worth it. Hot tea in fancy pyramid bags. Above average drip coffee. Not horrible prices: $10 got me a chicken and salmon salad, but one I enjoyed. (I've often seen a $10 "Cobb" at other cafes that are essentially packaged arugula and ham you might find in a nicer gas station. Or a $10 crappier "Caesar" that's basically lettuce and crutons.)

No ice drinks on a hot summer day. Beautiful patio. Nice staff. Doubt I'll return, but it's an agreeable space.
author: David S.

description: I love the croissants here and went to indulge myself today. There was a full tray of what I thought were fresh baked croissants but when I went to order was told that there were no more. Puzzled, I asked about the tray further down. Apparently those were all day old croissants and they use them to make their almond croissants. I insisted that a day old croissant would still hit the spot, but to no avail. Quite disappointed by the cashier's lack of understanding and surprised to learn how their almond croissants are made. Food for thought...
author: Fritha C.

description:
(updated 6/15)

Since my initial review, the manager contacted me and finally met in person. They obviously investigated what happened and why that happened and explained to me that it was just an one-time incident. 

Very surprised that they actually contacted me to know the details and  I think this kind of fast corrective action following thorough investigation make them stand out and keep their quality high.

Impressed with their follow-up!
author: Mac K.

description:
Literally the best chocolate chip cookie I've ever had in my LIFE. It was amazing. Get it warmed up. Almond croissant was also superb. Flaky and crispy on the outside, warm and chewy on the inside. Perfect amount of sweetness.

They have a good selection of pastries, but a rather minimal drinks menu, which is fine. 

This place rivals B-Patisserie in terms of taste and quality, but is not nearly as crowded. Would choose this over B any day.
author: Jane H.

description:
ALMOND CROISSANT

Wow,  definitely haven't had a pastry this good in a while,  the croissant was both crispy on the outside,  yet lightly fluffy and buttery on the inside,  not soggy with the oils at all!  The almond paste an top was also lightly sweet and a little crisp on the outermost layer and coconut-paste-like (in a gaimeibao) right underneath.

Definitely coming back if a want a quick pastry
author: Tina A.

description: This bakery is a really cute neighborhood bakery. Lots of seating and pastry options. I would have stayed longer to work but they don't offer wifi which I understand can be a plus so people don't loiter. I had a savory scone which was delicious but the hot cocoa was average. The annual bread Christmas tree tradition is a sight to be seen. Wish they still made their bunny bread during Easter!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Hands down my favorite almond croissants- and I've only had them here today for the first time. I asked my brother, a San Francisco local foodie, "where do they have the best almond croissants?" He said probably here. He was beyond right. 

The bakery as soon as you walk in smelled amazing. There were lines to order and all the seats were taken. I wanted everything! (Savory turnovers and bread puddings. What!!). But I got what I came for and the result was beyond expected. 

As soon as you bite into the croissant, there's this incredible crunch and crisp as you bite deeper into each level. The middle is a little more saturated with the almond paste but the flavors are perfect. It's not very sweet and not at all bland- it just leaves you wanting more. For me, a good croissant entails of a good crisp (but not the crispy type that leaves your mouth hurting) and a good amount of sugar. 

I will so return for this bakery in the future. I've had my share of bakeries in San Francisco (bakery heaven?!?) but this is by far my favorite.
author: Lilian N.

description: Stopped in here to pick up some treats for coworkers on my way to work. The kind gentleman behind the counter selected a number of great pastries to sample and boxed everything up nicely. From this selection, I sampled the coffee cake and the blueberry scone. The coffee cake was good, but the scone was outstanding. A perfect balance of sweet and savory with a texture that was a nice balance of fluffy and crumbly. This humble store boasts some pretty amazing baked goods. I can't wait to go back to try some of their bread selections as well.
author: John W.

description:
The only thing to hate about Thorough Bread is how ridiculously close it is to my house. Because it's dangerous. Thank god it's not on my way to work, otherwise, I would be developing a 2 croissant a day habit. 

Rarely any lines (unlike Tartine), and amazing pastries of all kinds. Their croissants are like crack. Too often have I found myself walking by here and feeling compelled to buy an almond or ham and cheese croissant -- just depends if I'm in a sweet or savory mood. I'm also not above buying multiple pastries just because it's too tough to choose. 

Don't forget to get some gougeres to go because those little savory bread bites are ridiculously addictive. Don't kid yourself that you'll only eat one. 

Coffee here is legit (although don't even bother asking for iced coffee as they don't sell that here). Their cookies, scones, and muffins are also all solid options. Same with their fancy chilled desserts. But really, I'm in love with Thorough Bread's croissants and gougeres. 

I'm almost tempted to tell you to stay in the Tartine lines so you won't make this place too crowded, but I'll share my Thorough Bread. You'll thank me.
author: Vic C.

description:
Had lunch here for the first time last week. Someone told me about this place quite a while back but I never tried it. But boy I'm glad I did. I had the chicken sandwich my first time there and it was excellent. Reasonably priced. Had a cookie afterwords and it wasn't the best cookie I've had (though I'm kind of a cookie connoisseur). 

I liked my sandwich a lot but yesterday I stopped in on my way home and got the pulled pork sandwich this time. And that was excellent. Maybe one of the best I've had!

This place has friendly service, a simply laid out atmosphere and a nice patio in the back to boot.

The sandwiches are top notch. I gotta get back to start tasting some of those amazing pastries!
author: Chris D.

description:
Nice bakery with a patio and lots of light inside as well.
Tried the chocolate chip cookie and almond croissant. Both were good.
Good pastries and chill vibe for the win!
author: Coralie S.

description:
I stopped in here as I was running back to work from an errand, and immediately regretted not doing a little more noodling in the Yelp reviews before I came in. What do I order!? They seem famous, but for what!? Everything looks so good!

I changed my mind a few times before deciding on a raspberry muffin. It was fresh and flavorful, but I'm a fluffy muffin person and this one was capital "D" Dense. No matter, I'll be back because by the sounds of it the cookies and croissants are where it's at, and I love carbs.
author: Brittany B.

description:
almond croissant is pretty good. I came here at around 820am on Sunday and it wasn't crowded. no need to wait in line or something. service is fantastic. I ordered 4 almond croissants and at the beginning she was using a box for me. I asked if she could give me 4 small bags instead of a big box since i am going to give 2 of them to my friend. And she was really patient and nice moving each croissant to the bag for me. 
The store environment is good too. But since i left my dogs in the car so i can't dine-in. But i will definitely try eating there next time. 


almond croissant is super crispy and not that sweet which is exactly what i like :). it's $4.
author: Tina H.

description: I like the idea of Thorough more than the actual implementation. The back patio is gorgeous, but I think the food is lacking just a bit in imagination.
author: Jay M.

description:
This is my go to bakery, why wait in line at Tartine  when you can come here for all eats, sweets, and actually take a seat! 

Ham and cheese croissant, it perfectly flaky, with hame and cheese baked inside, and I believe béchamel cheese and breadcrumbs on the top. Ask them to warm it for you it tastes even better as the cheeses melt a bit. 

Almond croissant is up there with anything you would get in France. Just order them. My frenchies can't get enough of these! There is almond filling inside.  Don't get it warmed.. It's better the way it is, otherwise the sugar and croissant get a little dark and charred for lack of a better word. Friends from out of town prefer this place to any bakery they have ever been too.

Today they had a special Valentine's Panna cotta!Wow what a sweet treat the tart berries and deep red color, and served in a glass cup to go, can I take it back for a free refill? 

Who says you can't have breakfast for dessert. 

Quiche options change daily and the consistency and flavors are always amazing, each day a veggie and meat quiche is offered. Have not found another place in the area that offers quiche consistently that can compete with the options here. 

My only gripe I need you to get through some Monday's why must you ever close. (Rhetorical)
author: Morgan S.

description:
This place is great when it comes to finding an outdoor place to study. I think their coffee is slightly better than average. I don't really get food here though because I'm not all that into sandwiches and salads. But from the one sandwich and salad that I did get, I would say that it was good. The bread was yummy. 

Service is good. Coffee is good. Food is average. I think this place overall is good. I only give it three stars (really, 3.49) because nothing about it makes it stand out really from other bakery-cafes.
author: Rylan C.

description: Have tried there almond croissant and puff and both were AMAZING. Croissant is so crispy and tasty. I would buy like 5 if I am not on diet  The puff has some chocolate on the outside. The crunchy chocolate tastes really good with the soft puff and I really like it. People are friendly here too!
author: Xu C.

description:
I have been to this place several times and feel the need to rate this as many people are posting reviews which did not match my experience. Not many vegetarian options in sandwich's, the only veggie option is with sprouts in a sourdough bread and balsamic, tasted salty and of course no protein. Ordered different types of pastries as my CrossFit buddies keep talking a lot of good things about.
1) Croissant - pretty flaky (GOOD)
2) Chocolate Croissant - Not much chocolate inside it
3) Profiterole - Average 
4) Eclairs - Average 
6) Coconut Macaroon - hard and bad 
7) Chocolate cake - hard and did not taste good at all, like it was sitting in there for 5 days ($6.50) (DEFINATELY NOT WORTH 6.50).

I would never go back to this place.
author: Raj M.

description:
It's true - the best almond croissants you're likely to find!  (3/5 green stars)
I've had some very good almond croissants in the bay area - Firebrand and La Farine, for example - but I think Thorough Bread gets the prize. I also had a savory turnover (spinach and feta I think, perhaps) and a choc chip cookie. Just $8 for all three seemed very reasonable, especially considering the location. The space is very attractive - especially the patio out back. If I lived nearby I'd definitely come here regularly to relax on the patio or just to pick up pastries.

I'm giving them 3/5 "green stars" for social and environmental impact for now, mainly due to lack of information. Hopefully someone will get back to me with some answers. When I was in there I asked what kind of flour they used - nobody could answer the question. So I didn't bother asking any more complex questions, like are the eggs pasture-raised, etc. The website has no info and when I emailed them I received no response. So with a lack of information to base this on (other than the fact that they serve Sightglass coffee) I'm giving a neutral rating that I'll update if I hear back. It's a pity because they are the bakery outlet for the SF Baking Institute - transparency on ingredients should be part of what they teach.
Interested in writing green star reviews? If so, contact me! (greenstarsproject)
author: James K.

description: Favorite bakery in town! Love their almond croissant ! Coffee is great too. AND they have outdoor seating. Love love love!
author: Suparna J.

description:
A solid neighborhood bakery with a large variety of baked goods, including their well-known almond croissant, as well as a good selection of heartier offerings, whether decent sandwiches or items like quiche. 

It can get awfully hot inside, but the best part about the whole venue is the glorious outdoor garden in the back which can accommodate small groups for meetings. Overall, a decent choice in a neighborhood that lacks good-quality bakeries, unless you're willing to trek a bit further to the Mission or other nearby areas.
author: Vincent L.

description: So happy I found this cute lunch spot near my new office! Been here 3x in the past week; highly recommend the Turkey Cream Cheese Club sandwich and the Apple Galette. All of their ingredients are fresh and delicious!
author: Houston G.

description:
Out of  towners passed by , stopped by and enjoyed the brief visit. 
Delish selection of savory pastries such as savory scones , spinach turnover and ham/ cheese croissants. Lots of sweet options. Good coffee.  A cool garden in the back. Recommend it.
author: Dani O.

description:
Was walking by and had to take a look.

Nice looking bakery.  Outside seating in the back.  Friendly staff. Great looking items.

I choose a chocolate croissant.  Flakey and buttery.  I just wish it had a little more chocolate inside.  Great tasting though.
author: Sam V.

description: I strong believe that Thorough Bread has the best almond croissants in San Francisco! They even rival the ones from Tartine Bakery. Skip Tartine's line and stop by this place for almond croissants and the ham and cheese croissant.
author: John L.

description:
WOW, Thorough Bread positively hit ALL of my 5 senses. It's gonna be difficult fighting back the urge to come back every single day... I totally understand the stellar reviews, but the deliciousness of their food is an understatement!

SIGHT: Right when you enter, you can see their collection of bread and pastries neatly lined up for you to purchase. Everything looked amazing... I wanted to order all of it!!! It's a lovely coffee shop/patisserie/sandwich place. The decor gives you that rustic and homey feel, taking you back to your mother's or grandmother's kitchen.

SMELL: Don't even get me started on the smell. The smell of fresh bread lingering throughout my entire 30 minute existence at the place can't accurately be put into words. Seriously, I'm not even mad that I still smell like bread.

TASTE: I ordered the gougeres (amazing deal by the way), ham & cheese croissant, and chicken melt sandwich. All super tasty. They all had the right amount of flakiness and crisp that makes you wonder HOW?! 

TOUCH: The items that I ordered were soft and heated at the right temperature. Not greasy or oily like most pastry places.

HEARING: Gosh, I love the customer service. Quick, friendly, and gets the job done!

Note: Unfortunately, this place is not in downtown SF, so I can't just walk outside my office and it'll magically appear. However, you can take the muni metro to Church Station and it's literally 2 minutes away (walking distance).
author: Jenny H.

description: So far I have only had the chocolate drizzled creme puffs. They are delightful, and I look forward to trying more!
author: Riley J.

description:
Dear SF Pride,

In recognition of your fabulousness, I am going to eat ALL the rainbow foods! 

This includes Thorough Bread's buttery shortbread-like Castro Cookies.

It's a tough job but somebody's got to do it.

XO
Amy C.

p.s. I also got an Almond Croissant but there was NO pride. 

Though it wasn't rainbow colored, I gobbled it down in less than two minutes.

#WaddleOfShame
author: Amy C.

description:
Basis for my starred ratings (which skews heavily to the food or drink):
1 star:  Never again.
2 stars:  Poor food, poor experience, extraordinary measures in order for me to come back.
3 stars:  Average, nothing really special, nothing particularly bad.
4 stars:  Very good, would definitely return.
5 stars:  A favorite, one of the best.

A very good, though I don't believe one of the best bakeries in San Francisco.

Major pluses include the outdoor seating area in the back, which was gorgeous when we were in town.  Also, a good cappuccino.  Finally, my wife raves about the mini carrot cake here.  One of the best she has ever tasted, and I agree, it is quite good.

I ordered a quiche with bacon and squash, and an order of the gougeres.  The quiche was quite good, way above average.  The crust was a little thin, but it was still flaky.  Good balance between the saltiness of the bacon and the sweetness of the squash.  The egg was cooked well and well set.  The gougeres were fine.  They were light and had a great cheesy flavor, but, tasted a little grainy on the back end?  There was something off, not so much that I wouldn't eat them any more, but just a tad off.

They warmed up the quiche and gougeres for me before serving which was great.  We'll be back to try more of their food and baked goods.
author: Rich B.

description: I came here in between dance classes, and I was starving. It's a really beautiful spot, and the pastries all smelled super good. The boy and I split the chicken melt and Caprese sandwich. The Caprese sandwich was alright - a little bland, but the bread was amazing. It was much better when dipped in the salad vinaigrette. However, the chicken melt was great! I would definitely get that again. The only con is that they don't have wifi here, but I guess if they did, they would never have tables available. A little pricey [close to $30 for two sandwiches], but quite good.
author: Amy L.

description: Amazing place! The best raisin rolls ever. Very good hot chocolate. Staff is super friendly. Delicious ham and cheese croissant.
author: Margarita B.

description: Is a great place to drink a delicious cup of coffe alone or with your doggie like me or if you prefer with friend.
author: Miguel C.

description:
Solid bakery worth the hype. I prefer their pastries over Tartine. Price is more reasonable too. You HAVE to get their almond croissant. I'm a huge almond croissant girl and they have the best in the city. 

We also ordered:
* Pulled Pork Sandwich: good but not out-of-this-world kind of pulled pork (you know what I'm talking about if you're a pulled pork lover)
* Sweet bread pudding: make sure you ask to warm it up. It was just the right amount of sweetness and sogginess
* ham and cheese croissant: too much cheese inside the croissant and outside as well. You may like it if you like the more salty/savory pastries. Bread itself was fluffy and so good. 

Came here on a rainy day with my friends after church. Can get crowded on the weekends (not really a place you can camp out with your laptop for a long time).
author: Christine C.

description: Cute little bakery and cafe. Got a few pastries here, all of them were great. Come early as they run out of baked goods early.
author: Mia D.

description:
First of all, this place smells amazing. We arrived before 8:00am and there were already a few patrons waiting outside. 

We had a late dinner the previous night so I was really just wanting a cup of coffee. Once inside, I couldn't resist. I ordered a small Rustic Fruit Tart and J ordered a Stick Bun, which they warmed upon request. 
They also have a nice selection of cookies, sweets and  rustic breads. Yum.

To top it off, I had accidentally left my bag with wallet and phone handguns on my chair. We were on a morning walk and I didn't even miss it until we stopped in a store over an hour later. I called Thorough Bread and having seen I left it, placed it in the back office until I returned. Phew!

Thank you!!
author: Kris M.

description:
I like pastries, and I like tea - Thorough Bread & Pastry dishes up both of those things and they do it pretty well. 

Star 1: How were the service and atmosphere?

The indoor outdoor patio seating arrangement at Thorough is in and of itself a huge appeal; and I could have easily spent the entire morning just sitting and observing or reading as I saw many others doing. Service is fast and friendly. Star Granted. 

Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?

$3.50 for a smaller sticky bun isn't exactly a bargain, but it isn't a price gouge either; nor is the $4.00 that I spent for my Chai Latte. Star Granted. 

Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?

My Chai Latte was good, although it admittedly had a bit of an unusual grainy sort of consistency across the top of it and it was quite a bit more whipped than what I'm used to. That's not a bad thing per se, but it was a bit different.

The sticky bun; unfortunately, was pretty weak, with lacking flavor and only average consistency. Not my favorite. 

Single Star Granted. 

Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?

I can't say I would, but Thorough is worth a visit just for the atmosphere. No Star Granted.
author: Paul V.

description: This is a fabulous bakery. I love the coffee and the great selection of scones, croissants, quiches, etc. Love the sandwiches, salads. Had a fantastic scone and coffee and took a tuna sandwich with boiled egg on a brioche roll with potato chips to go, for lunch. Was it tasty? Yes! Also, the atmosphere is lovely and wholesome. Everyone is friendly with the customers and each other, and you can watch them bake and display their baked goods. It is homey. In the back, is a lush place among the trees where you can sit and savor. Enjoy!!! I always do!!!
author: Donna C.

description:
I loved every pastry I tried here! I'll definitely be coming back. The place itself is cute with nice seating indoors and some outdoor in the front and patio. 

We got a potato turnover, savory scone, ham and asparagus quiche ($5), and coffee cake. Most of the pastries on display were about $3. My favorites were the potato turnover and savory scone. They were both really unique flavors. The potato turnover was filled with collard greens and caramelized onions and the scone had rosemary, asiago, and walnut. Super good!
author: Linda X.

description:
Those that know me know that I like to frequent bakeries and that I like gougeres. A good friend at work lived near this bakery and once brought me a few gougeres from Thorough Bread. I had not heard of this place at that time, so I thought he had gone to a horse show. 
A few minutes passed, and I polished them off. I tried to savor all four, because they're small, but leave some carbs on my desk and you're asking them to disappear.
So naturally I paid Thorough Bread & Pastry a visit after that taste... and a couple more times after that. The childlike crayon logo is very charming.

Gougeres - 4 for $2? 12 for $4.50? 
I'll take 2 dozen please. I'll serve them proudly on a plate and pretend they are homemade. Just kidding...kind of. A gougere is a cheese puff. Given the price and inconspicuous appearance, you wouldn't think much of them, but I found them to be executed well. The dough was light and puffy, with many pockets of air. The cheese and chive flavor was savory and well-balanced.

Chouquettes - 4 for $2
Basically the sweet version of puff pastry, topped with a few specks of pearl sugar

Cream Puffs - 3 for $3.50
A rather light cream puff with chocolate drizzled on top, also with pearl sugar. delightful

Danish - $2.00
I had a blueberry and a cheese danish. Both were delicious and flaky with a glaze. The blueberry could have used more fruit filling. The cheese danish was just creamy and smooth.

Almond Croissant - $3.50
This is an excellent croissant, super flaky and airy with generous almond paste on top and lots of almond slivers. I think it rivals some of the best almond croissants in the city.

Apple Galette - $2.50
Very good apple tart. Thinly sliced apples baked on top of flaky pastry. There was a shiny, sweet glaze on top that added sweetness and was probably a good glue to keep the apple slices in place

Chocolate Bread - $3.50
I didn't have high hopes for chocolate bread. I thought it would be dry, but it was pillowy inside with a nice outer crust. The best part was it was loaded with chocolate chips.

Chocolate Chip Cookie - $1.50
Thin, crunchy cookie, also with plenty of choc chips

Basil Mozzarella Sandwich - $7
The bread on the sandwich was excellent of course. The tomatoes & mozzarella tasted fresh. I love a good simple caprese sandwich, but I would have preferred it toasted. It seemed like they had just finished serving their morning crowd and didn't bother to ask us if we wanted it toasted. Oh well. It also came with some mixed greens. 

Thorough Bread has a lot of variety - pastries, fresh bread, cakes, sandwiches, etc. Grabbing a few things to eat and hanging out in their outdoor patio in the back is a good way to spend a sunny afternoon. Good work, SF Baking Institute!
author: Joy W.

description:
Sometimes, I feel like my work location is some type of test to see how much I can avoid adding to my waistline with all the great, local restaurants/stores in my vicinity.  Thorough Bread got onto my radar when I was walking on Church St one day, and I've enjoyed their delectable pastries ever since.

From their almond croissants to their macaroons, I've never been disappointed in their baked goods.  Their croissants have a wonderfully flaky texture, and my only regret is that I limit myself to one sweet item at a time when I visit.  I've also tried their espresso-based drinks and thought their coffee was great. 

The only thing limiting me from giving this place a 5-star review is that when I tried one of their sandwiches (the turkey bacon club), I thought it was fine but not quite up to the excellent standards of their pastries.  I'll have to try their lunch menu in the future and see if this is a consistent thing with their main food items or if I just ended up choosing a less than perfect option.  In any case, Thorough Bread is definitely one of my go-to's when I'm looking for something sweet in the neighborhood!
author: Keith H.

description: A little treasure in the Castro. Thorough Bread & Pastry is a lovely spot to grab a bite and hang out! I had the chicken melt, tasty & filling, and finished my meal off with a threesome of mini cream puffs and delicious, hand crafted latte. But the real drawvis the pleasant backyard patio, lush and plant filled, with a nice scattering if tables, it doesn't feel like you're in the heart of the big city! I'll definitely be going back to hang bout here!
author: Rose C.

description: I've tried their baked goods and sandwiches and have never been disappointed. Their savory scones are always tasty and the coffee is good too.
author: Janette W.

description:
Don't come here if you're on a low carb diet. Gluten, gluten, gluten, gluten rockin' errrrrywhere...

I tried their savory bread pudding and soup of the day. I enjoyed the cauliflower soup (pureed with other veggies). The bread pudding was also good. And my friend's ham and cheese sando was yom yom. 

They have a whole bunch of pastry options, and they're known for their almond croissants and sticky buns. I'm no sweet tooth Sally, so I'll pass on those. My friend likes 'em though!

I LOVE the outdoor patio. So peaceful and quaint. One table was a desk- I dig the uniqueness. I appreciate how this place is not as crowded as other cafes. It's a full house, yet you're usually able to find seating. Excellent community gathering place- knitting clubs and the laptop crowd alike come here. (For real, I saw a group of people knitting in the back of the patio. Right on...)
author: Joanna L.

description:
- To-die for and affordable bread 
- To-die for an affordable pastries (I used to live in Iowa and Ohio -- seriously -- this is affordable, even by Midwest standards of pastries 
- Great atmosphere and beautiful backyard / garden seating 
- Super attentive and fast service 
- They're currently doing name-your-own price chocolate chip cookies for charity to help NCal with the fires -- gotta love them for that.
author: Salim Z.

description:
A little pricey but sweetness levels on the pastries/desserts are always on point! I especially recommend the croissants! They're crispy on the outside, and lightly fluffy and buttery on the inside, not overwhelming with the grease at all!

Be prepared to fight for seating though and no wifi unfortunately :(
author: Sarah Z.

description: This review is solely for their cream puff and their signage. Get the cream puff. Now. Perfect size, great consistence in the cream, just sweet enough to satisfy. Also, I love their sign writer.
author: Shoole S.

description: This place has the most delicious baked goods, I'm esp a fan of their croissants! Interior is nothing fancy but the goods are simply delicious
author: Coco J.

description:
I went here because Tartine was too crowded and some reviews said this place is better and better it was! Get yourself one of their Almond Croissants and coffee (they use Sightglass beans!) and you'll know what I'm talking about. 

The folks here are friendly and the pricing is reasonable, I'm definitely coming back soon. 5 stars.
author: Gouthaman K.

description: Ok 2 words: Almond Croissant!! If you have not yet experienced this delight you are missing out! Just go in order it and don't think twice! Other pastries are pretty good too, bread is okay but the almond croissant is the star of the show. They have a pretty patio out the back as well which is a nice place to sit and chill for a bit. Worth visiting for sure!
author: Sophia V.

description:
Just had a breakfast snack here on a sidewalk table and tried two items: a quiche and a criossant.

Bussel sprout-poblano quiche: The brussel sprouts are a bit unexpected when it comes to a breakfast quiche, but it works! 

Berry-almond croissant: delicious. Flaky crust, sweet center filling, just the right mix of flavors. 

My girlfriend had a macchiato when she liked, so there's that as well. 

The service seemed quick despite a small crowd, and the back patio looked pretty nice.  Next time!
author: Charles R.

description:
This is my favourite pastry place. It's bad that it's so delicious and close to my house because I can't resist going in for a treat far too often. Haven't had anything as good anywhere else in the city. 

Pro tip the cookies are to die for. They fall apart in your mouth and somehow (I think it's probably witch magic they would have been burned for just two hundred years ago) the chocolate chips are always gooey.
author: Ryan C.

description: Cute little cafe/ bakery with fresh loaves of bread, various pastries, good coffee and even sandwiches. Stopped in for an almond croissant and it did not disappoint. They even warmed it up for me. I will be coming back to try more of their baked goods :)
author: Jenine G.

description:
I would be 10 pounds heavier if I lived in the Castro neighborhood because of thorough bread! 

I wish I could've tried multiple items on my visit here
---almond croissant: love how this croissant is light since some almond croissants are dauntingly sweet to finish! Yumm
---espresso with cold soy milk: they don't offer iced drinks here so this was the closest I could get! 

NOTE: super cute hidden garden/patio area out back but all the tables were taken when we came so we sat on the sidewalk out front
author: Jenny S.

description:
I think this was the best almond croissant I've ever had.
The coffee was great and the place is clean and simple.
author: Kat A.

description:
Great little spot for a quick breakfast on a Sunday morning (no wait). The coffee is great and the quiche and savory pastries are fabulous.

Sadly, the sweet pastries are not very good. The almond croissant, bread pudding, pear crostata, and key lime tart were all just-ok. It's the first time I brought pastries home from SF and nobody finished any of them. 

I would come back for savory pastries and the cute patio seating in the back.
author: Melissa D.

description:
Surprisingly good, despite its modest appearances. Love the pastries, particularly the croissant varieties. Love the garden in the back! 
It's a great part of the Castro.
author: rik p.

description:
So I haven't had a chance yet to try their famous croissant yet, but it's on my list! This review is for their desserts.

Overall I'd give 3 stars for the desserts - there seemed to be a bit of a trend with the desserts being a little too sweet without much depth of flavor. The macarons, for instance - both were a bit sweet, but while the black sesame flavor still came through, I didn't really get any orange flavor from the blood orange option. The texture was spot on, though. But at $2 a pop for these mini macarons, I was hoping for more flavor!

But an extra star for service - the girl who helped me was very friendly and prompt, and threw in an extra macaron when I ordered a half dozen :)
author: Delia Z.

description:
Thorough Bread is my ABSOLUTE favorite coffee shop/patisserie in the city. Their pastries are just delicious. From coffee cakes to the pain au chocolat, Thorough Bread never disappoints. They also serve SightGlass coffee, which is very good. 

Take a seat on the back patio to enjoy some fresh air, and enjoy the coffee and pastries. Very walkable for those who live in Castro, and it's less than a block away from the Church St Muni station for those outside the immediate area.
author: Mike D.

description:
Bakery and coffee shop near Duboce. 

Almond croissant - 4/5 - On 2013 7x7 list. Crunchy, flaky. Good taste on the frangipane. Could have used just a little more filling. Very good when warmed up. One of the better versions of the almond croissant in SF. 

Blueberry scone - 3/5

Overall, solid bakery. "I'm a fan. "
author: Mark O.

description: I absolutely love this bakery! You can get your good bread and pastries without the super long lines like a lot of SF bakeries. You also don't have to worry about bread being available only after 4pm (Tartine), or the store closing so early (Neighbor Bakehouse). They have a good mix of sweet and savory pastries, so you can get either (or both!), depending on your mood. In addition, they also have many different kinds of artisan bread. I've tried my share of their food and all are delicious, but for me, epi is definitely a must! The coffee is good, and the ambiance is nice too. The place is small and cozy, and there's an outdoor seating area as well. Not sure if I'm just lucky but I've never had trouble finding a place to sit. It's a nice place to chill on a weekend when you are craving some yummy carbs but don't want to deal with crowds!
author: Michelle F.

description: I concur with everyone else's review that the almond croissants here are absolutely amazing. Their other pastries are also good, but the almond croissants particularly stand out. They also have a back patio area that's really cute and a great place to spend an afternoon working or reading. The service is also really nice, and they'll warm up your order for you.
author: Keerthi N.

description: It was my Birthday last Saturday and I hit 4 bakeries in a roll. However, Thorough Bread wasn't on the list. So today I decided to head over and sample their apple galette. Once there, I chose the rustic apple tart instead, it was another OMG moment, ha-ha. I don't know folks, we just have some stellar bakeries in the city. That tart was super buttery, flaky, a perfect pastry. It's on par with Arsicault's almond croissant.  We're blessed to have the best bakeries in the country. That's a fact.
author: Anthony W.

description:
Great pastries!

The almond croissant was definitely one of the best I've ever had. So perfectly sweet and flaky, with a generous amount of almonds on top. The mini berry cheesecake was tasty too, with a great balance of sweet and tart from the cream cheese.

Knocking off a star because the gougeres (egg/cheese puffs) were the only thing that weren't great. Maybe I got a batch that wasn't as fresh, but I didn't think that they had a great texture, and I didn't get as much cheese flavor as I wanted. 

Judging from the almond croissant and mini cheesecake, I actually think it's better quality and less hyped than Tartine, despite the slightly disappointing gougeres. 

I'll definitely be back to try more from their large variety of pastries!
author: Sara L.

description:
I can always trust TBP to bake delicious, buttery pastries. I ordered the huge lemon blackberry mousse cake ($38) for Father's Day. It can serve 10-12 people. Trust me, the price is worth it for this beautiful cake! The fruit and cream were so fresh, and the cake was perfect in its tartness. My father, a man of few praises for food, absolutely loved the cake. Thank you to TBP for baking the best cake for such a special occasion.

I had walked into the bakery expecting to just pick up the cake and leave. Lo and behold, my sister and I walked out with three delicious pastries (cause we can't help it)! We got the jalapeño corn muffin, the bacon scone (a must have), and a pear newton (the more expensive relative of the fig newton). We left with happy stomachs.
author: Joanne K.

description:
I've passed by Thorough Bread several times but never made an effort to actually come here to eat pastries. I had a sudden urge to visit one Sunday morning so my boyfriend and I stopped in and were immediately impressed by the variety of pastries and the fact that there is an outdoor patio in the back!! So cool. Love when I discover those.

We ordered an almond croissant, some fruit danish, and an apple gallette. All of them were fresh, flaky, and delicious! We sat outside on the patio since all the seats inside were taken. It had been raining earlier, so the atmosphere was like a tropical rainforest. Quaint and quiet place to hang out with friends and/or pets while snacking on your pastries. Oh and don't forget to purchase a baguette on your way out! I'll have to do that next time.
author: Stefanie C.

description: Best local bakery on church! I haven't had anything I didn't like and I've tried a lot of their stuff. Go for lunch, get a sandwich and soup, and sit on the back private patio and enjoy the quiet serenity. It will be your favorite spot too!
author: Joy M.

description: Although the macchiato I ordered tasted great, the presentation was rather poor. There weren't anyone else in line, so there wasn't really any excuse for such a messy cup. The almond croissant was very tasty, however when asked to have it heated up it took more than 4 minutes and my coffee was already cold. They do have a nice patio with lots of natural lighting. I'll come back for further reviews!
author: Rj L.

description:
I haven't been by in a while and it doesn't seem like I missed anything. Either the almond croissants aren't as good as what I remember or the standards have gone up with so many new good pastry shops in the city.

I remember them being the best in SF and not too expensive to boot. Now they're still better priced ($3.50) but I'm not sure it's worth it. Instead of being light, buttery and flakey they're deflated and a overcooked (burnt). Nothing special at all.
author: Jean K.

description: Mel's usual - almond croissant and mocha. Sometimes the turnovers. Sometimes the scones. At times the sweet rolls. Comfortable seating plenty of natural light and Joanna told me to get out of her Instagram shot
author: S S.

description:
Great almond croissant!!! I was completely won over at the first bite. Warm, flaky, fluffy, well-flavored inside, and not too sweet on the coat outside, it made me wonder what they did to take croissant to the next level of tastiness. 

They also have a quite backyard to immense yourself with nature and food!
author: Yuhuan T.

description:
Consistently great. We go there every Sunday morning and I'm still yet to try something mediocre.
Everything they make is simply balance and enjoyable at its max. Not too much not too little 
I love going there
author: Bruno P.

description:
Prices are lower than Tartine and without the line. When the weather is nice, try passing some time in  the lovely outdoor seating area in the back. 

Their almond croissants and gougères are delicious. Also their spinach feta turnover... and the quiche.... and the scones...Get them!
My friends love their cookies. 

Not necessarily a fan of their fruity croissant options but they have so many other options available it's not factored for scoring this establishment.
author: Nathan C.

description:
When I want to get coffee and pastry, this place is usually my first choice

The pastries are good. Their almond and plain croissants are among the best I've had in SF. I think they make the second best blueberry scones in SF. And other items I've tried are at least better than average.

They usually have the items I want. There have been occasions when they were either out of something or they were about to make more of that item, but those occasions were few.

Prices are reasonable. 

No ridiculously long lines. This one is important for me. Despite the prime location and good products, this place doesn't seem to attract bozos whose main purpose in life seem to be forming and adding to long-ass lines. I have been here at various times and days of the week and I have yet to wait longer than 3 minutes. Even on weekend mornings, I can find a seat. There are tables inside, in the back patio, and two small tables out front.

Bike parking. There is one rack and two parking meters directly in front of the store so you can keep an eye on your bike.

Good staff. The vibe is generally positive and welcoming without being over-animated.
author: keith s.

description: We love this cafe!  Nothing better than a cup of coffee and a hunk of savory bread pudding on a Saturday morning.  And those mini Gruyere and cream puffs!  This neighborhood gem has been a favorite of ours for years.  So much so that we ordered desserts from them for our wedding this last weekend.  Working with Courtney on the large order was a breeze.  The cream puffs, mini macaroons, and fruit pates were a hit!  So much better than a big wedding cake no one wants to eat. Thank you Thorough Bread for helping to make our big day a little sweeter :)
author: Jen H.

description:
We came for the macarons and left with the macarons and macaroons. 
Service was quick and pleasant even though the place was the perfect amount of busy. The patio in the back was quaint and Percy place to grab my sugar high.
author: Kristin M.

description: Really delicious almond croissant and blueberry scones! There is a wide variety of pastries. It would be better if the pastries could be warmed up (but I didn't ask either). Def worth a try if you're around there :)
author: Tina C.

description: I really, really like this bakery.  I've been in a couple times.  They have the best croissants in SF.  They also make a mean latte.  But what I really like is the back patio.  It's a green and quiet oasis.  I could spend all day there.  Wonderful things in the bakery include Croissants, savory pastries, snickerdoodles and chocolate chip cookies.
author: Andrew S.

description: They make delicious pastries and serve sight glass coffee. They also offer a small selections of sandwiches. Pleasant and friendly customer service.
author: Natalie H.

description: What a blessing to have so many quality bakeries in town! This place is no different, plenty of delicious options. And walking distance from another bakery that tends to have crazy lines. If you come to Thorough you will not be disappointed. Good bread and croissants ($), good pastries($+), good hot breakfast options($+), and great coffee ($).
author: Andrew L.

description: How are there still lines at Tartine? Same neighborhood, arguably more delicious. Almond croissant: on point. Country sourdough: on point. Banana chocolate chip pecan muffin: on point. Almond milk cappuccino: better than four barrel's. Yes, it's that good.
author: Charlotte A.

description:
Lemon tart, super sweet.
Vibe, super chill.
Walk, super long from the Bart. (Sike, not really only cause I was lugging around a bunch of stuff).
Workers, super nice. 
The back, super relaxing.

I'd recommend coming here to study or just to get away.
author: Susan H.

description: Came here for coffee and pastries after lunch. Not sure if it was because it was "late" for a bakery that opens pretty early, but there weren't many cake options available in the case. The bread looked and smelled amazing though. Ended up getting two cappuccino, one regular and one with almond milk and a key lime pie to share. The drinks were quite good, but the pie was too sweet. Maybe their other pastries would be better. We were lucky to find seating in the back, which was nice and breezy. 4 stars for the ambiance and coffee.
author: Lindy C.

description:
This is one of my favorite bakeries in SF. It's WAY better than Tartine, and you don't have to wait in a huge line. 

Their almond croissants are the best, and I usually don't even like almond croissants because they're too creamy. But these are something else. I also love their blueberry scones and chocolate chip cookies. The sandwiches are pretty good too, but I'm a sucker for the pastries.
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
Dear Yelp, 

I think I have come across the best kept secret of San Francisco. Earlier today I indulged in what must have been the most delicious ham & cheese croissant. I repeat the MOST DELICIOUS HAM AND CHEESE CROISSANT. No competitors can compare.

Sincerely,
Sarin 

(PS please try the ham & cheese croissant, you're welcome)
author: Sarin P.

description:
I was in the mood for good fresh baked bread but Tartine didn't have any (they bake and sell loaves at 4:45pm daily) so I stopped by the next nearest one - Thoroughbread. I've been back on several occasions and had not been impressed:

- Olive bread - same dough as foccacia. Super hard and crusty. 
- French Baguette - very mediocre, I think Safeway bread is better 
- Cupcakes - meh. 

Sorry but this was a thoroughly disappointing bakery in my opinion.
author: Jess C.

description: This has become a favorite lunch spot since I discovered it several years ago. They make their own pastry items which other reviewers have covered.  They also bake their own bread which is good, I particularly like the whole-wheat bread which is only available at the weekend. They make sandwiches to order as well as homemade soup, which changes on a daily basis. I wish they offered a soup and half sandwich option but since they don't I order a sandwich and my partner order a sandwich and we ask them to split the order, which they generally do without any problem. Luckily they do not have WiFi otherwise people would stay at their table even longer than they otherwise do, which can be a problem at weekends.  Overall a great place for pastries, bread, soup and sandwiches.
author: Fred B.

description: The Mediterranean Omlette was 14.25$ and for that price it was a pretty bad one even by SF standards. There was no wait to get a table.
author: Abi K.

description:
SO cheap, and so delicious --

Here are my two favorites:
1. almond croissants: these ARE, in fact, to die for. pulled perfectly apart, you can see all the thin soft doughy layers, yet you can enjoy perfectly browned crusty outside corners of these tasty pastries. perfectly sweet, not overwhelmingly sugary. we got these warm, EXTRA points
2. olive bread: gigantic fresh meaty olives inside crusty bread. SO good.

Highly recommended and my mouth is watering as I write this review, definitely DEFINITELY coming back.
author: Kristie C.

description:
Five stars for the outdoor patio alone. One of the best places in the city to come on a weekend morning, have a coffee, and relax outside. The patio feels as if it were in a garden, with trees and shrubs surrounding the entirety of it, which also makes it shaded and cool during the recent heat waves. It is also sequestered in the back of the property, so there is no chance of being accosted by the homeless during your breakfast.

The pastries are also excellent. Haven't had anything I didn't enjoy, with the favorites being the coffee cake and the savory bread pudding. Given their high quality baked good, their prices are also quite reasonable, with most pastries in the $3 range.

The combination of the marvelous patio and their top notch pastries make this an unbeatable morning getaway.
author: Michael S.

description: My first time here, and definitely not my last. After reading numerous positive reviews on Yelp, I stopped by for a pastry and coffee. I went with the much lauded almond croissant and a nonfat latte. The croissant was what a buttery, decadent splurge should taste like. Simply exquisite and worth every calorie. Buttery, flaky layers; just the right amount of almond paste and toasted almonds; ample sized without being oversized; and the perfect level of subtle sweetness. My latte was hot and flavorful. I ate indoors with a view of their special made-of-bread Christmas Tree. I ordered a holiday stollen to-go and, while good, it was a little too sweet for me. Service was efficient and friendly. The woman who helped me offered recommendations with a smile. I'll be back next time I'm in the city.
author: Nina C.

description: This neighborhood bakery is a jewel!!! The pastries rival what we ate in Paris. The cafe atmosphere is casual, comfortable and inviting. And, the staff are super friendly and helpful. Favorites include the chicken melt sandwich ,  the almond croissant and the corn meal - cherry scone. Your taste buds will thank you!!!
author: Alan W.

description: Best place to get bread! Bought two baguettes, one multi grain, and one sourdough to bring back home with me to Los Angeles. Crunchy on the outside and soft in the inside. Absolute delight. My family was in love with the bread. Definitely coming back for round two on my next trip.
author: Sophia H.

description:
After a heavy lunch, we were craving for some pastry. Looked up bakeries on Yelp, and found out about this place. We got there an hour before they close, so they were out of some of the pastries. 

They have a good amount seatings inside, and they also have a patio. Even though the patio seemed quite nice, we ended up sitting inside due to the weather being really cold. I liked the vibe here. Very warm and cozy.

The lady who took our order recommended us their almond croissants and cream puffs. All the items were tasty and fresh. Most items here are around $3. The almond croissant was covered with almond flakes, and it was very buttery. The cream puffs were very creamy; however, not as tasty as the croissant. I felt the cream fell a bit short and it was a bit bland. 

We also tried their cappuccino, and it was average. Not mind blowing, but good enough.

But hey, this review's focus is on their pastry not their coffee. So, they definitely deserve a 4 star.
author: Ashkan H.

description: really delicious tea I ordered the raspberry tea and the patio is so nice to just sit and chill or have a sweet conversation. Large selection of pastries I didn't try but would like to someday
author: Cecilia H.

description: This is my new favorite. Everything about the place makes it great: nice light, big windows, sweet garden area, always-smiling staff. And that's not even about the food. Their sandwiches are super tasty, every pastry I've had is the best of its kind. Prices are fair, not high, and they have 75 cent cookies! I love seeing the pastry chefs rolling dough and filling tarts in their white coats. I wish I lived around the corner.
author: Seth M.

description: No WiFi. A reminder for myself to read the about the details of a place first before going there. Their pastries are supposedly good and the coffee was ok - not great - but ok.
author: Freddy E.

description:
4 stars for the bread and pastries. Pretty good chai here. They've also got a pillowy light ciabatta loaf - makes it harder to cut but very delish. I was able to make some nice sandwiches and garlic bread out of it. Not my favorite bakery (that might be b. patisserie), but it's a great one to have in this area, and you can get yourself some proper loaves here.

2 stars for the sandwiches. I got a garden sandwich one afternoon, only to get my veggies served on stale focaccia. :( Not fun having stale bread scrape up your mouth...Another day I got the bruschetta sandwich, this time during lunch hours. This wasn't bad; they also toasted this one. I don't know if it's worth the price, however. For sandwiches, I'd go to any number of other places from now on.
author: Linus W.

description: I really want to like this place. Nice staff, nice patio and mostly good food, but I'm really disappointed this morning. My chocolate croissant had a tiny thin strip of chocolate in one side, see photo. The chocolate is pretty good so I wanted more!
author: Ajj J.

description:
I've been going to Thorough Bread for the past four years. I've had terrific pastries, coffee that's okay, and the staff is super friendly.

However, if I'm honest, small things change over time that have made it not what I remember it to be. The prices, but I can live with that (costs are going up for them too I'm sure!). But then today, they told me they won't even slice the bread they bake anymore on request - at up to $10/loaf, is slicing such a big deal for them (or at least allowing me to even do it, which I asked)? And what bakery doesn't do something that simple, especially if a simple machine does it easily? While the frontline staff seemed apologetic for some management directive, there's no reason they could provide beyond "we've been told we're not allowed to slice bread anymore."

It's one small thing, but I feel it's this gradual loss of feeling excited to give you the best product you can get for the customer by people who are so excited about you getting to try their work. You pay for that, but you know you're getting what's potentially the best product for 100s of miles. It's now more apathetic, and "take it or leave it - we really don't care" attitude. That's what I know is standard in other cities, but I've always loved shops in SF because they didn't do that.

I'm just going to Whole Foods now for bread - I get "take it or leave it" and only marginally lower quality at much much less price. It's just not worth the hassle.

ADDENDUM: I think I was a bit harsh in my initial review. While I still think the minor details like cutting bread should be basic, their pastries are actually pretty good and their staff is super friendly. 4 stars is probably much more fair
author: Punit S.

description:
This is a wonderful local spot. They have delicious pastries and food. All of the pastries are reasonably priced. I pick some up for my coworkers all of the time and they are thoroughly appreciated.

They have free wifi and delicious coffee as well. It's a very casual, order at the counter atmosphere. One of the best perks is the garden in the back (with seating). It's one of my favorite hidden patios. 

Great spot to have a date or meet up with a friend.
author: Juliet S.

description:
I come into Thorough Bread about once a year when I'm nearby and want a small bite. I never gave this place enough credit for serving delicious pastries and breads without the fuss and hype of places like Tartine. I love Tartine but it's such an ordeal to go- workers seem to purposely move slowly, and on the rare occasion I go, I end up spending like $50. Thorough Bread is reliable and though prices have crept up, it is quite affordable for the quality. 

Recently I spent hours trying to make chouquettes for a party. The sugar was burnt, they were too eggy, and they were deflated. I totally forgot I could just buy them here (prices keep changing but they are now 50 cents). I picked up a few dozen chouquettes and gougeres. They were so worth the price considering how much time and money I spent trying to make them. Then there are also the breads. At this same party, I was putting together a sandwich bar so was able to pick up all the breads from here -ciabatta, epi, baguettes, and rolls that come in different sizes. 

I also just discovered their olive fougasse. It's a flat bread shaped like a complex pretzel (apparently supposed to be shaped like wheat?). The bread is brushed with olive oil and there are plenty of olive bits in every bite. I'll definitely be frequenting Thorough Bread more now that I've rediscovered its goodness.
author: Mimi L.

description:
Five stars- no brainer!!! When I think of cafe, this is the first place that comes to mind.  Fresh fresh fresh bread and pastries!!! The baker smiles at you when you walk in; she must be excited for you to try some of her delicious treats! 

Coffee was amazing!  This is the perfect spot to read a book on the patio, do some work on your computer or catch up with a friend!! 

The OUTDOOR PATIO I repeat OUTDOOR PATIO is perfect. My only fear is that I won't be able to find a seat because it is so lovely!
author: Shay K.

description: Cute cafe with outdoor seating in the back. The pastries are good but too heavy handed on the butter. Maybe not mixed well? Don't believe what the other reviews say- definitely not the same quality as Tartine. But it's a nice location in a less busy part of town, and you don't have to wait in line.
author: Marianna M.

description:
One of the best bakeries in the Castro area. It's really a hidden gem with delicious baked goods and a wonderful staff. Dare I say it's much better than the renowned Tartin around the corner, without the dreaded hour long wait. The prices are also fair and relatively cheap.

Their outside area is lovely, especially on a warm day, without the pesky clouds. It's generally easy to find a spot, even on weekends albeit need to clean the area before sitting down.

They serve food items, but have you pick up drinks from the counter. I think it would be better to choose only one of the options. I got my sandwich and half an hour later and after several times of visiting the counter, I still couldn't find my cappuccino -- later I found out someone else took it. By the time I got my cup, I already finished my sandwich. Probably this was a one-off issue, but still would have been nice to get my items all together.

Looking forward to more delicious treats! Keep up the hard work and keep delighting us!
author: Zorayr K.

description:
For some reason this bakery had a very out of town feel when in fact this is less than a mile from my place. I adored the exposed brick walls, the light pouring in from the street side windows and the outdoor space. I just wish there were additional tables outside. 

Their cream puffs are dangerously addictive. I can probably eat a dozen in one sitting. All the cakes in their glass display looked mouthwateringly delightful. Every single one of those cakes were something I'd like to have taken home. The croissant was probably one of the best I've had in my life and yes, I've had croissants in Paris.  

In my opinion the best bakery in the area - maybe in all of San Francisco.
author: Esther A.

description:
My favorite bakery so far in the Bay Area.

All of their food is on point from their pastries to the sandwiches. Even their proportions are not something to worry about because you will definitely get full. Compared to other bakeries that can give you minuscule baked goods and coffee, Thoroughbread gives you a great proportion to enjoy and chill in the backyard patio.
author: Marisa L.

description:
A gem in Castro/Mission area. Delightful baked things (not a long line!) and great sandwiches as well. 

The best part is outdoor patio, canopied by some big trees. Good coffee date spot!
author: Shilpa R.

description:
I really wanted to like here. Like really. It was raining this morning and I really needed a good pastry to start the day off.  I walked in around 8:00am, and while the spread of baked items was delicious appealed to all my senses, I decided to go with their mainstay item in the almond croissant.  I got my croissant to stay, so when I sat down, took a big breath (and a few photos) and took a bite only to find that my croissant tasted overly chewy as if it was somewhat stale, I was a little sad.  It had all the potential in the world with a light dusting of powdered sugar and almonds, and wasn't overly sweet to the point where I had a hard time eating it.  It was cold, and not buttery and flaky like the croissants I had at other places most recently.  While I'd like to say that maybe some of this was because I didn't get them when they came fresh out of the oven, I also would think that by sitting down and eating it right away and by coming at 8AM would have prevented that.  In any case, I know that Thorough gets a lot of rave reviews from a lot of enthusiasts with tons of experience, so I'm hoping I caught them on an off day.

In a small additional minor note, a few people mentioned the poor customer service here, and while no one was overly rude to me in any way, I did notice the lack of enthusiasm and smiles when I was ordering and when I had asked for a small bag to take away my pastry in.
author: Lisa I.

description: Very impressed with the atmosphere her, and incredibly impressed with the price for the city! Two drinks and a loaf of sourdough for under $7! Usually it's exponentially more throughout the city. If you're looking for breads and savories this is the place to stop.
author: Maryam T.

description:
Thorough Bread & Pastry has succeeded in inspiring me to thoroughly taste all of their offerings.

I was drawn in by their gorgeous display of tantalizing baked goods, and I'll be returning because of the prices (comparable to Arizmendi, much more affordable than Tartine), the fast service, and the baked goods themselves.

Unsure of what to choose, I decided on the small goodies: 4 CHOUQUETTES for $1.50 and 4 GOUGERES for $1.50 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/thorough-bread-and-pastry-san-francisco?select=rdy_Kq0fjBmKSyYJmxGQQA#rdy_Kq0fjBmKSyYJmxGQQA). You can also buy 12 for $3.50.

The chouquettes are small hollow balls of baked choux pastry that I think are flavored with almond and sugar. The gougeres are the savory version of the chouquettes and are less hollow due to a thin cheese&chive layer. They tasted like an omelette! Which meant I liked them more :)

Oh, NO WIFI.

I was also eyeing their $2.50 bostock, $2.50 sticky bun, and they apparently have 5 French macarons for $3.50!?

It is imperative that I return.
author: Adele F.

description:
Came in here and purchased 4 pieces of the cheddar and chive gougeres for $2! It reminded me of profiteroles cause they were hollow inside and the same size if not smaller! A snicker doodle (delicious and my favorite of the 3 items) and double chocolate chip cookie $1.50 ea.  

I wouldn't drive all the way back here but if I'm in the area I would definitely come for another snicker doodle.
author: Liz N.

description: Mixed feelings about this place. Because it's a nice space, and the baked goods are delish... and the coffee is strong... and the aesthetic is pleasing. But the lines are AWFUL on the weekends and they sure don't move all that fast. Someone I dated for a minute and a half loved the almond croissant here, but I don't know that it was good enough to compensate for the slow-as-molasses lines. I think I still prefer Illy, up the street.
author: Sean B.

description:
I love coming here every Sunday morning before church. It's affordable, reliable, and delicious. The pastries are all delicious- just try a new one every time you come in. You can also buy sandwiches and quiches if you want something more substantial.
Even if there is a line, it goes by pretty quickly, and you can usually find a seat inside or in the patio in the back. I recommend getting anything that has "almond" in the name and you can't go wrong with anything that has fruit in it. At least I like to tell myself that I'm a little bit healthier that way. 5 stars.
author: Grace L.

description:
