The two stars are for the bread products -- excellent crust, texture, and taste. 

No stars for their pastries -- morning bun, croissants, scones, and cinnamon/pecan roll. They looked delicious but were underwhelming, lacked the finesse I expect from French pastries, or just weren't tasty. Definitely just head over to Tartine or Arsicault.
author: K. S.

description:
Omg soo amazing! I have been here more times than I would like to admit lol!
Great & convenient location to pop in & out or stay and enjoy the lovely indoor or outdoor back patio! 
The baguette is one of the best in the city as is the chocolate bread!
Fantastic pastries- I've only had one that wasn't great.
Friendly staff.
Super cool clean environment.
author: Ashley G.

description:
Too full from brunch at Kitchen Story, but in need of a place to chill, my friend and I decided to check out Thorough, if not just to scratch off another one of my bookmarks. Whoddathunk I'd end up buying so many pastries?! (Okay I had just the slightest inkling I would, but anyway...)

I ended up picking up some cream puffs, a rustic fruit tart, almond croissant, bacon scone, and blueberry scone. Not even halfway through the batch yet, but I have a feeling this will still thoroughly cover my thoughts either way:

* Cream Puffs - Their take on this classic, with some chocolate drizzle and sugar crystals on the outside, is divine, and probably among the tastiest ones I've had to date. I was super tempted to pick up another dozen of these before I left, but, the resistance was strong in this one.

* Almond Croissant - Filled with frangipane of course, and also quite tasty. Not quite as stellar as some of the ones I've had in Seattle, but up there for the Bay Area, and gives the ones are Tartine a run for their money: choose Thorough's if you like yours slightly less sweet. And either eat it fresh here, or take it home and toast for some extra goodness.

* Blueberry Scone - I still don't know if authentic scones are supposed to be soft and fluffy, or harder biscuit like things, but theirs is more the former than the latter (a la Arizmendi). Not bad on its own, but would probably be far more delicious when warm, and served with some salted butter.

A solid 3.5, and a place I'll come back to, if not just for those cream puffs...

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A decent sized bakery/cafe, mostly filled with two tops to the side, and the pastry displays to the right. Fairly accessible when the place isn't packed, but I suspect getting back to the front door when there's a line might be a little difficult, as there's really only enough width for 1.5 people. As for the tables themselves, the two tops are small enough, with large enough feet, that you might not be able to scoot in as much as you'd like. It's not the worst, but it could be better.

Bathroom - Totally accessible!
author: Johnny W.

description: Super cute spot! Saturday morning tea with a scrumptious, flaky, and super filling Ham and Cheese Croissant and book to read in the cute back patio area? Yes please!!
author: Joanna C.

description: Lovely spot, very cute back garden patio. Staff could be friendlier and it really needs to set up wifi, but if you're just chatting and need your wheat fix, this is absolutely the place to go.
author: Be F.

description: Best almond croissant I have tasted outside of France! Cute cafe with ample seating and lots of goodies off Market St. They have dessert-type sweets, sandwiches, and more breakfast-type pastries also got with a typical cafe drink menu. I am a huge fan of anything that uses their croissant pastry and the savory scones are good too.
author: Cara R.

description: Come here for the almond croissant holy heck.
author: Ken H.

description: This place is LEGIT! They're my go-to for an indulgent breakfast, housewarmings and birthday cakes. Every person who has taken a bite of their array of delicious pastries, breads and cakes have fallen in love. I recommend their croissants (almond croissants, in particular), sweet buns and their chocolate cake. Their cheesecake is also delicious! Best part? Their prices are super reasonable -- forget those $7 cruffins.
author: Lily L.

description: Amazing croissants, bread, scones, and turnovers. Great Sightglass coffee. I like Thorough's baked goods better than the ever-popular Tartine. There's the added benefit of not waiting in line and they have a lovely back patio.
author: Bre D.

description:
Cute place in the heart of the Castro. Came here before the day started around 7:30 am and there wasn't a line. 5 minutes later as I was waiting for my latte, there was a line out the door! The orders are taken pretty quickly though so no worries!

The shining point of this cafe is the cornucopia of baked goods being offered. The bacon scone is SO DELICIOUS! With cheese, chives and of course bacon, the savory scone was a perfect compliment to the coffee, which definitely held its own.

Ample table space to set up and study.
author: Rebecca L.

description: Delicious coffee and cheesecake.  A nice little patio (except for the ear splitting Blue Angels) with some major table hogs.
author: Pat P.

description:
Been here twice and disappointed each time.
While the pastries look delicious, I found the muffins and scones to be too dry,
author: Philip C.

description: Excellent bite size cream puffs with drizzle of chocolate! Nice outside pastry dough very light and inside had good amount of cream. The little cream puffs were good for a  special treat because they were on the expensive side. I actually bought 6 puffs that cost $7.00. Next time I really want to try the$3.50 almond croissant that everyone on yelp keep raving about.
author: Priscilla L.

description:
This is my favorite bakery in the city. Yes, better than tartine and b patisserie. They make super light and fluffy croissants. Other pastries are also amazing - try the chocolate croissant bread pudding if they have it. Prices are also really reasonable at $2.50 for a croissant and $3.50 for chocolate, almond, ham & cheese, or other specialty croissants.

Ambiance is great like a little French bakery with really friendly staff and a great back patio with outdoor seating. You can also get cakes and breads.
author: Phil D.

description:
The smell of baked goods when you walk in, is enough to stop you in your tracks.  

My fave is the veggie sandwich-- filling and so very yummy and sloppy.  

The selections of teas are perfect.

The pastries are to die for-- oh yeah the bread-- yum-o-rama!
author: Princess P.

description: I had this on my must try places and I do not regret it.   The pastries were fresh and so moist and tasty.   I bought some Gougeres, savory Turnover, and chocolate croissants.  All we're delicious.  The staff was friendly and the ambiance is nice, cozy and rustic.
author: Kathy C.

description:
It felt like a dream - to get such amazing baked goods in SF without standing in line. Hands down, their pasties are way better than Tartine bakery. Crisp, flaky and oh so tasty! Plus they have a cute backyard that allows you to enjoy all the yumminess in a serene surrounding. 

Warning: This place is dangerous for your waistline. They have a wide selection of both sweet and savory pastries. I almost wish I hadn't discovered it - as now I have to fight the urge to go there every morning.
author: Paawan K.

description:
Sadly it's difficult to justify more than two stars for a place that makes a baguette so hard that we had to throw the bottom half out, eating only the top half. Having had baguettes all over Europe and in many of the best cities, San Francisco just doesn't seem to have the knack for making authentic French bread (and that goes for all the usual suspects: Tartine, Boulangerie etc). We had hoped, based on Yelp reviews, that this place would be different. It isn't. 

The almond croissants were good/tasty albeit also slightly overdone.

Maybe the bakers need a little more training?
author: Alex B.

description: Great breakfasty breads and coffees, but the real reason to come here is for the delightfully-sunny patio in the back. Service was OK, a little harried. I loved my croissant.
author: Joni W.

description:
There are a lot of trendy bakeries in SF over the past decade, but this is by far my favorite.  The lines are reasonable, they alternate what they make by season, and the food is uncompromisingly delicious.  We love them so much, we served their pastries as dessert at our wedding recently.  The interaction we had with Courtney solidified this being our favorite bakery in SF and ensued our love for them will remain unwavering.  They made us 100s of Cream Puffs, mini macaroons, and fruit pates and unlike wedding cake we had 0 left overs.  I just assume people loved them so much they stuffed them in their pockets and purses.

Thanks Courtney & Thorough Bread, we love you, and see you soon.
author: Tim D.

description:
Ah, Thorough Bread and Pastry. You are my chosen bakery. I may venture into other bakeries every once in a while, but fear not--I will always be back.

The only time I ever really go to bakeries is on Saturdays during my morning runs. I pick a bakery and set a path to get a good run in while also being able to stop by a bakery and grab some breakfast. My go-tos are Thorough Bread and Pastry and Craftsmen and Wolves. I usually decide to go to Thorough Bread, though, because they have a wider and more consistent selection, lower prices, and a more casual atmosphere (I.e., less awkward for a sweaty woman in running clothes to walk in asking for two pastries in paper bags to put in her Camelbak backpack).

Thank you for sharing your delicious pastries with me! I can't say I've been disappointed with any of your pastries thus far, and I'm looking forward to trying many others!

Favorites: ham & gruyere croissant, bacon & potato turnover, chocolate croissant
author: Julia N.

description:
Wow, how could I forgot to write a review for this place after a year. I love this place and everything about it.

We ordered:

- Ham&Cheese Croissant = flaky and crispy croissant with delicious cheese

-  Quiche = light texture with yummy bacon and spinach

- Tuna melt sandwich = my favorite with french baguette and fresh greens

- Bruchetta sandwich = melted cheese on top of the bruchetta and on toasted french baguette was divine.

- Cup of macchiato = strong taste, definitely awakening.

- Cup of cappuccino = perfect cup of coffee!

We had our brunch in the courtyard and it was nice and homey. Would love to come back and try their other goodies. What a great place to enjoy a wonderful meal. I am definitely a fan!
author: Owie N.

description: Just get the almond croissant okay.
author: Tammy P.

description: OK quality food, moderately price but awful service. I have been coming to this pastry place for about two years now since it is near my house and not once that  I had an OK experience. They really need to train their cashiers how to be efficient and pleasant to customers.
author: Angelica V.

description:
Five Stars well earned for their Almond croissant and Ham and Cheese croissant! Almond croissant is flaky, buttery and crispy even when they warm it up. Rivals what I am used to in Paris! 

Ham and cheese is delish too with a nice cheesy sauce they use. Crispy just right. 

Their veggie sandwich is so good on their amazing bread. And the coffee is super smooth and not bitter. And I am very picky about coffee. I came here two days in a row. I can't wait to go back!!!

It's super fun to people watch too! :)
author: McKenzie L.

description:
A good place to get breakfast or coffee. Definitely above the others in the neighborhood.  

The place is heated (not a standard in San Francisco cafes) and bright.  Next door Church St. Cafe may be better for working on a computer but this one has fresh baked goods.  Coffee is good quality. Almond croissant was fresh, above factory manufactured but for high-end a bit soggy in the center.  This may be due to the wet weather.  

Good to meet for 2 people to talk. Not good for larger groups.
author: Flo B.

description:
I love you Thorough Bread & Pastry 

Highlights:
Almond croissants
Apple Galette
Baguettes
Turkey, bacon and cream cheese sandwich
Mini cakes - specifically the carrot cake - oh lawd, it's good
The incredibly stylish and bada$$ staff
Right between Dolores Park and Duboce Park

Only flaw:
No wifi.  

#tbp4lyfe
author: Jennifer Z.

description:
I ordered a "symbolic" wedding cake from Thorough Bread for my recent wedding (i.e. a cake that was used for the cake cutting that fed the closest family & friends while the rest of the guests enjoyed a dessert buffet).  

I would like to thank Thorough Bread for their professionalism and their incredibly tasty and affordable chocolate cake. I will definitely be recommending Thorough Bread to other brides.
author: Julie V.

description: This place seriously has amazing bread! I know San Francisco is known for their sourdough but this place has such an amazing variety of options that you should really Branch out Beyond the classic sourdough. Don't get me wrong the sourdough is amazing but this place raises the bar when it comes to bread
author: Michael P.

description: My favorite croissant and cappuccino in town,nice and friendly help....
author: Francis G.

description: Super cute atmosphere. Clean and friendly. Coffee was awesome. Staff was great and recommended awesome pastries.
author: Ann D.

description: Upon walking in you are greeted with a smile and the aroma of freshly baked bread. I was meeting a friend in the area and in desperate need for something to eat. I ordered the almond croissant and chai latte and it was so so good. Super fresh ( still warm from the oven) and it was amazing on this somewhat chilly SF day. Super accessible by muni-- will definitely be back!
author: Sarah C.

description:
This cafe is growing on me.  I like walking here for a cup of Cafe au lait $3.00 and a delicious baked Rustic fruit tart or quiche in the morning before hitting the 24 hour fitness gym around the corner.
This place brings in the crowd about 8:00 am but many of the patrons do not dine in so lots of tables to be had.  The pastry selection on display will surely drive the dieters mad unless they have very good self control.  I surely don't so I eat what I want, in moderation, of course.
author: Michael L.

description:
Highly recommend. Fast service, not cheap but fairly priced, and a rotating set of really creative baked goods. 

I got a butternut squash and Brie turnover which was  rich but not particularly flaky, and would have been much better heated up.  

Seating is tight but there is some outdoor seating to enjoy on nice days!

I think Arizmendi sets the gold standard for bread but this place has high quality across the board..
author: Ben S.

description:
Cute cafe with nicely priced baked goods.  Few tables for indoor seating.  Employees were all nice, friendly and helpful.

Grabbed a few things to go:  Epi, Croissant, Almond Cranberry Scone, Morning Bun, Cream Puffs and a Fougasse.

Everything we purchased was good, especially the fougasse which had rosemary and olives in it.  Saw some people having sandwiches and soup, may come back to try other items they offer.
author: J D.

description:
Got a baguette and a country loaf. Very tasty whole wheat in both. 

Also got some different, tasty French macaroons and an American macaroons.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
This is hands down the best bakery in all of San Francisco. I came here initially because one of my coworkers said this bakery was the closest thing to France in SF. 

I can't decide what I like more -- the almond croissant or the chocolate croissant. Make sure you ask them to heat it up for you! The pastries are super flaky and crisp. You'll get weak in the belly that's for sure!
author: Tran N.

description:
The almond croissant is literally the most delicious pastry I have had in my life. 
My friend and I bought a croissant and a slice of crumb cake. While the crumb cake wasn't really memorable, I was straight up devouring this croissant like a crazy person and I actually bought some extra to bring to some friends back home, but I actually ended up eating those myself. They're crunchy, flaky, warm, and just the right touch of sweetness, and they are seriously so good. 
The restaurant itself is kind of small, but the servers are really nice and they have a great outside patio that's homey and makes me feel special. You'll understand once you get here. If I'm in the area, I'm definitely making a stop here.
author: Salley P.

description: Light, airy, fresh pastries and cookies. Loved the flakey almond croissant and shortbread-like snickerdoodle cookie. Quick snack on the go for $5.25. Friendly staff and clean location.
author: Julie L.

description: Very spacious place with tasty pastries and coffee. Lots of tables, really nice backyard.
author: Jen G.

description:
Cute and warm bakery. 

I stopped by Thorough after I hit up Ike's for a sandwich. I ordered a fruit tart to go, and the lady who was helping me was really nice. There are a few tables inside, and it was nice and warm and cozy; seems like a great place to come with a good friend or your significant other for some pastries.

The fruit tart was okay but it was a bit pricey at $4. The pears were yummy, but there weren't very many berries and there was a bit too much pastry, I would have preferred more fruit. All in all I think if you are in the area this is a good stop but I wouldn't go out of my way to come back.
author: Sam F.

description: The pastries are always so delicious and wonderful. Wide selection. A must place to check out
author: Eugene K.

description:
No question. I am a pastry fiend. I will go to the ends of the earth to find and eat good pastry. I appreciate the talent involved in creating fine pastry. And I adore the finesse of how artisans decide how to assemble various ingredients that result in delicious pastry goodness.

That said. I really like Thorough Bread's almond croissant. It's loaded with almond. Like literally, if I put it on a scale the scale would probably tip over. It's not overly sweet - which is annoying because in the morning on a fresh palate you don't want to go overboard and get sugared out so that you have a sugar drop quickly after you stop eating.

Each bakery I like has certain high points which I will always come back for. For me, the almond croissant at TB is it.
author: Joanna T.

description:
The woman behind the counter was friendly and patient with my ordering since I just stood there in front of the cashier STARING at the pastries on display for the looongest time. 

Some of the staff at this bakery are students from the San Francisco Baking Institute. They have classic pastries and bread options as well as delicate looking miniature cake slices. I had the sun dried tomato and goat cheese scone which had a nice texture and good balance of flavors.Their gougeres are great too, but not cheesy enough for me. (the best ones I've had in SF is at La Folie Lounge) But the obvious standout here is their almond croissant: a light croissant that's big enough to satisfy your craving; topped with powdered sugar and sliced almonds. The generous layer of marzipan inside is a nice surprise! I wish it was more flakier, more butter next time please! I also tried their coffee which is served in a huge cup, full bodied and gave me the added caffeine jolt that I needed.

I'd been here twice already and can't wait to come back to hang out in their back patio. However, don't EVER ask me to do the Paleo diet with you. I'll fail in an hour.
author: Janice C.

description: This place has an amazing selection of pastries and desserts. When I got there at around 11.20am, there was a line and most seats (indoor, outdoor patio and outside seating) were almost full. Line moved quickly and I got a ham and cheese croissant. Croissant was great - fluffy, warm (you can get it to warm it for you) and flaky. They are also very generous with the cheese. You can grab water yourself by the counter. Can't wait to try more of their stuff next time!
author: Erica Y.

description:
I've been coming here since 2012. Had I written a review prior to my recent visit it would have been a 4 star rating.  My enthusiasm for this bakery cafe has taken a tumble.. Something is amiss. The pastries are not as good as they used to be.  My latte was barely hot.

My favorite has been the almond croissant and bostock (discontiuned).  The almond croissant was so good I used to buy a few to put in my freezer. I'm glad I only bought one this time. I was sorely disappointed. It was not very flaky and the filling was a bit scant. The sticky bun was not worth the calories. Just not the quality that used to draw me here.

Not sure I'll be back.  Although, I should give them another try since I have really liked their products over the years, huh?
author: Debbie T.

description:
Visited this Saturday morning. Staff are attentive when you walk in. The woman who ended up taking my order, after I needed a few minutes to browse being that it was my first time, looked like she couldn't have cared less. I didn't feel welcome and I won't be back. Well, maybe I'd come back if I were in the neighborhood and needed a baguette. 

Top 3 reasons I was bummed: 1) I want the first person taking my $15 in the morning to look more awake than me and practice some verbal outreach. Just a few words would suffice -- like Thank you. Or Would you like your receipt, You can pick up your café au lait here to my right, or Hope you enjoy are a few that come to mind. 2) I tried the simple and humble blueberry scone. I lose faith in a shop that doesn't make a good one I can brag about later to friends. 3) If there's no line and your customer looks overwhelmed at such a nice selection of sweets and pastries (and is chubby and looks hungry) AND says it's her first time here so needs a few minutes to take it all in, this is when an offer to introduce her to what makes your bakery exceptional is appreciated. Being helpful is what I believe it's called. Hey, I made it all the way to your place to check out your bread, butter, sugar, and coffee. I had to find parking, pay for it (initial real $ investment in an unseen product is already a show of my faith in your business), step over trash on the sidewalk, and risk getting wet by people spraying it down next door. Be nice. Oh and serve better coffee.
author: Mo O.

description: My favorite coffee shop and bakery in the city!  Very unassuming store front, clean, warm and friendly inside with a nice outdoor patio in the back.  And the food is exceptional.  Best cholocate cake, period.  A thoroughly delicious experience!
author: binh l.

description: They have an excellent almond croissant - literally one of the best I've had. I didn't try their coffee, but my friend had an Americana and said it was "clean", whatever that means (I don't drink coffee). Anyway, there is some cool outdoor seating with a great ambience if it's a nice day.
author: Chris L.

description:
Pretty pretty pretty. As soon as I entered I was attracted by the glass case and all the goodies behind it. It was hard to limit myself but I went with the following:

- Almond croissant: flaky, crusted with almond slices, and not too sweet. Yeah!
- Rhubarb berry galette: Petite portion rustic pie that was ok.
- Savory bread pudding: Attracted by the name, it tasted like a thick cheesy tomatoey foccacia but softer. Thumbs up.
- Mushroom leek turnover: Lot of flavor and nice to see some savory pastry options.

Didn't get prices on all of them but with a large cup of chai (~$4) and my total ~$18, pastries were in the $3 / $3.50 range.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Everything I tried was really solid, and prices are very reasonable compared to other places in SF. 

- Double chocolate cookie: $1.50 each, chocolatey, not too sweet, could have been a bit softer/chewier on the texture
- Gougeres: only $2 for 4 mini ones.  I like bite sized things, so I definitely prefer this to the giant gougeres some other places do, and it's really good warmed up
- Almond croissant: good crust outside, but not enough frangipane. Texture was good - flaky and not doughy. I think it was $3.50, and it was pretty big
- Savory bacon scone: this had good bacon and cheese flavor. I love savory scones. The outside had a nice crust, but the inside sort of melts in your mouth from the butter. I thought the texture was right on

I still can't get over how much less expensive than they are at some other places in SF. They have a huge variety of things but did all of them well, so I need to come back and try some more of the other things.

No wifi.
author: Marilyn T.

description: The carrot cake was amazing and I only wish the location was closer to me.
author: Neil C.

description: What a lovely little neighborhood coffee shop and bakery. We were guided here by a long time local and close friend. What a wonderful find. If you can get a table it s great. If you can't it is still great. The selection of pastries is very very nice and we, three of us, all tired something different and all were excellent.  If I were local, this would be a regular stop. Enjoy
author: Charley C.

description:
Any sane person who has taste buds at all would agree that the almond croissant from Thorough Bread is absolute perfection. Unlike other almond croissants, it has an extra layer of almond magic on top. 

Heaven would be eating Thorough Bread almond croissants every day and not getting fat. Since we live here on earth, let me just say that the almond croissant is worth the diabetes.

the vibe inside is so delightful, everything is delicious, a true neighborhood gem. Kinda glad that it's not as popular as Tartine (only because there is no line when I need to get my fix) but it deserves to be.
author: Tuwie N.

description: One of my favorite spots in the city. It's a bit lesser-known, so you might actually snag a spot even on a Sunday morning at brunch time! The sourdough bread is to die for, all of the pastries are similarly delicious, and the spacious, flowery outdoor patio is vibey. This place is chill, lovely, and cozy. Definitely recommended.
author: Cassie P.

description:
Thorough Bread and Pastry has the best smell. There was an outdoor seating area in the back with lots of people enjoying an afternoon snack surrounded by jolly yellow walls. The service was quick and friendly... AND I finally got my hands on some sourdough.

I bought two sourdough loaves and one multigrain, which I smuggled on my plane home. My husband and I have been hacking into them for days and they are still really pleasant. I just love knowing they are in our kitchen. The world seems very small to me when I know that there are bread loaves from 2,000 miles away in my kitchen.

Excellent service. I definitely recommend coming here in addition to Tartine and Craftsman & Wolves.
author: Erica G.

description: Fantastic. Almond croissant, apple galette, and an olive/rosemary thingy. All delicious. The best part...front row seats of the trolley buses that pass by for my train enthusiast who's 4. We could have sat there all day.
author: Regina R.

description:
Wonderful little cafe with pastries, breads, sandwiches and teas/coffees. I think everything is affordable except for their cakes which run on the pricier side.

Also really like the outdoor space with five or six tables, although it's usually in shade sadly so no sun to warm you up.

A little gem in this neighborhood.
author: Mary X.

description: Yummo!  Walked to this little gem on our first morning in the Haight Dist., and it was so lovely.  Kiddos gobbled up Sticky Buns, Chocolate Crossaints (could use a bit more Choc.), scones and hubby and I really enjoyed our morning brew (me a latte/himself coffee/dark).  The best part of all. . . 5 surprise chocolate chip cookies that I stashed for our bike ride later.  Everyone was quiet and had chocolate covered faces.  :)
author: Kari F.

description: Lovely place with lovely people, but after ten bites into my chocolate croissant with no sign of chocolate, I must say I was confused. Went to the counter with my croissant asking if I was given the right pastry, but they told me to poke into the other side. Perplexed and feeling rather silly, I did. Lo and behold, finally, a sliver of chocolatey goodness, way off in one side, worth perhaps a few bites, max. Truly an excellent croissant, but Thorough Bread and Pastry needs to up their chocolate game in this particular treat.
author: Patricia L.

description:
BEST CROISSANTS. Hands down. Don't wait in that long line at tartine for a burnt-on-the outside-questionably-done-on-the-inside croissant. Pop on down to Thorough Bread for some of the most amazing pastries from a great, caring staff.

I love grabbing a box of pastries from here to take to work on special occasions. I've tried the croissants, pain au chocolate, both sweet and savory bread puddings, the scones, the lemon tarts, the chocolate cake is to die for and on top of all that, they serve Sightglass coffee which is my favorite in the city.

They serve lunch too. The chicken salad sandwich was really awesome. Served warm and it's got a hint of sweetness from the golden raisins. Mmmm tasty.

Really adorable little place with a patio out back, it's one of my favorite spots to be on a sunday afternoon.
author: Jessica R.

description: It's one of the best cafes in the city that I enjoy spending my times: my favor order is always the ham and cheese croissant (toasted) and the cafe latte. The outdoor patio is just the bomb and the indoor settings are awesome too! Very home comfy decor and there are always fresh hand -picked flowers on every table! But there is one down side, it doesn't provide wifi so you might have to use your data.
author: Yuki J.

description:
This place is amazing! Sandwiches are delicious, perfectly garnished and the bread, oh the bread ... the best bread in SF. But let me back up. When you walk into the space, it smells like a bakery. Slightly sweet like brown sugar, with a hint of fresh yeast bread, and coffee undertones. It smells like fresh handmade baked goods, but not so strong you can taste it. The pastries displayed are beautiful and fancy, but not intimidating. The staff is very kind and not rude when you don't know what you want right away like some other well known SF bakeries.

The cookies were delicious. 
*Brown butter chocolate chip - A++. Perfectly cooked, the slight nutty-ness of the brown butter coming through, crispy edges, and a good ratio of chocolate chips to cookie. 
*Oatmeal raisin - A. They thankfully do NOT put nuts in the oatmeal raisin so the oat flavor comes through. 
*Dark chocolate - great dark chocolate flavor. Solid B, would be amazing dipped in some coffee or hot chocolate. 
*Snickerdoodle - C. It was delicious and the texture was perfect, but it lacked the full snickerdoodle flavor. Like there needed to be a ton more cinnamon in the sugar cinnamon rolling before baking. 
*Castro Cookie - A+, a definite must. It's not only cute, but the recipe is perfect. Delicate crumb texture and flavor. And it's a great size.

Yes, we got other things, but the cookies didn't even make it through the ride home. No regrets. Don't want this spot to get popular. However, I want everyone to go and support them and treat your taste buds. Next time I will maybe make it to the outside seating area. But contemplating which sweet treats to get while enjoying an amazing sandwich is always too tempting.
author: J Z.

description: Best best bakery! I loved the almond croissant and the other bite goodies. Coffee was great too. Thus bakery is better than la tartine but it is not so popular. We manage to find a place to sit after 5-10 min of waiting. Reasonable prices too!
author: Antonia S.

description:
The smell of carbs hit you when you walk in.. Tough decisions to get croissants, breads, or other pastries.  
I was greeted immediately by someone when I entered and she followed me as I walked to look at all the options. Felt rushed with stares so just got what came to mind-sticky bun.  Brought it home, chilled in the fridge for several hours and it was surpringly delicious even cold.  Man, I want another one...
author: Linda T.

description: Went for breakfast on a Saturday, and was surprised to find there wasn't a long wait, and there was plenty of seating available in the little garden in the back. Shared a bunch of pastries with friends, and the blueberry scones and almond croissants were especially good. Would definitely go back.
author: Lauren C.

description:
I've lost track of how many times I've frequented this place - which I also swore I'd already written a review for Thorough Bread, but I guess I was too busy stuffing my face with all the delicious pastries to even remember. 

I know I raved about Tartine Bakery, which their morning buns are still at the top of my list - especially for any out of towners visiting San Francisco.  However, if you're out for a simple pastry to start off your morning, then Thorough Bread will offer you a wealth of options - none of which will disappoint! 

One tip: You MUST try their Almond Croissants :)

Enjoy!
author: Patricia T.

description: It was Kismet that morning. I didn't really feel like going to yoga, and I was working really hard on being with myself in the moment and only doing what felt right (for me) ... And while I was feeling really connected with myself ... my mom called. "Let's meet in The Castro, coffee, lunch, whatever ..." I didn't have time to discover the Thorough Bread while I was busy feeling ... Thank you Yelpers! This bakery is everything Yelp reviewers promise. The bread and pastries taste like a quick landing in Paris, without the hassle of flying. My food notes read "scrumptious"! Take your baguette with a ripe raclette to the closest horse show ...
author: Anna L.

description: Tea was good but that's the shittiest eclair I've had in the US, period. It's dry and flavorless. If that's what you're craving for, do yourself a favor and go get two big eclairs for $3 (same price) at Safeway across the street (yes it's that bad). Source: I'm french
author: Greg U.

description:
The almond croissant is OK: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/thorough-bread-and-pastry-san-francisco?select=DjDChZV4nYIS0sTtS7gd7g#DjDChZV4nYIS0sTtS7gd7g
The inside is a little too dense and mealy; I prefer a version that is light/flaky/crispy.  It's a bit overhyped.
author: Scott F.

description: I was introduced to thoroughbread by the restaurant Sous Beurre...where the bread was delicious.today I decided to pop in & sample it for myself. 1st impressions count & service was far from friendly & to top it off the almond croissant was terrible...it was so burnt it shouldn't have been for sale.
author: Nicole E.

description: Perfectly delicious chocolate croissant and cream puff. I love the nice eating area at patio. It's a fantastic place!
author: Akiko O.

description: Great croissants, some of the best in SF, especially the almond ones, and the ham & cheese. They're both so good, we ordinarily order both! They make a good latte too. There's rarely a queue, it's a nice place to sit (inside or out), and has reasonable prices. A rare combination in SF! Great job, guys, please keep it affordable!
author: Marcus R.

description:
So when two ladies are standing on the streets of San Francisco with a puzzled look on their faces, a couple of things can happen. Fortunately the best thing happened... a local walked over and asked if he could help.

We were wandering around the Castro district trying to decide what to do next since the shops were starting to peter out. So rather than ask for directions to a particular place, I said, "Is there a good bakery around here?" He suggested a few nearby, but his personal favorite was clear. Thorough Bread.

It was just a block off Market and the minute we walked in the door we knew we had a winner. It started with the whimsical loaf of decorative bread (imprinted with cupid and hearts for Valentine's Day). Then we might have done a collective sigh as we saw the pastry case.

One chocolate dipped macaroon and a Napoleon later and we were two very happy girls. Our blissful visit contined on the back patio which is a completely relaxing spot assuming you can find a table. This place isn't overly fancy and didn't have the long lines of some other cafes we passed, but it was pleasantly busy. I think it qualifies as a neighborhood gem. If you happen to live in a really cool neighborhood.
author: Jen K.

description: Easily one of the best bakeries in SF. Beyond fresh bread, their sandwiches are phenomenal so are their soups.
author: Bill K.

description:
Put simply, you get what you pay for here. The desserts aren't cheap but they are absurdly decadent.

I did end up getting a mozzarella, tomato, and basil sandwich. It was all very fresh and was plenty of food. It wasn't terribly expensive but then again it shouldn't have, being a veggie sandwich.

Nice little patio if you can find a space. Hip crowd.
author: Andrew L.

description:
4/28/13

If you need a pastry or a little sweetie something to nosh, and don't want to stand in that outrageous line at Tartine, Thorough Bread & Pastry is the answer. I've been coming here since they opened a few years ago. The pastries and baked goods here measure up to cafés and bakeries in France.

*Almond croissant: extremely flaky, you can see layers of flakes like a Napoleon, with generous almonds on top and almond paste filling packed to the crescent. Topped with frosting. 

*Chocolate croissant: the same heavenly goodie with chocolate filling.

*Mini cream puff: be careful, you can eat a dozen of these. It's a buttery chouquette infused with cream drizzled with a bit of chocolate and sugar clumps. 

*Eclairs: make my toes curl.

*Peanut butter cookie: crunchy peanut butter-full of goodie!

Lots of goodies here depending on what time you come by. Morning buns are glazed with pecans, usually sold out by late morning. They also serve sandwiches which I have yet to try. Plenty of seating including a serene patio in the back.

This is a neighborhood gem.
author: Matt Y.

description: I didn't think Thorough Bread could improve on their mixed berry muffin, a favorite of mine, but today I ate the best mixed berry muffin of my life. Please stick with this current recipe! Thank you!
author: Sean M.

description:
Simplicity at it's best!  All the favorite bread and pastries served w/ fresh coffee ad a staff that is super friendly. 

The back patio is coZy and fun. Coffee is strong and hot--this is a bonus. 

I always seem to find a table and the widow is great for watching the busy upper market area!

See y'all soon eh?!?
author: Valerie R.

description:
Very nice and respectful staff starting from destiny Lucy Kelsey and Edgar and everyone there I am not familiar with their names are the nicest people ever 
Their coffee is so addictive and delicious, the smell of their fresh baked bread and croissant will take your mind elsewhere
Try their almonds croissant with a fresh cup of coffee and you totally got hooked to this place 
Always clean spot and they offer water in fancy glass jars
I recommend this bakery if you are planning to start your day with a positive energy and see pretty faces that motivates you for the whole day
author: Saleh M.

description: I came here after visiting a park with my boyfriend to rest up a bit before heading out again. Oh my god, no regrets for choosing this place. The bacon scone was so good! Little pieces of savory bacon along with bits and pieces of cheese inside, so good!!!! I am in love!! Would come again for the scone and outside patio
author: Doris H.

description:
You must get the ALMOND CROISSANT. Even if you do not feel like eating an ALMOND CROISSANT, just order the ALMOND CROISSANT.

Oh yea... You will like the ALMOND CROISSANT. Then you will come back for the ALMOND CROISSANT.
author: Kien M.

description:
This is another bring-your-own-Internet coffee place. The atmosphere is quite nice with a beautiful backyard. The pastries are average and the service is below average. 
If a coffeehouse cannot bother to provide Internet in this day and age why would I bother showing up. I won't. This will be my first and last stop here.
author: Dario V.

description:
If you're waiting in line for Tartine, I feel badly for you. If only you knew that there's a place -- in easy walking distance -- with better quality pastries, for less money, and basically no wait!

(On the other hand, I hope you never read this, because I want the secret all for myself.)
author: Tim R.

description: Been visiting for a while now. Good selection of pastry and great service every time I visited.(Mainly purchase for to go and have not tried any sandwich) Decent pastry and cake overall. Have tried many in the selection and have not had any negative experience. Perhaps it has to do with timing, but I have not had to wait in long lines as many of other bakery in the city. Something that may be a consideration for those not able to spend the time and/or avoid popular hours. Would recommend to give it a try!
author: J Y.

description: One of my favorite bakeries in SF. Their croissants - almond and chocolate are wonderful. Bread pudding is also great. Coffees are good. Definitely one of my favorite to go places for some pastries!
author: Anwar H.

description:
I've been here a few times before. I decided to stop by the other day because I started to miss it.

The shop itself is standard. Cute, wooded decor. They have plenty of pastries, breads, and tarts. I chose to get 3 French macarons and one chocolate bread. 

The macarons aren't the best. They refrigerate them which isn't the traditional way. They're very sweet and dense and I didn't mind it that much because they were cool and it was hot. 

The chocolate bread is my favorite thus far. It's simple but has the right amount of sweetness. So awesome. Whenever I go there, I always get chocolate bread. 

The only bummer about Thorough Bread & Pastry is that they're closed on Mondays.
author: Sofia R.

description: BEST almond croissant in the whole world! Cakes are tasty but expensive! Coffee is good!
author: Serena P.

description: cute bakery on church street. i've heard good things about this spot, so was in the neighborhood and decided to grab an almond croissant and a ham n cheese. both were yumm - almond paste was just the right amount of sweet, not overwhelming at all but perfect with a black coffee. ham and cheese was savory and comforting. good selection of breads and individual desserts.
author: Christina L.

description: Incredible breads, outside seating, and Madame baker makes one of the best German chocolate cakes ever! It melts in your mouth and isn't sickly sweet.
author: Krismet C.

description: I visit this bakery / coffee shop every time I go to San Francisco (about once a year). It never disappoints. The chocolate croissant, almond croissant, and other pastries I've tried are delicious, the coffee is high quality, and the quiet patio out back is perfection. I recommend a stop here when you're in the neighborhood.
author: Catherine S.

description:
Almond croissant- #54 on the 2013 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

Thorough Bread & Pastry is a cozy cafe that has indoor and outdoor seating (in the very back). I loved that their items were neatly labeled and arranged, and the variety of baked goods they had. It looked like they were sold out of their almond croissants, but it turns out more were just coming out of the oven, so I'm glad I asked! I ordered:

-Mini Carrot Cake ($5.50, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/thorough-bread-and-pastry-san-francisco?select=wortfXGvYXne1KNXHyNFFQ#wortfXGvYXne1KNXHyNFFQ): Pretty good, but not sure if it was worth $5.50. The frosting wasn't too sweet, which was nice, but the size of the cake was pretty small.
-Almond Croissant ($2.50, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/thorough-bread-and-pastry-san-francisco?select=wortfXGvYXne1KNXHyNFFQ#mki7KNYkvtpYCPX_7P9Z3A): Super delicious- 7x7 got it right on this item! The croissant is buttery and flaky, and there is an almond filling as well as on top of the croissant.
-Cream Puffs (3 for $2.50, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/thorough-bread-and-pastry-san-francisco?select=wortfXGvYXne1KNXHyNFFQ#39ITuwjx5-dx8iyIVpGHhw): Just ok, nothing special.
-Diamond Cookies (Vanilla & Pistachio Flavors, 3/$1, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/thorough-bread-and-pastry-san-francisco?select=wortfXGvYXne1KNXHyNFFQ#EeazcImmvgnqfqQ9UmNSVQ): Cute little cookies that were also yummy. If you like buttery shortbread type cookies, you have to give these a try. I like the vanilla flavor a bit more than pistachio, but both were good (and cheap!).

Overall, I had a positive experience at Thorough Bread & Pastry, and highly recommend checking it out if you're a pastry connoisseur! The staff here was really nice and welcoming, and I'll definitely be back. You can also order sandwiches if you're looking for a heartier meal. Parking in this area can be tough, but there is street parking available although they are all metered spots.
author: Amy D.

description:
In the world of bakeries, this place is THOROUGHBRED-- see what I did there?? They were clever, so I was clever and changed it back. Don't worry, I'm here all week. 

Thinking too hard about the LOW, LOW prices made me forget that I was in gorgeous Castro, in a warm cafe, with a beautiful outdoor patio, while eating THE BEST ALMOND CROISSANT that I've ever had in my life. But honestly, that is the way that every bakery cafe should be!

Service is great. Coffee refills are a $0.25. Plenty of seating.
author: Diane N.

description: The tea here warmed up my soul.
author: Juliana P.

description: Way better than Tartine and you don't even have to stand in a queue as long. Had croissants at both the places, and this place has way better croissants than tartine. Tartine is overrated.
author: Megha T.

description:
Thorough Bread must be one of SF's best kept secret, but I'm not doing my part to keep it that way. My friends who have lived in the city longer than I have discover the shop from me. I admit the competitor a few blocks near has some good stuff, but I champion Thorough Bread all the way and I will tell you why.

Used as a training shop for the San Francisco Baking Institute, you'll see many intern graduates perfecting their craft in artisan-baking. You'll delightfully taste their training in everything you choose to indulge in. Behind the counter and cases filled with pretty pastries and cakes you can peer into the busy open kitchen while the aroma of fresh baked goods arouse your your appetite. Be awed by the occasional full scale sculpture they bake here (christmas tree and a Jean Paul Gaultier corset are two I can remember). 

The shop offers a variety of fresh breads, pastries, cakes, cookies as well as sandwiches in an amazingly affordable prices.

Their most loved creation is the buttery and flaky almond croissant with its signature lightly sweetened almond filling and topping of crunchy almond frosting for $2.50 a piece. Available also are the chocolate, ham & cheese and regular croissants. Another favorite is the mini cream puff made by injecting fluffy cream into buttery chouquette then drizzled with a bit of chocolate and crunchy clumps of sugar crystals for only $2.50 per 3 pufflets! These delicious nibblers often accompany me to many dinner parties and picnic invitations. Other delightful items in the pastry category include a number of fruit danishes & tarts, chocolate & coffee eclairs and the savory mushroom vol au vent, bacon & potato turnover, and sweet potato turnover. I've had them all and they're equally delicious.

There's no better place in the city to get fresh and good artisan breads for such good prices (less than $5) than Thorough Bread. If you love bread puddings, you'll be happy to know they make them in large squares sweet or savory that easily fill up your tummy. You might have to share, only if you can of course.

I've yet to dive into the beautiful cakes and good looking sandwiches, despite the fact I've been a regular for over a year. Trying everything means I have to order something different each time I go, which is hard to do when the memory of the last thing I tried still lingers pleasantly in my mind. I have no doubt when the time comes, I'll be just as satisfied with the cakes and sandwiches at Thorough Bread. They have a high standard here. If you love cakes, you'll love the variety here and the individual portion they come in. They also make larger cakes that you can pre-order or pick up on a moment's notice.

I can go on and on about how I love Thorough Bread, but there's only three more things you need to know. First, service is always with a smile and efficient even when busy. Second, walk through the back door to a lovely secret patio to enjoy your pastry with a hot beverage. Third, take comfort in the fact the Frenchies frequent the shop.

Enjoy and you're welcome!
author: Rina W.

description:
I absolutely love this coffee shop/bakery. I live a block away so I come here often. In fact I'm writing this review from Thorough Bread while sipping some peach ginger black tea and eating a ham & cheese filled croissant. 

Pros:
- friendly staff
- fresh baked quality pastries & bread
- tasty lunch menu w/ healthy options
- outdoor back patio
- only a few steps from the muni Church station
- NO internet (I list this as a plus because it deters people from planting themselves in here to do work or study for hours. At the same time many regulars, myself included, can be found reading a book, writing, or even creating art)
- fresh flowers at each table
- espresso machine & a staff that knows how to use it


Cons:
- small place, it gets pretty crowded but I usually can always find a table


Favorite dishes - 
- quiche (it sells out quick so get your fix early!)
- chocolate croissant 
- basil, mozzarella, tomato sandwich, comes with a healthy side salad

Other comments:
- tea served for here comes with a tea pot
- long line moves fast
- bus your table! The bus bins are under the counter near the espresso machine
- if you're looking for a coffee shop with interwebs, just go next door 
- at Christmas time, they make a giant tree with ornaments made entirely of bread. Even the tree trunk is bread baguettes!
- they close down every year for one week starting New Year's Day 
- Also they're closed on Mondays
author: Jennifer A.

description: Wonderful bread and pastries with a beautiful outdoor patio.  The coffee is average, but the food makes up for it.
author: Sudoni M.

description: Lovely bakery with nice assortment of savory and sweet breads and such.  If like me you went specifically looking for Rye bread, call first as they don't seem to had it regularly.
author: Steinbeck H.

description:
The Amazing:
-caramel napoleons 
-baguettes
-blackberry lemon cake
-displays ( I know, odd, but makes me happy to see their incredible bread art. These are some creative, talented, FUN people! They recreated the corset Gaultier made for Madonna's Blonde Ambition tour out of BREAD!!!! Amazing!)
-back deck on a warm day

The Good:
-pricing really fair
-customer service if you call in advance and speak with a baker
-lunch stuff

The Not As Good:
-some of the cashiers kind of grumpy, but ya know, no huge deal.  
-wish they were open later.  Way long time ago when the original Just Desserts (not the awful corporate just desserts that took over later) was in this spot it was lovely to sit out back and have cake at night.
author: El B.

description: I'm such a big fan of this bakery. I especially like the girl who works there with the short hair (color changes every so often) and cheek piercings. She's always super nice and happy. Got the almond croissant again and it was absolutely perfect.
author: Erin C.

description:
I've been coming here the past few years for birthday cakes and other special occasions. Their pastries are good.

But I went there today and the counter staff wasn't very friendly at all. And so.... I didn't tip like I normally do! Funny how that works, right? lollllllllllll
author: Chris S.

description: Great coffee and very pleasant atmosphere. Also the pastries are delicious! Pity it closes so early.
author: Tomce R.

description: This was is a cute little spot in SF! They have a different selection of pastries to try from that are reasonably priced. We got the Rosemary bread (I forgot the name), and the sweet bread pudding as well as the savory one. All three were very delicious, although the Rosemary bread was kind of hard, maybe because it wasn't fresh? I liked the sweet bread pudding because it wasn't overwhelmingly sweet and the savory bread pudding was good too, tasted like a quiche. I give this place 4 stars since the woman helping me said, "you can go now" while I was still waiting for my coffee to be made.
author: Alissa G.

description:
Great stuff.... super yummy offerings... super stop-off for a snack and a coffee to tie me over with all that walking in the Mission...

The coffee I ordered came from a carafe hot air thingy, and when served me, it was tepid and obviously been in there for a while. I didn't have the heart (later I chastised myself, thinking, "You paid for it.. you could have had them brew a fresh pot!)

Gougeres were nice, and the toasted bostock brioche was also done well.

Nice little find as I made my way to Lower Haight. 
I think the folks here have a jewel of a cafe and bakery here!
author: Jana C.

description:
This is my favorite place to come to when I stay with my sis! Everything is so good and fresh!!! 

The Almond Croissant couldn't get any better. I always try to bring some back to LA with me but sadly they never make it past SFO due to being a porker and binging on them!
author: Veronica R.

description: Best almond croissants! Well, everything there is absolutely delicious. Highly recommended!
author: D S.

description: We ordered a croissant, chocolate croissant, and coffee. The coffee was smooth with a great taste. The croissants were buttery, crumbly, and simply DELICIOUS!
author: Ruth R.

description: My friend and I took the F line on Market street and walked a block or so to the bakery. I love the Vol-au-Vent with mushroom. The almond croissant is flaky with almond filling all the way to the tip of the crescent. Everything taste great.
author: Ann K.

description:
Ordered a plain croissant and a slice of veggie quiche. 
As noted by others, the service and atmosphere are top notch. Nice seating inside, and a beautiful patio out back. Noisy level was comfortable and background music was quiet. 

The croissant had a crisp, flaky exterior, good mouthfeel and nice buttery taste. However, the interior was closer to a spongy, moist bread and did not retain good layering.

The quiche was just OK. I asked for it heated, it was served lukewarm. I liked the filling: eggier than usual fare. The crust didn't make the cut: mushy on the bottom and too dense. Overall, Tartine's quiche is better. 

Bottom line: Worth a visit, especially if looking for a quiet nook.
author: Isaac L.

description:
If your idea of some "me" time is reading a good book in a sunlit cafe over a moist, almond croissant and chai tea latte, then come to Thorough Bread & Pastry. They should rename their place to "Thorough Bread, Pastry, & Relaxation" because it is just that!

Things I've tried & loved are the almond croissant, chai tea latte, and caprese sandwich. The bread for the sandwich is baked fresh daily there, but is served untoasted. If you're looking for a hot sandwich, ask for them to toast the bread for you.

They also have a nice back patio if you want to go on a cute lunch date. Bathroom is very clean as well. Do yourself a favor and bus it over to Thorough Bread & Pastry---even if you do have a car---because  you'll find yourself wanting to stay longer than you expected and their establishment is right across the J MUNI line.
author: Valerie F.

description:
I ordered pastries from Thorough Bread last week and can't say enough wonderful about this bakery! Due to a scheduling mistake I ended up having to make a last minute order for 75 people (11am on Thursday for an 8am Friday pick-up). They were wonderful about it, double-checking with the bakers and being optimistic about the possibility. I gave them my person count and budget, I was flexible with what they could provide last minute, and that was it. My order was ready right at 8am!

We got fruit bars, croissants, gougeres and chouquettes. The plates were cleared pretty fast and next time I'll have to order more. 

Definitely recommend trying this local business before the big guys down the street (WF)!
author: Chanda G.

description:
It's a cute store, but the pastries fall short. I tried a croissant and a soy latte. The latte was meh. The croissant crust was amazing, but the insides were too bready and chewy. 

It's a cute place if you are nearby to grab a quick breakfast, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go back.
author: Sneha P.

description: Close your eyes and envision the delightful, deliciousness of Tartine. Inhale. Now think about Tartine without throngs of tourists and hipsters and no line. Exhale. That's basically what you got over here! An Amazing world class bakery set in a neighborhood. It's lovely. They even have cute little pastry bags they order from France with nice pictures. All just to make you smile and enliven and already sweet experiment.
author: Brian K.

description: I've only been here once, but would love to go back again.  I got their ham and cheese croissant and my husband got their savory bread pudding, they were good, but next time I would like to try their sandwiches and pastries.  I loved the atmosphere there- very warm and inviting, lots of tables.  We felt comfortable playing a game there.  Can't wait to go again!
author: Becky N.

description: This place was delightful. I was in the search for a close-to-authentic French pastry, and this definitely got the bill. I had an almond croissant and enjoyed it so much that I got a pain aux raisins to go in hopes that it would be just as delicious. The cappuccino was smooth and creamy with beautiful coffee art. They also have a lovely patio behind the building with excellent outdoor seating options.
author: Rebecca G.

description: Amazing quality pastries, surprisingly good coffee. Best breakfast I could find during my 2-week stay in the city. The breads are great too - I even brought back to NY some.
author: Anton T.

description: Phenomenal baked goods in a casual setting with a lovely back patio. Highly recommended. One of the best chai tea lattes I've had in a while -- nice and spicy.
author: Amy S.

description:
Ventured in here on pleasant Sunday afternoon. There was a bit of a line, but it moved along fairly quickly. 

I ordered the pulled pork sando...supposedly one of the most popular. The meat was tender, they added some pickles and mayo for a little extra flavor. Overall, greasy and messy and tasty.  A basic side salad with some vinaigrette...not too special.

I went back for an almond croissant since it was so highly recommended. Be sure that you ask for something that has just come out of the oven, because that's how you'll get the freshest goods, of course!  It was light and airy and crispy, while the center was nice and buttery. I would say it's solidly good, somehow it seems like it's missing something.  Perhaps a little almond paste in the center, like i've tasted in other bakeries? Also, know that the price is now $3.50. :-)
author: Evelyn K.

description:
Items Selected:
Chocolate Croissant Bread Pudding
Almond Croissant
Carrot Cake
Blueberry Scone
Sticky Bun
Chocolate Chip and Snickerdoodle Cookies

Long ignored due to my infatuation with Knead, b. patisserie, and Craftsman & Wolves it was with an early morning eleven mile run already under my belt that I finally made my way to Castro-favorite Thorough Bread & Pastry and although dismissive hipster service marred my experience at the counter I'd be lying if pronounced the pastry as anything less than impressive - only an overly-sweet frangipane-croissant disappointing in the least while the remaining half dozen selections shined.  Certainly more classic in approach than the aforementioned trio and not nearly as storied as Tartine it was just after 7:15am that I arrived at the Church Street storefront and with obvious sighs plus an eye-roll accompanying requests for separate plates and warm bread pudding it was to the back patio that I retired to indulge, the buttery bread pudding a decadent first bite as laminated pastry proved an admirable scaffold for rich custard and pockets of melting dark chocolate.  Underwhelmed by the croissant it was onward to two crisp cookies that my tasting progressed and with a soft scone well-endowed with butter plus blueberries quick to follow the best was yet to come - a salty caramel strew sticky bun crowned with toasty chopped pecans followed by reference standard spice cake chock full of carrots and lightly sweetened by layers cream cheese frosting that would make all but the most picky Southern Grandma swoon.
author: Michael U.

description: Almond croissants are to die for. Nice staff to deal with. Definitely come back again
author: Matt S.

description: I actually prefer Thorough over Tartine any day. The lines here are shorter, service is friendlier, and prices more reasonable. Their almond croissant is superb and their blueberry scone is moist and packed with blueberries. No complaints :)
author: Jen P.

description:
I went in to get a cup of coffee.

I came out with a mushroom quiche, a blueberry scone and 2 croissants, in addition to my coffee. Yes, they were all for me and I enjoyed every single morsel. Don't judge me.

Will I be back? Duh!
author: Stella L.

description:
Thorough Bread is a feast for your eyes, stomach, and soul. I wish I could have tried every single pastry on display, but alas...I am only the size of a human and not a horse. 

I wasn't in the mood for anything sweet, so luckily it wasn't too difficult to pick something. I settled for a savory scone and cappuccino. The savory scone was a surprisingly airy affair, filled with walnuts, rosemary, and Asiago. I am not normally a huge fan of walnuts, but they gave the scone great substance; their earthiness also balanced out the fragrance of the rosemary. Scones elsewhere are usually bricks of dry dough, but this scone was lighter than croissants I've had elsewhere. Speaking of croissants - my friends ordered a ham & cheese and an almond croissant; they looked so fluffy and delicious I immediately got jealous even though I had just finished my scone and I don't even eat meat. 

I was catching up with a friend in TB&P's fabulous outdoor courtyard and ended up staying long enough to catch a light lunch as well. The soup of the day was a tomato & lentil stew; if you order a cup, it comes with 4 slices of delicious sliced French baguette. Sadly, the stew was underseasoned. The bread, however, was fantastic - super soft, just chewy enough, and considerably more flavorful than the stew. 

Can't wait to come back for more carbs!
author: Sherry W.

description:
Just the best chocolate croissant and almond croissant I've eaten in my whole French life!
The owners are a French couple and they also manage the San Francisco Bakery Institute. Most of the employees there are actually students from the institute doing training there, which is kind of cute when you know it.

I can't stop having breakfast there every morning to taste this amazing flavor explosion again and again! You absolutely cannot be disappointed if you go there.
author: Jonathan V.

description:
The quiche is good enough, and so are the gougere puffs.  It's usually a second choice lunch spot, when other quiche options run out.  

Service is friendly but don't expect the extra mile here - they can't leave the register for long.

There's a decent patio in the back, shaded by trees, but beware of the pigeons!  They lurk.
author: Erika C.

description: They just raised prices. Coffee & almond croissant come to just under $6. It was around $4.50 if I recall. Significant hike results in lost star.
author: Chuck G.

description:
Another reason for Thorough Bread to earn a happy 5 Stars.....their *Chocolate Bread*

After being "good" since the New Year, what better time to splurge than Valentine's Day!  Knew I wanted to get a Church Street Cafe Mocha & what better pairing than Thorough Bread's pinnacle of yumminess - their Sticky Bun

In a word - it ROCKED but I won't bore you with another long, adoring description.....just read my previous review

After scoping out the opening hours here on Yelp - as I'm an early bird - I happened to read people's raves about the Chocolate Bread & I immediately think.....wow, they've just combined my TWO FAVORITE WORDS..... this has gotta be good.

And boy was it!

Slightly sweet bread that's chewy on the outside & soft & buttery on the inside w/ chocolate pieces that just melt in your mouth - no hard chips found here.  This isn't a muffin or a cake - but an honest-to-goodness bread & it's absolutely incredible!!

I had asked what people usually pair this bread with & from way behind the counter, this really nice guy tells me some place cherry jam on it & he's heard others talk about Goat's Cheese

Fantastic recommendations & I tried them both....  by itself (aka plain), w/ jam or goat's cheese, this bread is DELISH

Get. It.

Sticky Bun, Chocolate Bread & a Mocha - talk about a yummy splurge day!!

Thanks for making my Valentine's Day such a chocolaty delight!  I heart you!!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Thorough Bread & Pastry did the 3-tier chocolate cake at my wedding and it was fantastic! The cake tasting process was also really fun with a variety of mini-cakes set out to try. We ended up going with the 8-layer chocolate cake sans the chocolate flakes on the outside. I also asked for dark chocolate frosting and they delivered. 

The cake was not only beautiful but rich, fudgy, and delicious. It was seriously the best cake we had tasted all over the city. I had originally wanted a white wedding cake but switched to chocolate since it was just that good. Guests gave rave reviews and the bottom two tiers fed about 135 people since the caterer saved the top for our "1-year anniversary." I don't understand that tradition as why not go to the bakery and get a fresh one a year later so planning on defrosting and eating it when I have a large enough group.

We also ordered cookies as wedding favors and they were more than accomodating. Each had a orange stamp of the golden gate bridge on it, edges rolled in sugar as requested, and tied beautifully with purple ribbon in a cellophane bag. 

Not only was everything made with the finest ingredients and truly delicious but I found the prices very affordable and reasonable in the city. I highly recommend them for weddings!
author: Allison R.

description:
Two days in a row and I might be about ready to proclaim this my new favorite Mission bakery. (Gasp! Tartine! Definitely gives a run for its money.)

Another "down-to-earth" (read: still way more work than I'm willing to do at home for anything) but still "pretty hip" (yep everyone behind the counter is wearing trendy glasses) bakery, the cases of delectable looking goods start calling to you as soon as you walk in the door. As promised the almond croissants are delightful but they have an assortment of other treats.

One of the better aspects of Thorough Bread is the approachable size and pricing of everything. Very few items over $5, and most of the walk away treats are under $3. (Unheard in these parts) On the size front, they have small danishes (which in my opinion are almost always too big) and mini-gougeres and cream puffs. The delicious and well-reviewed almond croissant is only $2.50 and actually sized for one person, unlike most in the category. 

Haven't tried the sandwiches yet but by the looks of the breads it's next on my lunch list.

And maybe my favorite distinction from the other Mission favorite? NO LINE.
author: Stephanie T.

description: OMG....one of my co-workers brought a box of goodies this morning...Please only one time a month or less...just too good to resist..Loved the Ham and Cheese croissant, Hah thought I could only eat half..that's a NO! YUM!!
author: Michele U.

description:
The cheese danish here is great. The cheese filling isn't over powering but just sweet enough for the bread. The bread is firm with a soft center and has a savory aftertaste. The danish is also a reasonable size- not too small! It's great! 

I also purchased the quiche. It's a huge slice! I won't complain about the portions being too big. I wish the quiche had a more crispy crust. Because it lacked that, it lacked the satisfying bite it would have had. The quiche itself is great- soft egg filling with bits of ham. Delicious!
author: Saewah K.

description:
One day i decided to take a different route to work and stumbled across this charming little spot. I was impressed by the spread of pastries, displayed in the most beautiful way. As a savory food lover, I was also happy to see that they had a few non-sugary pastry options. I went with the potato bacon turnover and a cup of tea. Although they strangely didn't have ice to put in my scalding hot water, they kindly half-filled it so I could fill the rest with the cold water they had out for the customers. 

I think it's a very cute and delicious way to start the day, though I found the prices to be quite high. Visiting this spot every day on my way to work would add a lot to my waistline and take a lot out of my wallet! 

Definitely a good option in a convenient area though!
author: Christina P.

description:
Absolutely love this little bakery! As you walk in, you are enveloped with the heavenly scent of baked goods. To your right is an open bakery where a slew of deliciousness flaunts its stuff. Croissants, scones, bread pudding oh my! This is a carb lover's dream come true. Top that off with friendly staff, brick-walls and tons of outdoor seating; and you've got yourself a winner. 

I love that my friends are sharers. We got the savory bread pudding (my favorite), an apricot tart (delish) and a ham & cheese sandwich (just ok) that came with a salad. I'm definitely going back for more savory bread pudding!!
author: Emily H.

description: Went on a sunday morning at 9am. Wasnt crowded at all. They had everything out and fully stocked. Yum everything looks sooo good from the cakes to the pastries.  I got a little of everything. The mushroom tomato quiche was soo yummy n flaky. The almond crossiant had just the pefect amount of almond filling inside the outter crossiant was buttery and flaky. Their hot chocolate was a little on the bitter side for me and i dissapointed that they didnt make a nice little design like they do the mochas. The cream puffs drizzled with chocolate on top 3.50 for 3 small pieces but def worth every penny. Fillled with bavarian cream yummy. I also had their cheesecake 6 bucks for four bites but it sure was tasty. The carrot cake was dry n had too many spices for my taste. My husband liked the potato bacon turnover but the blueberry  scone was just ok.
author: Melissa K.

description:
Yummy at first bite!

Almond Croissant: Crusty, nutty, and tasty but I still prefer La Boulange's. 

Almond Brioche Toast: Yum. A step up from other flavored Brioche I've had. 

Mini Macacrons: Small and not too flavorful. A set of four comes in a plastic cylinder container. I would pass the next time around. 

Cheese Puffs: Delish. Especially when you take it home and warm it up in the oven. 

Service: Delightful. The girl working there was very nice and packaged each baked good in their individual bags. 

Parking: A nightmare. I parked about three looooong blocks away on a Sunday.
author: Dee T.

description: OMG... so good!!!  This place isn't as well known as Tartine or some of the others, but damn is it good.  The cream puffs are small bites of heaven.  I highly recommend this place!!
author: Mark B.

description: One of my absolute favorite bakeries in San Francisco. The almond croissant is crisp/flakey on the outside and warm/chewy on the inside. The cafe itself is so cute and they have a beautiful outside garden to hang out in as well. Love love this place.
author: Samantha S.

description: I have been going here for many years and I love this place!! It has been consistent in terms of quality bakery items and service. Not too much sugar and Incredibly fresh!! My all time faves are the Almond Croissant, there are others close to perfection of Thoroughbread in the City but this one always has The Best -  crispy goodness and that nice almondy paste inside to deee-light your innards. And then the Glorious dubl choco cookies  and choc chip cookies to make your smile melt and eyes roll way back....  Over the years I have purchased dozens of these treasures to bring to my clients and they were grateful one expressing that they did biz with my company Becuz I cared enough to bring these incredible goodies all the way to Oaklahoma!! And LA & Texas..... I hope things aren't changing too much there recently the cookies were weighed down by a major sugar overdose - so I threw 2 dozen in the garbage instead of taking them to a client.  I only hope this is not their new standard.
author: Lisa S.

description:
We enjoy the delicious pastries, cakes, bread--well, we love everything Thorough Bread!  Unfortunately, today's morning visit was at first delightful then horrific and then delightful again.  Our only disastrous visit to our not so sure favorite bakery anymore.

As we skipped with joy through the front door, to be greated by the always friendly and smiling baker--we almost ran to the front to order our usual almond croissant and eye the beautiful other choices to arrive at our second and final treat for this beautiful Saturday morning.  A perfect choice, berry coffee cake!!!  We ordered the two sweets and a latte to enjoy in the energetic and busy space that smells of everything good.

After a few minutes, I approached the coffee bar area and asked if "he" had an order for a latte.  "He" pointed to a to go cup on the counter and said in a rude, condescending and grumpy tone "she ordered it as as a to go!!!"  "I can put into a cup if you want!".  

How sad that such an awful person without any positive personality has to be employed by such a wonderful place--get a life, go somewhere where your &#^(*&!  attitude is appreciated.

I returned to my seat and my sweet partner asked what was wrong--I explained what a %@(#& and a *#*&^*&^# this guy was to me.  I walked up to the always delightful baker by the front door and told him what happened.  He explained that the front manager, Courtney was not in today but that he would speak with her about the situation tomorrow.  He was just perfect, customer service plus -- five gold stars for service, service, service!!!

I returned to our table and enjoyed the rest of our delicious pastries and my latte in a paper cup.

As we left, the baker wished us a good day, apologized for the Barista and handed us two special treats to enjoy later--again apologizing for the ^%@&(&^%.

What a super guy the baker is and what a super employee too.  Cheers to you for being so wonderful and shame on the other guy for being anything but a great team player or good employee--a total nasty creep!

We'll be back to Thorough Bread but Barista beware--we won't put up with your bad attitude or lack of customer service!

No choice but to reduce my 5 stars to 4 stars.  Train the guy or get rid of him.

Consistently wonderful food and wonderful service sans the Barista.
author: Jeff P.

description: We come here all the time. Pastries are fab. Coffee is good. Love the ham and cheese croissant, almond croissant and the lil puffs with rock sugar on top.
author: Nori L.

description: This charming hideaway in the heart of the Castro came highly recommended and did not disappoint me. They've got the most gorgeous baked goods selection: little cakes, turnovers, cream puffs, and tons more. The service was sweetly sincere, and I devoured the moist, crumbly, perfectly seasoned savory scone I ordered. Then I sat and wrote under the enormously tall tree on their nicely appointed back patio.
author: Kristy L.

description:
3 days until the Nike Women's Half Marathon and I'm at Thorough Bread & Pastry. I don't think this place will help me w/the hills. 

But I was invited to a small dinner party and thought that bringing desserts would earn me cool points. I'm currently at 475 points and if I get 25 more I could get a Chinese finger trap!

Easy point accumulators were:

White Chocolate Raspberry Mousse 5.95
White cake layered w/white chocolate Mousse, a huge slab of raspberry jelly, then more mousse, then a thin raspberry coating on top. Not recommended if ur training for a marathon. Or if u want to save ur teeth.

Caramel Chocolate Tart 5.50
Fancy tart w/a lil gold flake in the middle. Extremely sweet, only for the pros. Chocolate crust w/gooey caramel and thick chocolate filling. I scored the gold flake for my front tooth.  Instant rapper points. 

Carrot cake 5.50
2 layers of carrot cake divided by a layer of cream cheese. Gigantor walnuts. Very fine coconut shavings were added on to the sides of the cake, atop the cream cheese.  No CA raisins in this cake. They were probably dancing round the corner down Castro.

French Macaroons 3 for 3.50
2 pistachio and 1 chocolate. Typical macs, I've had better but I've also had worse. First time I had a chocolate where the filling was overpowering. 

What I didn't bring to the party but had on my way to it:

Good hand sized Snickerdoodle cookie .75
75 cents??  Mrs. Fields. You just got served. 

Vol au vent 2.50
Hollow buttery pastry shell filled w/mushrooms, onions and cheese. Super mushroomy. Super good.

This place is the bees knees cuz it employs the interns and grads from it's school- The San Francisco Baking Institute.  They learn how to make it, bake it, and we buy and eat it.  Their products are excellent.  Good job, students!
author: Rho T.

description:
2nd best cheese and ham croissant I had in my life. Sorry, the best one was in Germany. But it was close, really close.
Will be back :)
author: Caroline K.

description:
We went here to get a croissant and something sweet, I was hoping for a Danish.  The price at this place is nice but thats the only upside.

The quality of the croissant was lame (very dry, not buttery) and tasted sour.  The Danish was a tart, not a Danish, and only about the size of a 50 cent piece, had no center filling bit just three raspberries, not even in a raspberry sauce or something, just sitting there in the center of some over dry unglazed pastry dough.  And lastly the service was only okay, the girl who helped us scoffed when I asked if they had a Danish as if I was supposed to know at this one bakery thats what they call a tart.  But there was no line and we were in and out quick, so no real complaints there
author: Alvin B.

description:
I came here on a Sunday afternoon and got an almond croissant. One of the folks there said they are known for having the best almond croissant in the city, so despite the cakes looking unique and delicious (especially the chocolate mousse), I decided to try the almond croissant.
