It was truly well put together and delicious! The focus is on the bread as opposed to the inside filling -- it is perfectly fluffy and the almond taste is not overwhelming but certainly present. 

Other tasty-looking treats are the chocolate mousse and the strawberry lemon mouse.
author: Fatima S.

description:
This bakery used to be a "Just Desserts" bakery location many years ago. With the huge area, I don't think they couldn't put a better bakery but Thorough Bread.  

While still being one of jurors, wife and I came here for dessert/snack for her lunch intermission. I was also on my way to work, which is also in the same building. I'm sure some of you know what type of dangerous work I do. 
 
Every single pastries and bread are made in the actual bakery.The bakery is also a deli making Panini sandwiches made with freshest ingredients with the bakery's bread. With the elegant and nice presentations on the counter and depending on your desires, there are so many great options to choose. Also, wife was panting and salivating like a hungry-dog.  

Let's see...okay, I'll start. I had one of the bakery's Almond Croissant and a medium Latte, both for $2.50 each. I've always enjoyed Tartine's Almond Croissant Pastry. But in comparison, Thorough-Bread's version is right up there with the tasty filling and exploding crunch.  

Almond Croissant:http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MTIqLOBdISaon4G22qb5Lg?select=xdJzN45Z3zuTl51llb_J9Q
Latte:http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MTIqLOBdISaon4G22qb5Lg?select=3IxsICNmE_rvkJUwQmYaKA

Wife had the Baba Au Rhum. The $5.50 treat is a slice of Gallete soaked in a "STRONG" Rum. After one bite of the alcoholic treat, she felt inebriated, but happy. According to her, the bakery must've put Bacardi 151(proof) in the strong treat. Not a bad way to go back to court feeling buzzed. She also add a Peppermint Tea to complete the treat. The tea is from Harney and Son's Fine Tea. 

Baba Au Rhum: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MTIqLOBdISaon4G22qb5Lg?select=Xq_DgcRNxBSIx0K7AHxVPQ
Peppermint Tea: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MTIqLOBdISaon4G22qb5Lg?select=GzlPSXyglbE1ef2_F_SLtw

I'll defintely be back and check out more of the fresh pastries and check out the Panini Sandwiches.
author: Matt G.

description: Great little spot for coffee and pastries. I was dropping off some clothes at Crossroads, but arrived too early so walked over here for a morning snack. I had something with bacon...so of course it was delicious :) They also had a jalapeño cheese bread that sounded delicious too, but I will have to try that next time. Good amount of seating (mostly small tables from what I remember though, maybe more seating in the back?) and beautiful display for you to ogle the pastries as you wait in line to order. Not sure if they have outlets, but if so, would be a great place to work on a weekend. Otherwise, it's a great environment for people watching or catching up with a friend.
author: Kathy L.

description: The almond croissants here are heaven. Crispy on the outside, fluffy on the inside, and oh so buttery everywhere. I used to live in the Sunset and had to take the L to work in FiDi. If I got up a little early, I would get off at Church, grab an almond croissant, and enjoy the buttery goodness the rest of my way to work. Made my mornings that much better.
author: Cindy A.

description: A lovely post-work stop for treats, coffee, and bread.  It's a nice airy space with a clean bathroom.  The latte and pb cookie were great!  The two people who helped me were really nice too.
author: Desiree S.

description:
I love this place. It would be 5 stars if they composted.

I love their rosemary walnut scone. Decent coffee/espresso too.

Please bring back the cherry-pistachio pastry. Yum.
author: Raj T.

description: This review is only for the almond double baked croissant. Five stars and definitely a must try at this bakery. Great ambience and seating with plenty of power plugs, also serves sightglass coffee
author: Toon O.

description:
During that season where Irish Soda Bread is popping its currants up at every corner bakery, I stumbled into Thorough Bread.

I inquired about the studded little fella and to this day am not sure what to make of the response I received. The guy mentions something about lots of (baking) soda, in that, if I enjoy the taste of an aluminum can, I ought to get a loaf. I opt instead for a hefty slice of banana bread and it fueled me through the morning.

Pastries and breads are well priced and for once in this city, I feel like I am not getting taken on a loaf of bread. I mean, when did flour and water become so pricey that a loaf should run 4 or 5 bucks?

From scones, bite-size gougères, mini cookies and purple wheat baguettes, I can't seem to get enough. There are always piles petite treats so when you don't want to over indulge (or are feeling cheap), you can still fulfill that buttery-chocolatey-carby-yeasty craving of yours.

As much as I can't wait for aluminum cans to get back in season, I'm still a regular here, found popping a few gougères on the run or a fruit galette on the patio out back.
author: Alissa A.

description: I absolutely love this place--I'm the mayor on Foursquare and eat something here daily. The staff includes culinary students. Even basic things (like a bran muffin) are delicious. Try the blueberry scone, any quiche, a croissant with ham inside, and the chocolate cake. I've never had a bad item. (Also, they use Mr. Espresso beans--best coffee in the neighborhood.)
author: Tim P.

description: SF's hidden gem of a bakery! Better than Tartine and no lines! They have an incredible chocolate bread loaf that you can only get on the weekends. Also their fruit tart, bread pudding and ham and cheese croissants are incredible. They have a cute outdoor patio in the back if you want to hang out and enjoy your pastries. Seriously, this place is amazing!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
This week blew. So much so, that when I woke up this morning, I was like I AM TAKING THE DAY OFF (yeah, its saturday... fml) and going to go sit at a cafe, sip coffee, eat a pastry, read the damn newspaper, and be a honey badger for awhile. 

It rocked. Their almond croissant was just as good as people say and yes, I think it's better than Tartine. (Oh, and I love Tartine. I love Tartine like I love my cat. Except one doesn't swipe at my eyes while I'm asleep, so I love one of the two more right now.) And their patio was the perfect place to send a morning chatting with your friend about how much you dislike bitches, general nonsense, sandwiches, etc. 

If I had a normal life and normal metabolism, I'd come here all the time. But sadly I don't have either.
author: Emily D.

description:
Be warned: their pastry case is gorgeous, and the smell of fresh-baked goodies as you enter makes you want to buy everything in said pastry case. 

We had a mushroom quiche, a ham and bell pepper quiche, an orange scone, and a mixed berry muffin. The muffin was definitely the standout! You can really taste each giant chunk of berry within, and the consistency of the dough was perfect (moist without being too dense). 

Can't wait to try some of their other treats next time I'm in the area.
author: Diana P.

description: Food OK -- vibes not good and clientele way below par.  Don't bother with this place.
author: Richard D.

description: Just had another amazing breakfast (European style) at Thorough Bread cafe. Cappuccino, warmed apple galette, creamy butternut squash quiche. The key is to get your pastries warmed up. It makes all the difference. They do it happily in their oven (thank god not in a microwave!). Prices are reasonable and best of all...no wifi!!! That means people actually talk to each other and seats aren't taken up for 3 hours at a time. Backyard patio is a super bonus. :)
author: Jonathan R.

description:
What an amazing find, and in my humble opinion, better than Tartine. Plus, there's never a wait and there's a back patio to relax in. It really doesn't get better. Our go to items - 

Croissants - Ham & cheese, almond, you name it, are to die for. The best croissants I've had outside of France. Melt in your mouth buttery, perfectly flakey, just incredible.

Baguettes - Crunchy on the outside, soft and chewy on the inside, just the way bread should be. Both rustic & traditional are delicious.
author: Connie C.

description:
love their multigrain bread! Dream about it!
Try their Pan Bagnats, a traditional French sandwich from the South of France. Having lived there, I am always looking for a good Pan Bagnat and Thorough's is the best I've found in many decades of looking! Delicious!
author: Les L.

description: Great selection of pastries. Unfortunately no pre-made flan or tiramisu, but they said they would make those if you request them ahead of time. However, the big surprise came from their pulled pork sandwich. Big serving size and tasted great. Also, their sugar cookies are amazing.
author: Tony C.

description:
I wanted to like this place! Really I did! Mainly because everyone else seemed to love it and I got super excited about coming here. But as it turned out, I was disappointed instead =(

But Marti, they have good looking desserts! Yes, I agree. And they have good looking pastries as well. Unfortunately, no WOW factor for this girl. They all looked very typical.

My friend and I each had the Pulled Pork sandwich. Something different. And we both enjoyed it. Ciabatta bread, pulled pork with tangy bbq sauce, mayo and pickles. Yes, pickles! The ciabatta bread was a good choice since it retained all the juice from pork, giving the sandwich a nice contrast of textures. Soft/soggy interior, crunchy exterior. Messy!

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MTIqLOBdISaon4G22qb5Lg?select=1pzuaADgDzHd5cRd8KbTcQ
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MTIqLOBdISaon4G22qb5Lg?select=jyiRTGSQv3KNtCXHpi9_BA

Simple green salad on the side. Nice! Drenched in balsamic vinegar dressing. Not nice! 

Ah. Time for dessert. Lemon Pound Cake. I've heard much about it. Also failed to impress me. My critique? Too much glaze. Too little lemon. It felt store bought. Very generic. Nothing spectacular. A hint of spice, or lemon zest would've made it so much better =(

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MTIqLOBdISaon4G22qb5Lg?select=hk-hZWdH7NGvc7Le1LHnzw
author: Marti L.

description:
My foodie friend and I came for lunch yesterday around 12:30 pm.  Lots of empty tables.  When you enter, the pastry items are to your immediate right.  Everything looked so delish.  You can also take a look at the laminated menu next to the order taker/cashier.  Place your order, pay, find a seat, and your food is brought to you.

I ordered the veggie focaccia sandwich. I was able to sub the red bell peppers for more zucchini.  Great sandwich.  I only ate half as I wanted to save room for the almond croissant.  Went back up to the counter and placed an order for the croissant.  

Took it back to my table, and used a fork and knife and dived in.  

Mouth watering.  It was a good size one and heavy to the touch.  Again I was only able to eat half.  

Great cup of coffee.  Went well with the croissant.

I would love to come back and try some of the other tempting sandwiches and baked goods.

We took the muni metro to and from.
author: Shirley N.

description: I used to LOVE this place and used to buy some pastries for the office meetings. The bakers are talented and make very good (and pretty) cakes. Unfortunately  my favorite pastries are overcooked most of the time. this week again, the almond croissants were carbonised. they shouldn't have been sold. That's too bad because when cooked right, they taste amazing. They've mentioned they've heard this comment many times... but don't seem to care enough to change anything.
author: sandrine c.

description: I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this place. Hands down the best pastries in town. And yes I mean better than Tartine...by far! They also serve the best coffee drinks made with Sightglass Coffee. I am so happy to have this in my 'hood and love that it has been there forever and still people have not discovered how amazingly wonderful this place really is.
author: Denise L.

description: Returned from a trip to Southern France with a newfound sweet-tooth.  After searching for pastries at some groceries or mass-corporate cafes and almost resigning myself to foregoing all croissant pending a return to Europe, if not to bake them myself, I had to get serious.  (Paying $4 per piece at such places is bad enough, but for a hardened, stale ...thing?)  Therefore, was very pleasantly surprised to discover Thorough Bread & Pastry, where the croissant are excellent and rival those found abroad.  Sticky buns and loaves were also excellent -- all very fresh and tasty.  Cafe itself is clean, well-lit, pretty, dynamic and has exceedingly pleasant atmosphere, as well.  They offer 'real' cutlery to those who dine in.  I will try their sandwiches next, rather than take said croissant home in order to make my own, as doing heretofore.
author: Lisa V.

description: Delicious chouquets and almond croissant, especially when they are fresh out of the oven! The line can get long but it moves fast. I didn't think their shortbread cookies were that amazing. Haven't tried their sticky bun but maybe next time!
author: Michelle K.

description: The almond croissant is addicting!
author: Rose A.

description: Just the wonderful buttery smell that hits you as you walk in deserves 5 stars!  Personal favorite is the ham and cheese croissant, but you can't go wrong with anything you get there!
author: Michelle K.

description:
I am a party planner and picked up an order for a party today. Everything looked so good in the case so I had to buy a couple of things to sample since I've never been here before. 
Gougeres: 4 for $2.00  1 star
I got 1 of each, 1 savory and 1 that was sweet & dusted with powder sugar. Neither one did anything for me, not much to it, nothing I'd get again. 
Veggie quiche: I think the ingredients were asparagus & mushroom   3 stars
The crust was on point as was the flavor of the filling BUT there were a lot of stems of the asparagus that was "woody". I guess they either don't know how to snap it & toss the woody part of they know but too cheap to throw that part again. The ruined the whole thing for me. I don't care how good the crust, seasoning, and everything else is if one of your ingredients is funky. I won't be ordering this either nor will I return again for me.
author: May G.

description:
I smelled Danishes while I was working out at 24, and it was driving me crazy. Turns out this place is on the same block so maybe my nose is just super powerful! 

This place made some excellent raspberry Danishes and I definitely will come back for the pulled pork sandwiches
author: Tom I.

description:
I think I found my new favorite bakery.

Was craving something carb-loaded, so I did a quick search online and found Thorough Bread. I'm a sucker for a clever name (and their menu looked decent enough), so I stopped in for lunch on a Friday.

The place was relatively quiet, with only a few other customers present. I drooled over all of the desserts in the case and then asked for a sandwich menu. I went with the Garden Sandwich and got a slice of the sweet bread pudding to-go. The sandwich was delicious (and so was the bread pudding when I ate it later!). The service was good. Everyone was friendly and I was greeted by two different people when I walked in.

All-in-all, I'll definitely be back. There were too many delicious-looking treats in that case that I simply MUST try.
author: Cookie H.

description:
"Professional bakery from afar, student-run quality when up close"

This is another highly rated yelp eatery that i am not so in love with...i came here twice...both times trying a few pastries and a loaf of bread...neither times made me crave coming back but i did enjoy the atmosphere a lot. 

Almond Croissant = B-
- slightly dry
- way too much topping (like a melted mess...refer to photo)
- tasted okay, nothing wow about it

Coffee Eclair = C
- like any pate choux pastry, it needed to be eaten fresh
- as i ate it at 4pm, it was not fresh at all...soggy on the inside
- coffee filling had weak coffee flavor, but good consistency

Chouquettes (4 for $1.50) = D-
- Savory chouquettes = pate choux with a lil chive and cheese
- Sweet chouquettes = pate choux with a sprinkling of sweet
- because not fresh out of the oven, very difficult to eat + swallow...avoid!
- cold, uncrisp, soggy, and dry...not a treat to eat at all

Lemon Blackberry Moussecake = B
- good mix of sweet and sour
- outside cake layer looked very nice but not hard and stiff
- beautiful design

Baguette (sweet) = D
- too airy, nearly like safeway or lucky's
- flavorless (nothing like the bread i make at home or acme's)
- no idea why its a bestseller (sold out first time i went)

Teff Miche ($5) = B+
- best thing i had here
- was told by cashier that its a part sourdough bread and african in origin...she had a stuckup attitude but convinced me to buy this overpriced loaf
- has a strong sour taste that is similar but slightly different from sourdough
- nice and moist...great tasting crust + color

Bottom Line
- quite pricey for the quality
- great atmosphere as u won't get bothered and it is a wide space...too bad the seats are not spaced out enough
- bread is mediocre but Teff Miche is good
- sweet pastries fall very short of the top bakeries in sf
- looking at the pastry window, you can see that many were created in the hands of students...not as consistent as if made by pros
author: Simon L.

description:
I'm sure this is what Heaven smells like. I love this place. THE BEST Almond Croissant. Fresh out of the oven blueberry scone. So good. 
Oh, and the staff is so nice and friendly. I seriously love you guys.
author: Juliana A.

description:
The morning of Sunday, December 30th. 

The food was delicious. The croissant was light, fluffy and flaky. The Brighton crunch was the perfect mix of chocolate and hazelnut.

The service was horrendous, to be specific, just one employee made our visit miserable. A couple of points:
* she pushed us to make a pastry decision although we'd not been there before
* she handed us our plates and then rushed off before I could ask for silverware. 
* she then made coffee for the two people behind us in line until I begged another employee for our drinks who saw the empty cups just sitting there.
* when I asked for butter and jam for my croissant, she handed me one pat of butter. Then walked away. When I finally got her attention again, I asked for jam. She angrily scooped some out handing me a little tin cup and her serving spoon, just to get me out of her face. 
* I had to return to the counter to ask for silverware, but she walked away every time I tried to catch her eye, finally a nice employee handed me a silverware bundle. 

It was a busy day, tons of people in line, however, there was no need for the rude and bitchy attitude this employee showed us. 

Steer clear of the short, white, freckled face female with brown-haired employee, she's a nightmare.

To the pastry chefs and all other employees.... Bravo!
author: Pstephan A.

description:
I've been a huge fan since moving into the area.  My addictions are:

Almond Croissant-The BEST croissant ever...and leaves me feeling guilty since I devour the whole thing without sharing

Cream Puffs- I buy these every year for my coworkers during Christmas and everyone loves them

Besides amazing baked good they have a super friendly staff...def my favorite bakery in SF and I only live a few blocks away.  Lucky me!
author: Michelle M.

description: I was here for 4 days and went here twice which is a big deal for me because I'm all about tasting as much as possible.  The reason for coming back was one thing.  Ham and cheese croissant.  Oh my effing god that thing was so freaking good.  I took it back to our airbnb and warmed it up the next morning for breakfast.  I'm telling you I couldn't speak for like 3 minutes that thing was so good.  I'm sure everything else there is amazing but you HAVE to try the ham and cheese croissant!!
author: Bridget K.

description: Great selections! we just looked and order randomly, turned out everything are tasty delicious. Not too sweet, not too chewy. We had Chocolate parline, good little crunch. The cream puff has smooth creamy, not too sweet and the puff outside is not too soft nor too hard, good bite size, really nice texture and goes well with the cream.  We also enjoy the Coffee toffy and Almond croissant.
author: Kei S.

description:
Thorough Bread & Pastry was great! So I was craving pastries last week but didn't want to stand in that crazy line at Tartine so instead, I finally decided to try Thorough Bread & Pastry. I was SO happy to see that there was only 2-3 people ahead of me in line! 

My biggest complaint was that I felt rushed in ordering and felt like I couldn't really look at the selection. I ended up getting a Blueberry scone, eclair, and almond croissant. First of all, the prices were so reasonable and I walked out of there for under 8 bucks which I consider a steal for how delicious the pastries were. 

The almond croissant was great! Although, it was a little bit too rich for me and I couldn't get through the whole thing. Halfway through, the almond flavor became too pungent and sweet. But it's great for sharing and is definitely worth trying. 

I don't like scones much but my boyfriend does and we both loved this one! He couldn't stop raving about it calling it the best scone he has ever had. It's not dry like those terrible Starbucks scones. It was moist and each bite basically had crumbs that trailed off because of how soft it was. 

The eclair was good, too. It was no Tartine though- haha. 

This is a great alternative to Tartine if you're looking for a pastry and don't want to wait. They have a lot of seating too and it doesn't feel overwhelming when you walk in. I'd love to come here again for brunch with a friend or with a book in hand. So quaint and cute!
author: Angeline V.

description:
This bakery has the best pastries ever!!!!! I thought Porto's Bakery in LA was pretty awesome but their service and pastries beat every one out there. My boyfriend took me here on a Friday afternoon for lunch, knowing I would love this place =D. 

He got me the Rustic Tart ($4) and Vol au Vent ($2.50) with a cup of coffee while he got himself the Almond Croissant ($2) and a cappuccino. Everything was amazing!! 

The Rustic Tart has blueberries, pears, and raspberries with the perfect sweetness to it. I was originally choosing between the Rustic Tart or the Vol au Vent but I'm glad I got both because they were the perfect complement! 

The Vol au Vent is a flaky pastry filled with creamy béchamel and mushrooms. ohmygosh this is the most orgasmic pastry EVER. it's sooo delicious that I'm determined to have this at my future wedding ;].

I got to taste his Almond Croissant also...MMMMMM. Delicious! This would be a perfect breakfast. :] 

The bakery is affiliated with the SF Baking Institute so I love this place even more. I'm assuming the workers are students from the Institute. Great service, very kind and helpful. 

Definitely coming back here again to try everything!
author: Linda L.

description: There seems to be a magnet that keeps drawing us back! We were trying to find a new cafe and pastry shop but came back here probably for the fourth time... BUT this shows we do love the place!! If I cud if world have given 4.5 stars! The pastries were DDDelicious, we had orange pecan scone - just moist enough and chocolate croissant.  Only thing I can ding them on is the coffee is kinda weak.  I had a cappuccino. Made me wish I went to four barrels on Valencia for coffee instead. But I'd definitely be DRAWN again to the place!!
author: Chow C.

description:
Another great bakery in SF, but the advantage of this one is that it's close to home.  I ordered a large carrot cake for Mother's Day. $28 for 6" was not bad because the cake was tall and was more than enough to feed 7 of us. It had nuts, raisins and coconut, but best of all it wasn't too sweet. 

The Grasshopper tasted like an Andes mint, yum. 

The Bluejay was a white chocolate cake with blueberries in the center.  It was tart and not too sweet. 

If you like lemon and tarty cakes, then you'll like the lemon blackberry cake. It wasn't for me, but others enjoyed it. 

I'd definitely come back to try their other items.
author: K V.

description:
Holy moly...want can you possibly say about this place that hasn't already been said?? It's absolutely ridiculously awesome. I was in the city visiting and a friend told us to meet him here for breakfast one morning. We drove out and was blown away at the amount of wonderful baked goods that this place has. Their coffee was excellent, atmosphere was super fabulous. My daughter was in baked-goods heaven, as were all the adults in the group!!!

It's probably a good thing that we don't live in the city because I'd be a 500lb person living close to this place. 

The Almond Croissant was impossibly good, the Castro Cookies were fabulously fun, the quiche was sublime, the blueberry little cake was superb...I could go on and on. Really, one of my most favorite spots in the city. I know I'll be visiting there again when we go back to the city!!!
author: Colleen C.

description:
This is an ideal place to lounge while enjoying a hot(or cold) beverage with a fresh pastry. Like most bakeries, do not come here before closing and expect to find the best variety. This can be considered a good thing, since it likely shows that most of the baked goods were already bought out. 

I don't think I've tried even half of the items sold here, but everything I have tried tasted superb. The mousse cake varieties are my favorite so far. For you lemon fans out there, the lemon blackberry moussecake is especially  delicious. The moussecakes here are layered with a slightly spongy cake, followed by a generous mousse filling. 

The macarons are pretty good too. I got petite ones that were pre-packaged in a tube. Flavors vary from day to day. 

Other things I liked:
 
+Before entering:
The display window advertises the shop's crafty side. I've noticed multiple themes from skeletons made of bread to macaron trees. Each display is of intricate quality, revealing craftmanship, skill, and hard work.  

+Backyard seating:
There's an option to eat outside of the shop towards the back. It mimics one's backyard, almost garden-like. Very intimate and refreshing. 

+Hot drinks:
Warm up your belly with a steamy beverage. The hot chocolate and espresso based drinks pair perfectly with the foods here. 

+Cookies
Jumbo, crumbly, and soft. How every cookie should be.

+Bread and pastry assortment:
I love the concept used here. The breads and pastries look done free-hand style, not too perfect in shape or machine-made. There's a rustic and personal feel that really shines through, which is adorable and somehow alluring. 

I like this store and reccomend it to anyone embarking on a foodie adventure in castro. This place will without a doubt remedy anyone's sweet tooth. I will definitely be back for more moussecakes and to try new items!
author: Vaneza A.

description: I've been dreaming about the chocolate bread ever since I had it last week. That's right--chocolate bread. Two of my favorite foods combined. Not chocolate quick bread. This is real yeast bread. But chocolate. We split the one remaining chocolate bread, a generous-sized braided roll of chocolate yeast dough sprinkled throughout with chocolate chips. At $2.50, it was a good deal (and a much better deal than the insanely priced pie slices down the street at Chile Pies). The lattes were also good. In fact, the lattes and chocolate bread were good enough for me not to mind that there is no wifi here.
author: Susan S.

description:
I love places that are super on top of their customer service because that should always be a top priority for a business that serves customers. I went here yesterday and had some miscommunication with my server, in my frustration, I wrote a not so pleasant review. They were so on top of it! She came out and cleared up the miscommunication in a polite and direct way! I love that! Not only does it show accountability but also an individual approach. I am sure one negative yelp review for such a thriving business isn't a killer but the fact that she felt strongly enough to communicate to me and clear up the misunderstanding made me feel respected and valued as a customer. Really awesome! I am beyond impressed :)

Now for the food! If you come here early enough the intoxicating aroma of fresh baking goods fills the air and envelopes you in a cloud of sweetness. The pastry I ended up sampling was a delicate on with apples layered on top. It was soft, light, flakey and just the right amount of not-too-sweet. Also non of the other coffee shops have anything on their mocha's. Oh Lordy! That mocha is out of this world rich and decadent!
author: Anna B.

description:
Mmmm. Buttery, flaky, fruity goodness served up at the former Just Desserts cafe. 

But sadly the patio has a family or two of mice dancing and scurrying under the tables (we counted 4). It kinda spooked me. I saw a black exterminator box along the edge - it obviously isn't a large enough intervention.
author: Richard B.

description:
Wow!  Just finished brunch at Home Restaurant & Bar down the street, and my friend Bonnie says to stop by here for the best almond croissant she's ever had.  

This bakery is not only stocked full of "to die for" sweet and savory goodies, but it is also an awesome place to hang out on a lazy afternoon.  It has a nice backyard with gorgeous trees and plants.  Perfect for a sunny day.

Bonnie is right.  Thorough Bread & Pastry creates the best tasting, not to mention best looking almond croissant I've ever had in my life.  The croissant is so flaky.  Initially you will feel the crunch as you bite into the croissant, but once your teeth sinks in, you can taste how soft and moist the inside is.  It has the perfect amount of almond flavor in every bite.  I just LOVE it! 

I've also tried their pistachio shortbread cookie and it is amazing as well.  I can't wait to go back and try other pastries.
author: Gloria Y.

description:
Mmmm... I only tried two things here: almond croissant and pistacio shortbread cookie. The croissant was so, so yummy. Mmm... not too sweet, flakey and it had perfect almond filling. We visited on a late Sunday afternoon and they still had a great selection of fresh baked items. 

Can't wait to come back to try more of their baked goods!

Adorable patio for outdoor seating. What a nice place to enjoy some pastries and coffee!
author: Cindy Y.

description:
When I came into this pristine establishment, I feel like I should be banging two coconut halves like the gallant knights in "Monty Python and the Holy Grail". But I guess they mean thorough breads, not thoroughbreds. Clip-clop, clip-clop, clip-clop, clip-clop, clip-clop...

Whoa!...Good horsey. I've been wanting to come in here for a while because it looks so inviting. But alas, they close at 7pm, just when I happen to be perusing Church Street for a nibble. Food...I mean food. Y'see, I had a bad Friday as I skipped lunch entirely due to a stressful work schedule. It was the kind of day where I needed a dessert before I had dinner...and then another dessert after dinner.

Anyway, Jamie W. had the great idea of coming here after work before they closed. There weren't many baked selections left, but what was left looked good. We shared a $2.75 slice of Lemon Pound Cake that was effortlessly moist and not too lemony. We took it outside in the small patio in back. It was empty so we could hear the wind rustling through the leaves on top of the tall tree in the middle.

It was only later that I found out the students of the San Francisco Baking Institute make all the goodies, so that explains the attention to detail and the flavorful results. The warm decor also helps with the Tuscan-and-brick walls and well spaced tables. I'll be back if I can get there before it closes, but I have to saddle up now. Clip-clop, clip-clop, clip-clop, clip-clop, clip-clop....

FOOD - 4 stars...superior baked goods, need to come back for their hearty-looking sandwiches
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...warm, lofty appeal with a nice patio in the back
SERVICE - 4 stars...ah youth...friendly, attentive students on staff
TOTAL - 4 stars...a worthwhile stop on your way to Dolores Park...or if you had as bad a day as I had...
author: Ed U.

description:
If I'm going to end up fat, I'm going to do so by eating the pastries here with no shame.

Had their bacon quiche and almond croissant, both well heated in their oven for some delish goodness. Their croissant was moist, soft, and buttery inside - which, for some reason, not many bakeries in the US can do well.

I heard their coffee was not that good, so I ended up not getting any - but pair this place up with some respected coffee from SF poured by a good barista, I might just have to go and give them five stars.
author: Joe H.

description:
- Vol au vent: pretty good, flaky crust with creamy mushroom filling
- Almond croissant: delicious
- Pumpkin spice loaf: great if you like pumpkin; topped with nice crunchy pumpkin seeds
- Purple wheat baguette: it's slightly sourdough-tasting
author: Grace C.

description: The almond croissant was really good not worth $3.75 tho.  Maybe if you were super hungry like me. The customer service was lacking. Just a basic hi and stare. No smile or anything. Very typical hipster SF feel lacking in friendliness and personality. Inside looks nice but it was kinda cold with the door open not that cozy cafe bakery feel. If ever in the neighborhood again I'll prob try the coffee which looked good.
author: Lola S.

description: Love this place! We got the gougeres, chocolate croissant, almond croissant, blueberry scone and chocolate bread. Everything was so delicious!! Our favorite was the almond croissant but I would get them all again and again! The service was really good too!
author: S C.

description: The quiche was probably the best I've ever had. Amazing savory and sweet breakfast options and the coffee is of great, organic quality. The only reason I'm giving it 4 stars is the service was hectic, disorganized and less than desirable.
author: Bradley V.

description:
The gougeres are delicious but the cream puffs were absolutely  outstanding.

The choux pastry has a nice texture and the filling is rich and very nice but the Thi g that put the puffs over the top was the drizzle of chocolate on the top (not enough to venture into eclair territory) with a sprinkling of crunchy sugar.

Lovely staff- cheery and helpful.
author: Tru N.

description: Ok so visiting San Francisco and stopped into this little Heaven on earth. Omg sooo good!! Best Almond Croissant I have EVER had. I took some pastries to my clients in Dublin and the too were raving how good it was. So good I brought my 13 year old foodie and she was drooling. I have one question. Can you please open a location in Santa Monica !!!
author: Bridgette J.

description:
This place is in my top 5 favorite cafes and bakeries.  
Pros:
* Great pastries, especially the almond croissant.
* Have sandwiches and savory foods
* Tea comes in a cup with a teapot of water
* Friendly happy workers
* Clean (tables, floors, bathroom, kitchen)
* Good lighting
* No fleas
* Close to lots of transportation
* It's in my part of the city
Cons:
* It closes early (7pm)
* They run out of almond croissants
* No wifi
author: Herschell L.

description: Quaint little bakery with stellar sweet and savory goods, including solid sandwiches for lunch option. Best part of the place is a little patio garden seating area in the back, which is great for reading or hanging for a little while. Prices reasonable, service very friendly, I'm a big fan.
author: Anuj S.

description:
To One Direction's "One Thing"

I've tried playing it cool
But when I'm looking at you
At those buzzing flies
Looks so gross on those pies

But then I averted my eyes
You're my kryptonite
You keep making me weak
Almond croissant you don't stink

Some things gotta give now
Cause you're dying just to make me eat
That almond croissant with me now
Cause you've got that one thing

So get out, get out, get out of my head
And fall into my arms instead
I don't, I don't, don't know what it is
Your almond croissant, a good thing
And you've got that one thing
author: Christopher Y.

description:
I have no idea how I haven't written about this place earlier. 

In a city of overpriced, booshie bakeries Thorough Bread is a refreshing breath of affordable, amazing goodness. 

Cheap, great baguettes is usually what I'm picking up. They come in  rustic sourdough, and sweet and both are tasty, crunchy and full of that marvelous bread-y flavor. Oh and they're like a $1.50 a pop. 

They sell smaller sandwich rolls for a dollar, and bigger, fancier rolls like Cranberry Walnut for $5. 

I love their bran muffins, cookies, cheesecake and croissants. 

If you are in SF and you are serious about your bread, head over here.
author: Alex M.

description:
Best scone in San Francisco (and I know my scones). Not too flaky, not too buttery, not too sweet, not too dense. 

Baristas are nice and unpretentious (a rarity these days). 

The café is spacious yet cozy. One can easily have an intimate conversation or tutoring session here. Not too noisy and not too quiet. 

Not overpriced. Which is also a rarity. 

No wifi, unfortunately, but that forces you not to park the whole day.
author: Julia D.

description:
mmmm...

Come here too often ; ) The mocha is divine, almond croissant is perfection, chouquettes are delicious. I love the atmosphere, its quiet and when the weather is nice the patio with a small group of girlfriends is my favorite go to place when we need to girl out and gossip over a tasty treat!

The baristas here are so friendly and make you feel like I'm not just another $$
author: Brittany B.

description:
Probably the best ham croissant ever - complete with beschamel sauce. And there is a nice shady patio out back.

Unfortunately service was just ok; dude who helped me needed help himself - first giving me change for $10 instead of the $20 I'd handed him and gave me an almond croissant instead of sticky bun. I had asked for my au lait in a mug but it came in paper cup.  Normally one of those things would be ok but all three occurring in one transaction left me feeling less than excited about coming back.
author: Aimee B.

description: Get the cheese and ham croissant! Mrrrr. And there's a cute little back patio to enjoy it in.
author: Heather R.

description:
I went there this morning around 10:30 and they were closed with no sign indicating they are closed.  I'm praying they didn't go out of business, please keep us posted.
Thanks,
Stu
author: Stu S.

description: Best almond croissant I've ever had. A frequent visitor to this cozy neighborhood spot. I haven't tried anything there that wasn't delicious!
author: Suzanne F.

description: Tried to listen to the reviews and got an almond croissant... good flavor but greasy as hell. The oil soaked through the wax bag and two paper napkins within 10 minutes.
author: Jessica W.

description:
My friend brought me here because he had to pick up some stuff at Crossroads on Market Street. 

I ordered the almond croissant and a mushroom puff pastry. Both of the baked goods were delicious! They have a variety of baked goods including different types of quiche.

I like the communal cafe atmosphere in here as well.
author: Betty C.

description: I love this place esp the back patio, perfect for the summer! They have a lot of pastries and bread.  Ordered chocolate caramel something and it's really good except the crust is kinda dry for me. They serve sightglass coffee and has a nice brick walls.
author: Jami F.

description: Lovely garden, tasty pastries, good coffee.
author: Mandy H.

description: Going down our 7x7 Big Eat list we needed to check out Thorough Bread and Pastry for their almond croissant.  It was really good and not too heavy which can sometimes happen.  It's cool that they also have a bakery school they hold here as everything looked amazing. We ordered a quiche and chocolate croissant for tomorrow morning too so I can't wait to have that as well.
author: Blake B.

description:
Delicious quiche and croissants. The scones are ok. 

Only 3 stars because the dining area isn't very clean. We tried the back patio, but it wasn't very pleasant because some guy was watering the plants, which was annoying. Why do they water the plants during business hours when people are trying to eat?! Yet another example of terrible service in San Francisco.
author: Jamon B.

description:
Quiche is awesome. Wish they would give a bigger slice.
Im in love with the chocolate chip cookies and they are only 75cent. Who can beat that. Evdrything is made frrsh in house as well. Ic you get there early everything is still warm..
author: Ayana K.

description: Awesome fresh baked croissant and other pastries .. The staffs are always friendly and fast .. The price is a bit higher than average bakery shops but you will like it ..
author: Tom V.

description:
I read about Thorough Bread & Pastry through a friend so I had to hurry to try it.  I'm trying to go to all the best bakeries so if I'm missing any please let me know.

It's a small bakery in the Castro on Church near 15th St.  I walked from Civic Center Bart and it's only about 20 min away, or take the Muni F-Line.

I like that it's Open on Sundays & Take Credit Cards - Major points for that.

I got:

Chocolate bread $2.5 - it's a small round brown bread with chocolate on the outside.  Wish there were more chocolates inside & out!

Sticky bun $2.5 - Really tasty, I love sweet & gooey nutty pastries so I recommend it!!

French Macarons - 1 for $1.25; 3 for $3.50 - I thought they were good, small bit chewy & creamy inside.  I got 3 & liked them all.

I got Pate de fruits - little boxes of fruit-flavored gelees. 6 in a pack for $3.50.  I liked them ok.

Total $12 & used my credit card.

There's a bunch of 2-top tables, but all filled when I got there.

Christmas Eve 7am-7pm
Christmas Day -Closed

Closed Mon; Tue-Sat 7 am - 7 pm; Sun 8 am - 5 pm
author: Ann L.

description: I come here very regular, since I am so happy with this place. Cannot give any specific recommendation- everything is delicious! Very reasonable prices and friendly staff, too.
author: Eirini P.

description:
SF is a city cluttered with good bread and bakeries, and this gem on Church holds it own. The prices are good--baguettes for $1, cookies for 75 cents--and the quality gives the likes of Acme and Tartine a run for their money. 

Yelpers and magazines have raved about the almond croissant and with good reason: it's incredible. It's buttery, flaky, light, and delicious. A must-try when in the neighbourhood.
author: Josh L.

description: Good food but very holier than though service... In response to "oh, is this the sixteen ounce?" The answer is... "It's for here. We don't do ounces." Interesting, as the menu three feet to the right gives ounce specifications for the mocha. I imagine more people than me may ask, since it's listed. Let down by the attitude even though this spot was recommended by the photo place around the corner.
author: Doug D.

description:
More flair than flavor.
Really nice location and atmosphere and a bit on the pricey side.
author: Orson F.

description: Love the place.  Love their food.  However they are OVERCOOKING most of their pastries and muffins....someone should look at quality these days.  It should be golden brown, light brown...not dark brown/black....The idiot behind the counter's response, "They're good on the inside."  I can think of other coffee shops that are "good on the inside!"
author: Eli B.

description:
this bakery /café is under the radar, when the spotlight is on other venues... the place is owned by a french baker ( Michel Suas) who has been in the business for a while.
The products are very good, special mention to croissant and pain au chocolat. The pastries are very good. The best for me is the bread, which in this coastal par of the country very hard to raise . The baguettes are consistent, crust is hard and the inside very well areated. It's propably the best bakery in the bay area by the quality of its products-
author: Boubékeur O.

description:
Holy Sweet Breads and Pastries!!! I was in love with first sight....so many different types of breads and sweet and salty pastries! Yet again my bf managed to find a wonderful bakery to satisfy my carb carvings.. since I've been on a no-carb diet for like 4 months..-_-"

We tried this interesting little ball puff pastry called grougers...4 for $1.50. Then we shared an amazingly savory Bread Pudding - filled with roasted red peppers, sausage and mozzarella cheese and Vol Au Vent - which is a puff pastry filled with mushrooms and cream. YUMMERS! I wish I could eat moreee! they have some really yummy looking desserts too. 

The cashiers were very friendly and nice. Really great place to enjoy a cup of coffee and pastries for breakfast!

Must Try!
author: Joanna L.

description: Hands down the best bakery in SF. Secluded outdoor patio, too. If you're unsure, just order the bread pudding (sweet OR savory!)
author: John G.

description:
Aww, San Fran, can we bring your spirit here to NYC?

I sat on the back patio and had a fantastic pumpkin muffin with a little crumbly stuff on top and a cream-cheesy surprise inside.  None of this Starbucks-muffin crap.  And I had a very strong and rich americano, though it was served in too big a mug...

All this for under 3 bucks.  Wowsers.
author: Mark H.

description:
It saddens me to write a poor review for this bakery.  I have seen the service deterioriate at this place. Employees are not as friendly as they were.  I came in to get latte. Guess what? Latte was little bit cold. I was shocked - $3 for that? I could have went the next door to CHurch Cafe and got a better latte. I asked the lady to give me a better late.  Few minutes later, I got the latte that is also cold. Hmm..

Turned out that this person who made the latte is a manager, and she was so rude and a nightmare.  She even does not know how to refund $ - she gave me the money back but did not remember to give me the tax money back.

I am disappointed.
author: vadim m.

description:
Terribly LOUD inside and out

Used to be a quiet little oasis, but have really cranked up the volume on their sound system.  The sweet little courtyard out back is now dominated by these whirring and clattering cooling units that get louder as the temperature gets warmer.  In other words, the more you want to sit outside, the more unpleasant it is.  The pastries are still great, but get them to go.
author: Jeff Y.

description:
D-E-L-I-C-I-O-U-S!!!  I normally am not a big chocolate fan (what a freak, right?) but this place made me a fan of it!

My friend brought some yummy chocolate balls of gooey goodness over for dinner one night and my mouth melted. It's THAT good.
author: Samantha D.

description:
Thorough Bread & Pastry is such a quaint little bakery and hangout. The pastries are real yummy and you can even watch some of the bakers making stuff right in the background. If you get there in the morning expect a crowd purchasing the yummy croissants, flaky breads and scrumptious cakes.  You can grab a coffee or a latte or nice cup of tea on your way out or to stay. They have enough tables to hang out for a quick bite or even to hang for a hour or two. There is an outdoor patio in the back for when it gets too crowded in the front of the house, although sometimes it does get chilly back there. 
If you go enough you can notice some regulars, some quirky, some nice... but all very harmless and it gives the place character. The employees are very sweet, very cute 20 -something girls..in all shades of hipster and cute furry boys who all smile and are attentive to your order. 
Many people don't realize they actually have a lunchy kind of menu as well, have several different types of sandwiches; turkey, mozzarella and tomato and a garden sandwich, which is my favorite, they come with a small salad and a smile! They also have soups, chips and canned drinks. 
It is a total fun place to go with a group, first date or your AA sponsor.... you can have a nice conversation and stuff your face with yummy desserts or you can pen that new novel you always wanted to... Just remember if you are going on a Monday you might be shocked to see the place closed. Yes sometimes people need a day off.... and why not? Oh wait... I need that pastry... not today girl.. hit the gym dear.. Thoroughbread will be open tomorrow.....
author: Jo Jo D.

description:
This place is one of the reasons why I fundamentally can't handle a true low-carb diet. Maybe I could do the "no carbs after 7 PM" rule, as long as I've had an almond croissant from Thorough Bread and Pastry. 

In fact, I came across this place because I was working with a French dude one summer. I asked if he'd been to Tartine yet, and he replied that he had, but that I should REALLY try Thorough Bread and Pastry. 

Thoughts: 
- The pastries are beautiful and tasty. My favorite is the rich almond croissant, filled with delicious marzipan filling. The pastries are crunchy and flaky, the sign of a well-made pastry. 
- They don't have wifi, because it's more of a cafe/lunch spot than a stay-all-day coffee shop. 
- The back patio is beautiful and is a wonderful place to sit with a book or a friend. 
- They have delicious fresh-baked bread in the afternoon, at very reasonable prices. I'll drop by here for a baguette for dinner, at the price of $1.50. That's lower than most grocery stores. 

The place loses a star because of the "blah" nature of their brewed coffee -- in a city full of individually-brewed cups of single-origin coffees, theirs is very mediocre. But the espresso drinks are better than decent, and that's what I usually order here.
author: Tom P.

description:
I was having lunch at Crepevine with my boyfriend. My grandpa just broke his back and lives alone so I thought I'd bring him some pastries and such. My boyfriend suggested the pastries/cakes at Crepevine and I went over to look at them. They all looked old and disgusting and the man at the counter was not very nice at all. I remembered this place being nearby because of the super cute name. Haha. 

We walked over and were amazed by the pretty little cakes! We didn't get any since we were stuffed and those cakes definitely would be better eaten at the bakery so we figured we'd just wait another time for them.

I bought my grandpa a regular croissant, a almond croissant, a lemon pound cake, and I think sweet cake? It was $9 for all four. They were able to break my $50 and my boyfriend thought I paid $41 for everything! Haha. He was like whoah what did you buy? He got the ham and cheese croissant and the little diamond cookie things even though I told him they looked horrible. 

Service was really nice and I wish we could've stayed and shared a cake or something because I would've loved to watch them make their magic in the open bakery. My grandpa said he had tons of baked goods already so I kept the sweet cake for myself. After reading these reviews, I wish I had kept the almond croissant, especially because I love almonds! Homph. Next time. 

The sweet cake was a lot like bread pudding which is my favorite! It was filled with nuts and fruit pieces. There was also a white frosting on top but it all stuck to the bag by the time I ate it. The diamond cookies were eaten on the way to the car and they were pretty good, like little shortbread cookies.
author: Tiffany V.

description: This place really satisfied my sugar cravings. If u like iced coffee then go to Starbucks. They don't even have ice here. I do love their hot coffee and pastries!
author: Marjorie U.

description:
SUPER cute little coffee/bake shop that's also super convenient for me because well, it's literally right around the corner from where I work out when I visit the 'rents in San Francisco.  

FOOD: Is good, although I've really only had sweet things here.  Between my friend Helen and I, we shared a slice of the apple gallette tart and the almond croissant.  I also bought a bran muffin to eat later.  Verdicts:  

Almond Croissant - YUMMY.  Definitely one of the best croissants I've EVER had.  This 1000 calorie buttery sucker was oozing with marzipan, which I am typically NOT a fan of, but when it's carmelized and crunchy on the top, and melty in the middle... with glazed roasted almond slices on top of it... yeah... don't bother me I'm foodgasming...

Bran Muffin - Ok, so this was kind of a guilt purchase for consuming the oh-so-unhealthy, but oh-I-would-totally-eat-it-again almond croissant.  However, guilt didn't taste so bad this time. Muffin was moist, not too sweet, and had golden raisins in it - which are SO much better than regular raisins. If only guilt could be this sweet every time...

Apple tart - maybe 3.5 stars, which was sad because it was the prettiest dessert we ate. It was too thin though and the puff pastry it was baked on was kind of tough, maybe because it was so thin.

AMBIENCE: This is one of the few places I've been to where the ambiance probably bested the food.  The inside of the bakery itself isn't much to write home about, but just keep going back and you'll enter a charming little patio outside.  Simply no better way and no better place to enjoy a gorgeous day in San Francisco (and DO treasure them because SF doesn't get many of them!) while having tea and pastries with one of your best friends. 

PRICES: Well... not cheap.  Not any more of a rip off than Starbucks either though, and between the two, I'd rather get tea here.  Helen and I paid about $15 for three pastries, a cup of tea and a cup of coffee. I'd pay $15 to enjoy that patio again.

PARKING: HA!  Parking in the Castro?  Not unless you have a death wish.  Highly advise taking the N or J lines instead and getting off at Duboce and Church.

Verdict - I must come back to try Thorough Bread's brunch!
author: Catherine C.

description:
coconut chocolate macaroon. 
maybe the best in north america.
author: Steve B.

description:
Nestled on a busy block in the Castro/Mission Dolores border, one could easily walk right by this spot without batting an eye.  On the recommendation of Paul K., this bakery was an automatic bookmarked destination.  When you arrive, don't just jump into the line as you'll find yourself stuttering, frazzled, or speechless when they ask for your order.  First, you start at the refrigerated case and select your sweets by process of elimination... do I need these calories?!  Then, you proceed to the small baked goods section which includes cookies, brownies, and coffee cakes.  Finally, before you reach the cash register, you'll see my favorite, the croissants.
On my most recent stop, my selections were:
a) Snickerdoodle - My favorite non-chocolate cookie.  Flavor was good and, as most cookies, great with that cold glass of milk.
b) Chocolate Chip Cookie - Pretty good, though I'm used to more of a thick doughy texture for cookies (ala Specialty's).  Their cookies are thin and chewy good.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MTIqLOBdISaon4G22qb5Lg?select=8BhxmA88sJuj694dmY3jug)
c) Almond Croissant - Heated one up for breakfast and, yes, it did not disappoint.  Buttery good on the outside with consistent almond paste flavor inside.  
d) Chocolate Croissant - Light and flaky with just enough chocolate inside.  Another MUST HEAT before eating pastry. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MTIqLOBdISaon4G22qb5Lg?select=tMtiJTIslVSVeu4jhAwL3A)
e) Chocolate Caramel Tart - Think of a gooey, delicious pie on a chocolate cookie crust.  I imagine this would be a great dessert with a cup of hot tea or coffee.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MTIqLOBdISaon4G22qb5Lg?select=67P3EE1ihetkYDoW3-sCwA)

Thanks again to Paul K (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=OhFEevRThMfm1MHzi7TfFg) for his review.  Otherwise, I would have never known about this gem of a bakery.
author: Mike C.

description: Yuuuuummmmm. I'm so happy just to get my almond croissant and coffee. This place is consistently the best!
author: Andrew S.

description: I went here with a friend on Sunday around 10am. There weren't too many spots to sit inside but we were actually much happier to sit in the back courtyard. There was a line but it moved quickly (5-10 min) and the pricing was reasonable. I only tried their espresso and chocolate mocha (???...the mocha thing was my friend's). I was surprised by how great the espresso was! It was strong in flavor but not bitter and felt creamy despite drinking it black. Definitely exceeded my expectations. The mocha was delicious as well. The foam was thick and there was a good balance between the coffee and chocolate. I look forward to returning!
author: Diana M.

description: Stayed at the Parker B&B....Thorough Bread and Pastry is in walking distance...EVERYTHING IS GREAT......sticky buns are amazing!!! The only issue is the line out the door hahaha BUT....that's a good thing......worth the wait.
author: Steve F.

description:
Thorough Bread: the best kept bakery secret in SF, or something along those lines.

I've gone to Tartine and waited in line. I've gotten the almond croissant, morning bun, and a croque madame (or something similar to that) there. I've always regretted not going to Thorough Bread instead - the stuff at Tartine always seems to be slightly burnt, and not worth the long wait. (I haven't gotten the bread pudding yet, but maybe one of these days I'll wait out that line to see if it's worth it...)

TB is not that far from the Mission/Dolores Park, has never had a real line the way Tartine does, and their pastries are *awesome*. Like, not burnt, taste great, and reasonably priced. My favorites have been the almond croissant, their potato bacon turnover, the sweet potato pastry thing, and most recently, the goat cheese caramelized onion turnover. (I think maybe the goat cheese caramelized onion turnover replaced the potato bacon? Haven't seen that in a while...) I've also had their bacon scones, ham & cheese croissant, savory bread pudding, one of the fruit tarts, some other stuff, and they're all pretty darn tasty. Try to get your stuff toasted, even if you need to run off.

Oh, and they recently started doing sandwiches! The sandwiches themselves are great, though the side salads are a bit wimpy... not enough to kill a star, though.

They also do cakes and baguettes. I've never had those (except baguette on TB sandwich), but I bet they're great.

Highest recommendations for TB, though maybe the line at Tartine is better off where it is so I never have to wait here :P
author: Chris M.

description: This is a pretty good bakery. I enjoyed the rustic fruit tart and the raisin snail and a few other treats. Once I ordered the cheesecake and it was soft, creamy and delicious. Wanting a repeat experience, I tried it two other times afterwards and both times it was dry and leathery on the outside and kind of gummy on the inside. Tasting unfresh. This is not a cheap item I should say, almost six bucks. Finally, I mentioned it ( I thought gently) to a counter clerk who was fairly rude, didn't offer to trade it out and just said "She made it today." and stared indifferently until I went away. But, as I said the other items are good and taste fresh. I love the garden area out back which is a great place nice to read and chillax.
author: Bryan H.

description:
5 Stars for their authentic French pastry.  The almond croissant is amazing here... possibly the most "French" in the Bay Area.  At 2.50 it's quite reasonable as well.  

Other oustanding items:

- Roast chicken sandwich - One of my favorite sandwiches in the city.  Rich but not over powering. French style, so not over filled with meat and great bread texture.  It's a slice of Paris. 
 
- Cranberry walnut &  multi-grain bread - excellent texture, similar to breads found in higher-end restaurants.  I get a loaf occasionally for breakfast.

-Chouquettes - Like cream puffs, but with no cream inside. coated with a sprinkle of coarse sugar.  Again, texture is nice and just the right amount of sweetness.  Very authentically French.

-Almond pastry (forgot the exact name here) but it's excellent.

IMO, this is one of the best pastry shops and possibly the most "French" in the Bay Area!
author: Paul K.

description:
The fresh pastries and treats are to die for! A bit pricey by bakery standards but worth each penny.

The service has always been terrible but the quality treats make up for it.
author: Casey M.

description: A hidden gem in SF! The almond croissant has become a constant craving since I first devoured it. There's a beautiful patio at the back of the cafe for some quiet reading and writing.
author: Vivien S.

description: You've never had a cream puff until you've had a Thorough Bread cream puff! They're perfectly cold and creamy in the center. It's not really something that can be described in words. Once you try one, you'll see what I mean! They also make really good lattes. The only downside of this place is that I always want three cream puffs and a latte on Mondays... When they're closed! :)
author: Christine M.

description: I live around the corner from this place and it is my favorite bakery/cafe in the neighborhood. Great place to catch up with friends or do some reading. Pastries are delicious and the chocolate bread is my kryptonite
author: Sophie S.

description: Wow the cream puffs were very delicious and inside it is so cute and with an adorable backyard patio area. Definitely recommend
author: Francisca C.

description: Thanks you, fabulous barista who's name i do not know, for making incredible almond milk foam AND for your exceptional thoughtfulness & generosity. This place rocks b/c of people like you! :-)
author: Danielle W.

description:
Plenty of seats in this place and there are even more outdoors in the back. I simply just shared an almond croissant. I can't remember the actual price, but it was about $2~$3. Definitely worth the price and it's actually a pretty large size! Crispy and flaky outer layer with a very moist inside. Simply just stopped at this place after lunch in the area for a something extra since I wasn't completely full and it was a great decision just entering this place. Thoroughly enjoyed my time here. I'd definitely try out the many, many different pastries they have. They all looked incredible!

I highly recommend trying this place out for some delicious pastries!
author: Kevin T.

description: Food is good. My boyfriend got the savory bread pudding but I didn't care for it (I think I'm just used to sweet bread pudding -- it wasn't bad).  Almond croissant was excellent.  I'd suggest heading out to the patio for some solace unless you want to hear hip hop blaring at 8:30am.   In other words the atmosphere wasn't really too "coffee shop."
author: JC W.

description:
Tried the highly raved about almond croissant here. I think this place is fairly dedicated to making good pastries, yet I still think the croissant is not comparable to Tartine's croissant. Also, it would have been better if it had been just out of the oven. 

The ambience is nice, though a bit small with a couple of tables and back patio tables.
author: Joyce B.

description:
It was a rainy morning when my boyfriend and I were looking for a place to have breakfast.  We stumbled upon this place not knowing anything about it.  We both loved it.
I had the ham and cheese croissant.  I have never loved a croissant before.  It was really fresh and warm and delightfully cheesy.
I've tried a couple desserts from here and they're also quite tasty.
The atmosphere and service were very welcoming.  It is a bit small, and it was crowded when we came in.
I've been dying to come back here with a couple of my friends.
author: Audrey D.

description:
I come here all the time.
Great patio in the back.
The service is always excellent.
The croissants, baguettes, cookies, cakes oh my! Everything is very good, especially the blueberry-bran muffin (best one I've ever had--not too sweet) and the ham & cheeze croissant. Soups and sandwiches are also very nice .
This is a patisserie that offers all the classics, they are not reinventing the wheel, and it's all very well made. 
Also, no crazy lines!
Best of all? Very FAIR prices. Coffee+croissant+jam: 3,65$. That's an excellent price considering the quality and the neighborhood.
So much more worth it than Tartine or craftsman & wolves, IMO.
Go there!
author: Eli E.

description: Staff is not particularly courteous. Pastries are only so-so. No wifi and electrical outlets don't work.
author: Rebecca L.

description: Such a cute bakery! The decor is quaint and you can come here and study. I got the mini macaroons due to how cute they looked and they were quite tasty!
author: Emily C.

description: I think I love the ambience of Thorough Bread the most. Of course the pastries and quiches and coffee are delicious, but the exposed brick and quaint outdoor patio in the back really make this place special. Note: they do not do iced coffee beverages.
author: Jess W.

description:
This is my first review in forever, but I just had to write one about this place.  This place is heaven to my pastry lovin' self.  I had to hold myself back from purchasing the entire shop!  No wonder my friend had been dying to take me here for so long.
We had the ham and cheese croissant which is similar to a croque monsieur, but uber FLAKY. The bechamel and the breadcrumbs on top make it superextrafantastic.  We also bought a sticky bun, coffee cake and a baba au rhum.  They were all very good but the baba was moist, more than adequately soaked with syrup, and had a tender crumb.  It's not easy to do that, and to keep it in your pastry case without it suffering over time.
I also love that it has an affiliation with SFBI and is run by many of the schools interns.  
You can bet that I will return...I think that it just might be better than Tartine.  gasp!
author: Suzanne L.

description:
Thorough B&P has the BEST Almond Croissants in the Bay Area, no doubt about it! 

Pure paradise for your taste buds:
Freshly sliced almonds and powdered sugar dusted on top of the beautiful golden brown, buttery crust... crisp, flaky sheets of heaven leading to a sweet and delicate marzipan bursting with flavor... it scream ALMONDS, ALMONDS, ALMONDS! *Foodgasm* Perfection. It's so good, I can't even write in full sentences.

Their other baked goods are great as well. Among the ones I've tried include the bostock (heavenly), gougeres,financiers, choquettes, and macarons. I've yet to devour their sticky buns, but I'm quite confident they'll be good.

Minus one star for the extremely bitter brewed coffee, but add a pinch of salt and you're good to go. On the other hand, their lattes and other espresso drinks are superb. Always go for the latter.
author: Colleen W.

description: Still going strong more than two years later, and coming back from Paris I realized again just how fortunate we are to have Michel and the team in our city. It's the consistency and dedication to quality here that really stands out. The croissant are perfection, purple wheat baguette one of the best in the city, and rotating items such as the rosemary asiago walnut scone my personal favorite.
author: Paul G.

description: I have never eaten an Almond Croissant this good.  As far as I know, no one makes it like this!! I can't pinpoint the topping but it's so delicious that my sister and I picked up every crumb...yes, I know that I wrote another review for this place but I felt motivated to write another.  We drove up on a Monday and the place was closed....so we will drive back up to the city next week.  Um...I'm salivating just thinking about it!
author: P C.

description:
I love this place. It's my favorite bakery right now. I used to come here every day.

I can't anymore, of course, because that made me fat and now I am dieting :) It is easy to get fat coming here. First of all, their baked goods are fantastic. And they do innovative things too, like the tiny savory cream puffs I got last Sunday. I don't remember the exact name (something with a "G"), but they were your recognizable cream puffs: hollow and eggy with tons of butter and bits of fresh herb baked into them. There is a steady menu of reliable yum-ness (almond croissants, scones, bread, cookies..) in addition to occasional innovations. Second of all, because this is a "teaching shop" (basically an internship for culinary students) they can afford to sell their excellent food very cheaply. Large cookies that typically run $1-$2 are only 75 cents at this shop. Baguettes are $1.50, a ham & cheese croissant is $2.75, etc.

The space is nice too. There is a patio in the back.
author: Amy T.

description:
I adore the breads here.  Each variety is delicious and well made, great structure and flavor.  Very nice sandwiches, too.
The pastries are also varied and range from simple cookies and biscuits to amazing fruit tarts and complicated cakes.  The staff is efficient, the coffee delicious. Always, for several years, it has been terrific.  I go back almost weekly, I recommend it to neighbors and friends visiting.  Truly a gem.

(Pssst:  The soups are terrible.)
author: Darryl C.

description:
I can't say enough good things about this bakery!!

It's adorable, they always have the cutest window displays (go by at Christmas time and you'll see the coolest bread Christmas tree!), their back patio is a quiet oasis in the middle of the City, and the food....the FOOOOD!

I haven't tried everything...yet :)  But I'm on my way!  
Some of my favorites:  the sandwiches, Apple Galette, mini cheesecakes with the fruit on top, the Sesame Semolinas, Challah bread, the Rustic Tart was a HUGE hit at a party I took it to, they don't charge a cork fee the last time I checked, the eclairs are amazing and the staff is so nice even when it's busy.

Seriously my favorite bakery in the City! If you haven't been..do yourself a favor and go. I promise you won't be disappointed!
author: Elena P.

description: I've tried almost all the pastries here and have been ridiculously happy with every single one, though I have a soft spot for the bacon scone and the almond croissant.  The tiny little dessert cakes are perfect for a special occasion (or, you know, a Tuesday).  The tucked-away back patio is a beautiful and peaceful place to while away the morning with coffee, pastries and the newspaper.  Bliss!
author: Erin L.

description:
I love this place. Finally a pastry & bakery shop that is authentic and has great service too! Edgy & traditional merge effortlessly as you watch everyone behind the counter work as a team. I like the light & open view of the kitchen so you see where all that goodness comes from. Pleasant & smiling staff greet you at an early hour until they close. 

Like everyone else, I feel the almond croissant here is more than addictive. Its heavenly!!
author: Kai N.

description:
Want a sandwich?  Maybe you just need a pastry, a cup of coffee and a quiet secluded patio in the city to escape to?  Thorough Bread & Pastry is your place to go.  

Whenever I eat here I get the same thing, turkey sandwich on the semolina sesame roll.  The roll is so delicious I cannot resist.  They also spread a chipotle mayonnaise on it as well that is very tasty.  The staff is also always very friendly and willing to accommodate my request for extra meat.  The dressing for the salad is a wonderful tangy vinaigrette, and they don't drench the lettuce either.  

The patio is a wonderful place to retreat with your lunch or coffee.  Bring a book or some playing cards and enjoy the seclusion while being in the middle of the city.
author: Adam P.

description:
I LOVE this place! Just happened to discover Thorough Bread & Pastry last week, and what a find!! I've had the following so far (yes, all in the past week) and haven't been disappointed by any of them, which says a lot...almond croissant, ham and cheese croissant, choquettes, gougeres, pumpkin cream cheese muffin and the mini macaroons. 

I'm a sucker for almond croissants and they are absolutely delicious here. ...and for me, the almond croissant at a bakery is like the Pad Thai at a Thai restaurant...if they can't get it right, I'm very skeptical. Another favorite so far has been the pumpkin cream cheese muffin...so flavorful, light and fluffy! Had this next to a pumpkin muffin from Arizmendi (much denser and way too sweet) and there was absolutely NO comparison! I can never pass up trying a new macaroon either, especially ones so small and adorable. They were tasty, but to be honest, I couldn't pinpoint the flavor and thought they were just a tad on the sweet side...but since they're minis, I didn't seem to mind as much as usual. 

The back patio is also a plus...it's nice and spacious, but got a little chilly and I had to move inside after a little while. I can't wait to go back and try more, especially the sandwiches which I hear are super delicious. My only complaints are that they don't have heat lamps or wifi, but that might be the only thing keeping me from camping out there all day and gaining 20 lbs. Hopefully I'll only gain 5 instead.
author: Kristen C.

description:
Tartine? More like Fart-ine. 

For so long I'd passed by this place without peeking inside. One day I finally did and my head fell off my neck stick. Everything in here smells like heaven just shook out its dusty rug. Everything looks like a beautiful, buttered sculpture that's freshly been plucked from the oven and shoved in front of your eye holes. Everything tastes like it was made special for you by an entire swarm of French grandmas with family recipes. 

To be fair, I haven't eaten many things here. But what I have eaten I've completely enjoyed. The always-fresh blueberry bran muffin gushes with juicy blueberries (but not too much so) and is tempered with delicious bran that makes me drop it like it's hot. Their macaroons make me thankful for being born. I vow to try every cake dessert they offer, because each one looks like a discotheque of sugar and sweets with prices so low I trip over them as I dance to the next display case. 

The reason I give five stars? Because as I type this I'm "chewing the muffin" (if you know what I mean). And because, unlike most places in San Francisco worth their weight in saliva, there is never a line. It's generally busy, mind you, but what these guys get right in pastry deliciousness, they get even more right in service and realizing that you don't need an incredibly annoying line to attract people to your business. Each time I've been here they've had at least 3 cashiers helping the line along in an incredibly friendly and helpful manner - as if you are all together one and the same - united by the delicious snacks surrounding. This efficiency gets you in and out in under 5 minutes, with your delicious muffin sack tucked safely at your side. No line: a San Francisco miracle. You have the rest of the day to complete life goals! Like drinking the ocean, wondering if North Korea is real, and finally calling things off with your doctor who thinks "you're a really neat girl". While this does wonders for your day off, it may be a nightmare for your social life. Who really wants to spend time with friends unless you're both standing in a 30 minute line for a pastry? Not me, and that's why I have none of either.
author: Aaron C.

description: My experience here was great. The food was amazing, and the service was impeccable. This place and their chefs were genuinely curious on how their food tasted and you could tell that they would implement feedback if their food weren't up to par. They were so happy that we were enjoying our food and the atmosphere was very welcoming. You can tell that this place cared about their customers and their dining experience and I would definitely be coming back here again.
author: Lucille L.

description:
I've been here twice now and will definitely be coming back for more. Everything I've tried is delicious. Their almond croissants, as everyone else has noted, are amazing. Flaky on the outside and soft and sweet on the inside. 

I also tried a pine nut tart and a berry coffee cake and they were great. Coffee cake has a tendency to become very dry, but Thourough Bread's is soft and moist.

The chai is yummy as well; it complements an almond croissant nicely. 

The icing on the cake, so to speak, is that everything is very reasonably priced. 

I'm hooked!
author: Emily B.

description: Simply one of the best bakeries I've been to - ever! The almond croissant is melt-in-your-mouth ahhmazing! The olive bread is perfection:)
author: Brooke C.

description:
Lovely--  such a cute, little, quaint bakery/restaurant.  My niece & her boyfriend are regulars here.  This review is based on their daily experiences & my one experience there.  When I went, I had a custom-made turkey sandwich on sourdough.  I wish I had tried the baguette instead, although the sourdough was pretty good.  I especially loved the spicy dijon mustard.  More, please!  My sandwich had turkey, basil, tomato, dijon, & caramelized onions.  The onions needed more flavor & I wish the sandwich was more packed.  

I tried the carrot cake as well.  That was pretty awesome, although I wish the cream cheese was creamier.  It is marzipanish, in a way.  It was still delicious, though.  We were a large group & they were especially accommodating.  Everyone enjoyed their meals, which included a variety of breads, croissants, coffee, & cappuccinos.  My niece's boyfriend swears by their chocolate bread, which he adds nutella to.  My niece buys a baguette every day.  They are both thin as hell, so I don't know... maybe there's something to the faddish "French Diet."  hmmm.
author: Yelper Y.

description: This place is great.  I've had breakfast pastries, coffee, and now a pulled pork sandwich which was huge and awesome (a bit sweet maybe).  Coffee is from Sight Glass if I remember correctly.
author: Lynn S.

description: Decent pastries and lattes. Good little place to go when you're in this neighborhood. Cute garden area in the back too!
author: Josie C.

description:
I wan't even in town for a week before my friend Ivana said I needed to have an almond croissant. I asked her what it was, or batter yet (hee hee), why I even needed one and she said I didn't know because I never had one. 

Fair enough. 

She was right. 

The slightly sweet, yet mild and buttery croissant I slowly ate, no, savored into nonexistence was washed down by a nice expresso with honey as I sat there with the stupidest grin on my face. This place is freaking dangerous. As if it weren't enough that I now crave these stupid, delicious morsels of almond happiness (choo choo, next stop my thighs!), the girls who work here are so cute that I always get tongue tied and end up blabbering nonsense while just standing there. 

"I, um, do you...is there...how...water?"

"You're standing right next to the pitcher"

"Oh, HAH, hah, heh, um, thanks"

 The lowered tables make it really easy to chill and have a warm conversation, very opposed to some of the cold, white, tall table atmospheres of some places. This is now my new meet-up midday spot. Come here and unwind.
author: Manny S.

description:
