Some great bread and pastries, quick yet friendly service, and a neighborhood ambiance. 

The country bread has magnificent crust and texture if you need something with dinner or *as* dinner. The sticky bun is fantastic if it's a treat you're more in the mood for.

Coffee drinks are well-made and unpretentious. And a large is pretty big.
author: Mark R.

description: Lovely ham and cheese baguette sandwich complete with authentic cornichons, butter, and mustard. It's a great deal that comes with a generous side salad.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
unfortunately their service is the worst you can experience in the bay area. I used to always call in the morning make my orders, so I don't come there and find out they have nothing left. They also made the charge over the phone - so there was no risk of no pick up. This morning when I called to make my order - middle into taking my order the lady on the other side announced they don't take phone orders anymore. 

REALLY???

YOU DON'T???

You just changed the policy in the middle of my order after I used to do it every week?
author: Too M.

description:
I ordered 80 cookies for a family reunion because they have the best cookies, that I have found in SF, and then I shipped them to Southern CA. I ordered Chocolate Chip, Sugar, Oatmeal Rasin, Ginger Molassis. They were more than willing to accept my order, gave me a call to check in, and figure out the logistics. 
When I arrived for pick up, they were completed, and prepacked neatly. I checked the boxes to see if I missed anything, and everything was there. They were all uniform, and fresh. Maybe I'll order 160 next time.
author: Nathan M.

description:
Very good space, exceptional service, and above average pastries. Worth the visit if you're local, but I wouldn't go out of my way to visit, even for the almond croissant.

The pros:
Prices are awesome
Great service
Good almond croissant

Cons:
Sticky bun was a little dry
Those 4/$2 puff balls had great texture, but could use more flavor
author: C S.

description:
For me, nothing is more evocative than a spread of spectacular pastries.  I suppose it's akin to a pair of breathy ladies gazing at diamonds while passing a Tiffany and Co... Except diamonds taste like glass.

Their almond croissant demands a plate, fork, knife, and a generous bib, the cape you don at a hair salon would work too (it's that assertive).  It's flaky, but not the least bit greasy.  Oh so light, but has enough chew towards the center.  The almond paste shell is smooth, mild, and delicate with almond slivers that graze on top.  THIS IS IT!  The coffee served in-store comes piping hot in saucer-sized mugs which I adore.   

If you see the delicate profiteroles (aka mini cream puffs) with chantily cream BUY AT LEAST 4, hell, a dozen.  Their dessert case alone is like an art gallery.  Yes, gaze at it, and sigh heavily like a Southern Belle.  The French own patisseries, and dammit, they know it too.  

The sandwiches on their flawless baguette is ridiculously simple and delicious.  No sloppy globs of mayo, or excess cold cuts, European style.  Skip the soup, I agree with S.M., you're there for items that contain butter and flour.
author: Mai O.

description: Yummy. Period. Skip the line at the bakery that shall not be mentioned and come here for yummier treats without any hassle or crazy line!!
author: Meri S.

description: The food is very good for the price. I really enjoyed the roasted chicken sandwich. My friend claimed the toughness of the baguette was not ideal for his tuna sandwich though. Another friend hated her salad but she doesn't even like raisins so I don't know if I trust her opinion.
author: Derek S.

description:
I wasn't all that amazed by the almond croissant.. It was certain buttery, the cookie type crust on the outside was pretty gd, almond paste was lacking some sweetness though. I couldn't really taste much almond in the paste either.

Bostock ($2.50)  was kind of dry. Perhaps it would go well with milk. Guess I should've stuck with Tartine! Oh well..
author: Clarissa L.

description: I liked this place enough. They didn't have the castro cookie that I saw on this website, only do that for special occasions. They also don't have any power outlets for laptops. Kind of annoying in 2014. My friend asked the cashier if she could charge her phone behind the counter. A little weird. However, the pastries we ordered were spectacular.
author: Stefanie S.

description: Baguettes are fantastic, great warm sandwiches on fresh bread. Pulled pork sandwich is really good. But coffee isn't so good.
author: Elena G.

description:
Found a space outside but have no coins for meter!  Went in to get change and were captured by all the tasty treats.  

We ended up with the financier - $1.95 - lighter and less dense than a pound cake with nice flavors of almond and a bit of honey.   With it, a decaf Americano.

The young lady behind the counter was very friendly.

Will have to return to try other treats.
author: Gloria H.

description:
This place was down the street from my place, so I decided to try it out since I also walk past it whenever I need to catch the muni. The windows usually have cool looking bread in it which is eye catching. Everything is baked on premises, making the shop smell great. The girls seemed nice and I received my order quickly. 

I bought the sticky bun and a cup of coffee. The sticky bun is exactly that. The caramel was so sticky that the knife and fork would have some stuck to it. The dough pretty much tasted like cinnamon raisin bread with caramel on top. It was a little dry for my taste, and super sweet. I could barely eat half of it, and its not a very big sticky bun. The coffee was not very good. It was in a huge coffee mug, but it tasted like water with a bit of coffee in it. 

My search continues for a great bakery. Next I need to try Tartine.
author: Dorothy T.

description:
Love this little oasis of deliciousness, conveniently located at Church and Market. A delightful outdoor patio in the back, and fun and friendly staff. Thanks again to Babette for always being very gracious.

Every time I go there I find something new and delicious to eat and get to enjoy it with a big mug of coffee. 

It's also our go-to place when we need something rich and delicious to take to work or to a special occasion.
author: Dirk W.

description:
Don't buy the delicious, chewy chocolate bread here, unless you want to devour an entire loaf in an hour (which I did). For just $2.50, don't do it.

Don't buy the cheesy, airy gougeres either. Unless you want to stuff your face with eight of them in matter of 30 seconds.

Or the amazing wheat chocolate chip cookies...

Don't do it, I say. Unless you want to gain 10lbs.
author: Kel S.

description: I am a huge croissant lovers, before I found this store, I thought Tartine is the best, but the almond croissant is my favorite now. Texture is not too loose but also not firm enough to make you feel fool.
author: Sunny J.

description:
and throw in another couple of stars, simply because Thorough Bread & Pastry is a shinning star for those of us who love bread and all baked goods!

Purple Wheat bread is the best Bread in SF.  Tartine's bread ties, but then you can't get T bread whenever you want it. In fact, you can't get it unless you know three, that's right three  days ahead that you are going to have a "Bread Attack!" 

Almond Croissant IS the BEST in San Francisco! 

Sticky Bun - The Same!
Excellent Baguette and Sour dough bread!

My first visit, so you will have to wait for the cake and pastry review. How do I already know what that is going to be like?!!

 I feel like I am about to unleash the ten Plagues of Egypt. I know, so dramatic. Yet, here I am about to write the review that I never thought would be possible. 

First, I am a breadie, a sub set of the foodie (I'm all that too!) and there is, was, only one bread God in San Francisco. I was, for a long time, more than willing to put up with the inconvenience of serving the God of Bread, in order to have him/her provide me with that particular slice of heaven on those occasions that I needed my fix. And yes, a "fix" it was. There were pretenders to the throne, some of which were within a crumb's width of matching the God, yet none could quite get there. Outerlands, comes so close, their bread is outstanding!

Now that is no longer true. Thorough Bread & Pastry has succeeded in creating a bread just as good as... sit down, ...Tartine's. 

Don't go all Al Bundy on me, if your Great provider has been overthrown, it is, after all, the way of the world. But wait you exclaim, "You said that the bread was just as good, not better!"

Yes, and thereby lies the tale. For those who truly love food, there is this (sometimes unspoken) relationship with those who create the food we delight in. For some, it is what we live for. Part of this relationship is the mutual respect that unfolds between the maker and the consumer of extraordinary products. In many cases this mutual respect revels itself when the artist who creates, thrives in knowing how well his creation is received. This is why, so many times, the ubiquitous Hole in the Wall place is so revered. The connection is intimate, and ultimately REAL!

Thorough Bread and Pastry succeeds fully, while Tartine, well made bread not withstanding, fails.

 Respect for the customer, understanding that while none of us who revel in what is made would ever, for a moment have any qualms over the producers of what we love so much, making a financial profit. It isn't ever about the cost of the product, it is always about having a mutual connection, and sadly, Tartine  believes it is a one way street.

 Thorough Bread and Pastry walks the walk. Their products are just as good and as noted in some areas exceed T. They also respect their customers in providing the products that they do so well, not as peasants who get whatever happens to be thrown their way.

Of course what I fear most is adding to the numbers of people who will descend upon Thorough bread and Pastry when they read the reviews, but then, as they live up to their side of the bargain, then so must I.

So, if you are a foodie or better yet a breadie, then you must go to Thorough Bread and Pastry and try the recommended items, although once inside you will almost see delights that match your own preferences and try those instead (too?). You won't go wrong no matter what you decide to try.

You will get a big smile from the cashier (another plus for TBAP they have an efficient system that helps move the line, not an outdated someone takes order another cashes you out - slower and too many times one gets another person's order)

Best of all, you don't have to call three days ahead - the ultimate slap in the face for those who truly love T bread -you can when you feel like having a really good bread, just go there and get it. For those who need to get it hot out of the oven, their Purple Wheat bread comes out by 11:30
.
The cherry on top? The parking is better at Thorough Bread and Pastry. Baby cakes T, I know I hurt you with that, but then you deserve it. You broke the social contract - you believe that you don't need us. Worse, you could care less.
author: robert g.

description: Indoor , outdoor and sidewalk.  Oh and the food this place has it all!   Friday morning at 10am an 25 patrons, good sign and most seem to be locals another good sign,  must be packed on the weekend
author: W S.

description:
Wasn't all that impressed...  

The chocolate croissant was just standard...  What I'd expect in an airport... The quiche was meh... Couldn't even finish the ham and cheese croissant...  It was pretty nasty, and less than luke warm after being reheated...  They charge for refills on house coffee... Even though it's only 50 cents or something... Just kind of a hassle...

Whoever says that this place is better than Tartine is smoking crack...  Seriously... 

You can get SIGNIFICANTLY better croissants, chocolate croissants, ham and cheese croissants at Tartine, better coffee and free refills... Albeit having to hunt for a table, and wait in a 10 minute line...

The only advantages that this place has over Tartine, is... No line, plenty of seating, and a beautiful outdoor patio out back where they kindly allow dogs...

But there's a reason that Tartine always has a line that goes 10 people out the door, pretty much every hour of every day...  

It's head and shoulders above this place.
author: Will W.

description: As a regular customer, and I do mean regular (as spending $45 on the Buche Noel) I would have liked to have been treated with courtesy today, January 13. When I asked for an item on the end I reached over to point to the item  never intending to touch the food and I did not. I was sharply told by the clerk, " I will have to ask you not to touch anything".  I believe the young person needed to at least have some humor in her request or show some finesse of which she had neither. She needs to learn how to talk to people in a way that does not discourage them from returning to the bakery. Speaking of that I will not return to this bakery.
author: Fern F.

description: Like another reviewer said, I can't say enough good things about this bakery! Staff are so friendly (even the bakers say "thank you" to me and wish me a good day on my way out). Pastries are soooo good. Croissants are never soggy, always flaky and the chocolate ones actually have a lot of chocolate in them. The espresso drinks are excellent and they give you a discount for bringing your own cup! If you're not in the mood for sweets, their soups are yummy too. Very reasonable prices on everything.
author: Maryam M.

description: Mmmmm pumpkin cream cheese muffin with pumpkin seeds in the crispy top.  So amazing.  This was a great place for a quick break from errands.  The price was really reasonable for the muffin ($1.95) considering they are made daily and taste perfectly fresh.  I think that's about what you'd pay at Starbucks for a muffin that tastes like cardboard compared to this one!  I will make up an excuse to come back next time I'm anywhere nearby!
author: Caroline K.

description:
I love this place!  

My friend bought some pastries for me to try and everything was so good. 

Almond croissant - I am not a fan of croissant but this one was so good.  Nice texture.  It was crispy and flaky with the perfect amount of sweetness.  Very buttery outside with almond paste flavor inside.   No wonder so many people love their croissants! 

Chocolate chip cookie - When I have cookie, I hardly get chocolate chip because it always too sweet.  But the chocolate chip cookie here was perfect.  The cookie was thin but chewy.  The amount of chocolate chip was perfect too.  

Brownie - I love brownie but it is hard to find a good brownie because most of time it was too sweet (unless you bake it yourself).  But the brownie here was amazing.  Chewy, rich but not too sweet.  The size was kinda small thou.

I am ready to go back now!
author: Liza T.

description: Nice croissants and pastry, great service, really good coffee (and for the price, one cup is more like a bowl!). They even have a back patio. No wifi, but that can be good or bad, depending on what you need.
author: Sam Z.

description:
Warning: Will elicit fond memories of the European countryside. kidding, i've never been to Europe. 

But really, this is everything I've ever wanted in a cafe. It is bright, clean, and so so delicious.

I took note of the nice, french lady's accent, and decided to order a french macaroon.
Best decision ever. It was perfect-- light and fluffy on the outside, chewy on the inside. 

If I wasn't a college students and dirt poor, I would have attempted to eat this entire bakery. cute little patio included.
author: Leslie L.

description:
On our way to Church Street Cafe, my friend and I couldn't resist stopping in for some baked goods (this is after lunch and before going to a cafe for coffee).  We went a little nuts.  Items ordered:

1.  almond croissant
2.  fruit tart
3.  macarons
4.  forget what its called but sort of like brick toast

We were severely disappointed.  Everything looked so pretty on the display but the macarons - honestly the worst macarons I've ever tried.  The fruit tart was not to my liking.  My friend liked the brick toast thing and I thought the almond croissant was alright but seriously those macarons.  I can't even talk about it.
author: Christine B.

description:
I love to bake and I love to eat pastries, but I hate waiting in endless lines and eating shoulder-to-shoulder with a billion people before dashing off to make room for the next person in line. That's why I love this place.

It's conveniently located to people who live in the area and easily accessible by lots of public transportation. You can usually walk right up to the counter (your mileage may vary on Saturday and Sunday mornings) and order right away and they're rarely out of things even into the afternoon. The quiche is good, the savory bread pudding is delicious, but the almond croissants are the best. Their regular croissants and pains au chocolat certainly hold their own against any bakery.

The interior is quaint with little tables and exposed brick with local art on the walls (maybe every place in SF has this last feature). The prices are very reasonable, the drip coffee is fresh and excellent. All around, this is my go-to place for snacks, a light lunch, or pastries.
author: Athame E.

description:
I discovered this sweet neighborhood spot while in grad school when it wasn't uncommon for me to post up in a public space for hours on end. I've spent countless afternoons here with classmates and the staff has always been warm and welcoming for the entirety of our work sessions. 
 
The chocolate bread is ahhhh-maze-ingggg! It's definitely bread, not cake, and it's definitely chocolatey. The roasted chicken sandwich is dripping in delicious pine nuts. The blueberry bran muffin is clearly a favorite for not just me seeing how that one tends to go fast in the mornings.

There is a spacious back patio that is perfect for enjoying your treats & chit chatting with friends. It doesn't get much direct sunlight so bring an extra layer if you want to sit outside.
author: Melissa H.

description:
So first of all, I just want to set the record straight.  Tartine has amazing croissants that are out of this world.  The best in the City.  What I said earlier was just a fit of post brunch elation.  Just tryin to keep my Yelp street cred robust. 

However, Thorough Bread is still 5-Stars. Their baguettes are still awesome, I am still looking for better ones in the city or in CA for that matter. 

Some of the other stuff is amazing, it makes me feel like the luckiest guy in the whole wide world to have this a couple blocks from my joint. Stopping by just to pick up an Epi or an Olive shield thingy is my MO. 

Brunch here is amazing too, they have a really nice backyard outdoor seating area.  Something that most other bakeries don't have.  And one of the most amazing things is they never have lines here, which I still find incredible to this day.  More for me less for someone who can't find parking around here I guess.
author: Beef E.

description: BEST Croissants in the city!!! BEST Breads in the city!!! and now they have Bagels!!! Wonderful coffee and les magnifique patisserie ..... ooo-la-la
author: FogCity D.

description:
One of the best pastry shops in San Francisco! It's a walking distance from my house so I tend to visit this place whenever I can.

Their croissants are the best. It's really hard to choose between plain, chocolate, almond and ham & cheese. They're all buttery and delicious. My other favorites are sweet potato pie and choquettes (small cream puffs). 

For desserts, their carrot cake and bread pudding are just amazing. The bread pudding comes in a rectangular shape and has banana and chocolate chips inside. 

This place is no second to the OTHER famous pastry shop in the mission. Thorough Bread offers a great variety of pastries and desserts, and a friendly neighborhood ambiance. One BIG plus is I never have to wait to get my food.
author: Saran R.

description: Never fails to disappoint. Delicious buttery creations. Try the Asiago, rosemary, walnut scone!
author: Andrea C.

description:
I take it back!  It is worth a trip!  :-P

Ham-and-Cheese croissant = perfect crisp flaky outside and moist inside.  

Diamonds = shortbread cookies are delicious, crumbly but not dry and just addicting buttery sugar bits!

Lemon pound cake = deliciously tart but a nice aftertaste of sugar.  I'm not a huge fan of icing, so that's the only thing I'd nix on it.  

Staff = friendly!! Even though it was closing time (5 minutes till) and they were patient and let me pick out all these items.
author: Fannie S.

description:
First of all, let me say F.U. Tartine! 
I'm dating a new Bakery now and it's name is Thorough. Thorough does everything to me that you won't. So, here are a few of the reason's why I will dissolve and disassociate my so-called "relationship" with you. 

1.)Thorough doesn't have me wait in line for what seems like an eternity or 45 minutes (whichever comes first), just to be snarked at by some 20 year old assholes, who have more time than money because they're too busy posing such disdain for their jobs. 

2.)Thorough doesn't charge me a small fortune for the same croissant. Actually Thorough's is flakier, tastier and best of all, not burnt! Also, Thorough's croissant is $2.00 cheaper then Tartine's. That's $2.00!!!! WTF! Really? 

3.)Thorough doesn't have me fighting over tables, chairs or benches. Let's just say, seating in general is a non-issue with Thorough. You don't have to behave like a prowling panther, waiting to pounce on any vestige of personal space. Thorough has this and to spare. 

I could go on and on, but I'll stop. I do not want to seem too bitter. Only bitter enough to know that in my relationship with Tartine, it was all give (my part) and all take (Tartine's). Where as my relationship with Thorough is a more of a partnership. A working symbiosis so to speak. We both fulfill each other needs. My only wish is that I would have learned this long ago.
author: Gabe T.

description:
An outdoor patio, cozy indoors, food made with love, pleasant service and reasonable prices...that's like the gift that keeps giving.

I really would have liked to give these guys 4.5 stars. The only reason I would hold back on the last half is because there is no wifi. Perhaps part of the appeal is that you're around people who are engaging with one another, as opposed to those beings wholly consumed in an alternate universe. Thanks Thorough Bread & Pastry for keeping us in the present :D
author: Vivek N.

description: A great neighborhood spot to grab a pastry or sandwich. I picked up a lemon poppyseed scone for breakfast and the turkey sandwich later in the day for lunch. Both were delicious! I'll be coming back for sure! There's also a really cute outside area in the back where you can sit and eat your breakfast or lunch- an added bonus!
author: Emily P.

description:
I can't believe it's taken me this long to review TB&P, but here goes: 

If you've ever waited on line at Tartine for 45 minutes just to be served passable pastries by moody mission hipsters only to then fight for a table space on grungy 18th Street next to screaming bus/street traffic, you will be *delighted* by Thorough Bread and Pastry, which is just around the corner and down the street.  

Exceptional pastries (including their insanely delicious almond croissant which rivals La Boulange's for best almond croissant in the city), friendly staff and more than ample seating (including a lovely open back patio) make Thorough Bread and Pastry my go-to neighborhood bakery.  

Bonus tip: their marmalades (while not made on premises) are exceptional.  

Double bonus tip:  order the demi-baguette in the morning and ask for butter and jam. At a buck fifty, it's an amazing deal for fresh bread.
author: Giacomo D.

description:
This is a very nice bakery. They have a lot to choose from and you can see them baking it all right there. They have quite a bit of seating including a small yard in the back if you want to sit outside.

We tried their chocolate bread which I thought was going to be really sweet but it's not. I would like to try it toasted with some honey butter at home. I bought a ham and cheese croissant which I ended up eating the next day and it was really good and a good size too.

Next time I'm in the area, I would definitely go back because they have a lot to try. Breads, decadent pastries, breakfast pastries and so on.
author: C R.

description:
THIS PLACE ROCKS! I am happy each and every time I come here.

I make sure to have a morning snack here every time I am in the City.  Totally addicted to this place. Their service is fast and friendly. Their prices are MORE than affordable. And the quality of their food is unsurpassed.

I highly recommend the sweet bread pudding (they also have a savory one) and a house coffee! DELICIOUS!
author: Lucas C.

description:
Thorough Bread has the best pastries in San Francisco.  It is quickly becoming my new weekend morning routine.

Over the last few weekends, my boyfriend and I took a lovely weekend stroll to Thorough Bread, specifically to try the almond croissant.  The first weekend, we just missed the delicious croissant by one customer, so we picked a few other pastries instead.  Every item we have tried has been mouth-watering delicious!  I have had the coffee cake (yes, I know, it is very middle-American of me), almond croissant, purple wheat baguette, and seasonal fruit tart.  I have always been extremely satisfied and always ready for more!  

Of course, I cannot have a morning pastry without a delicious latte.  I prefer the whole milk double-shot latte.  It is the perfect compliment to the sweet morning pastries.  

If you want a delicious start to your morning, make a trip to Thorough Bread!
author: Justin D.

description:
I had a very bad experience 
I was there last Thursday to buy a cake and a ciabatta bread, once i got home in Walnut Creek i realized i did not have the bread, I came back to the city today for work,  I passed by and told them what had happened. The man who spoke to me said: "no one said anything", to which I replied : of course I'm telling you right now, he said "did you try calling and letting us know what had happened?", I answered "no" so he said:  "I can't do anything".  A woman came, she asked what happened and I took the time to explain her the whole situation all over again, which was worse, she explained to me that some people had gone there before and lied about that, so if i didn't have the receipt then she couldn't do anything for me. I don't look or smell like a homeless person trying to steal some ciabatta bread .  She also said if someone forgot something there and didn't let them know they decide to give it away as a donation . Company policy she said, so I asked: how can I know the company policy if you don't have it printed on the receipt? She only said" well it's our policy".
I really wanted to talk to the manager but at that point I didn't feel like repeating everything again. I like their products that's why I stop by once in a while, but I have to say, it's the first time I felt so bad coming back to a store for something I left. (it's not the first time, i'm always forgetting things ).
author: Carolina N.

description:
i think the ghost of just desserts is blessing this bakery with good juju and pastry cream. i loved coming to just desserts as a kid (best carrot cake) and i'm excited that church and market will still summon mouthwatering cravings for baked goods.

i confess, i ordered like 6 things when i went in because everything looked so good.
here's my review:
yum yum, croissants! chocolate and plain!
and the quiche! yummm!
and the bread that looks like a branch with kalamata olive pieces in it! yummmm!
blueberry scone, pretty good.

and really nice service. as i left, the baker even looked up from her pastry rolling to say "bye, have a good day."
author: Wanda D.

description:
Thorough Bread bakery is what -real- french bakeries are all about: Great bread, professional dedication, and no attitude (hear that, Tartine!). 

This is the best bread you will get in the Castro and mission areas. As a Frenchman living near Dolores park, I am soooo relieved to now have a real french bakery blocks away from home! Thanks to them, after years of painful abstinence, I have finally resumed eating baguette again (baguettes sold in most places in SF are crap, no offense). 

Funny - one guy in an earlier review compared the baguette they serve to "Safeway bread" (which is probably the worst bread you can find anywhere). With all due respect, I don't know if this guy has any clue what he's talking about, despite being so specific in his review. Every french person I know swear by their baguette.
author: bart m.

description: The pasties are dangerously addictive. I've come here a lot for lunch and have always been satisfied. I ALWAYS order one pastry and 1 sandwich. Also, the back patio is a nice escape from the sea of people outside.
author: Thomas Nathan S.

description:
Hubby and I went here during brunch time and ordered the following:

3 almond croissants- yummy, the best almond croissants we have ever eaten
Cappuccino - ok, not great but not bad
1 croissant to go- not tried it yet
Turkey sandwich- good, not great but not bad

The cashier was nice- took our order.
The place was hot- seem like they don't have air conditioning- is this a San Fran thing? Not sure. 
Only thing that I didn't like - flying gnats that landed on the pastries from time to time- probably because the front and back door were both wide open. 

We sat at the back which is an open patio area-it had  slight breeze which was nice. 
I would come here again for sure - those almond croissants are yummy- Better than the ones at Jean Phillipe Patisserie inside the Aria hotel in Las Vegas, which I didn't think was possible- less butter/sweetness compared to Jean's but smaller size.  But I think it was only $1.50 or $2 a piece so totally worth it. 

For the out of towners like us, please be aware that this place is kinda far from everything- in Castro part of town. If you take the F line bus ( yellow bus) if u are staying at Fisherman's Wharf- it will drop u off less than 1 block from this bakery.
author: C C.

description:
The people behind the counter speak French.

The pastries *sound* glorious when you bite into them.

The back garden area is adorable.

Enough said.
author: Ian S.

description: It makes me sad when I have to lower a review on a place I've loved, but something is going on at Thorough Bread and its not working! The lunch food has been consistently uninspired for the last 5 visits. I've had my beloved roasted chicken sandwich twice - the chicken hasn't been fresh and they did something icky to the bread - way to sweet! The soup has been bland, and the coffee still sucks. I'm not giving up completely, but Mae and Judy will be getting even more of my business.
author: Jerry M.

description:
On his birthday, my husband received a box filled with pastries from this place... adorable little pinwheel pastries with custard and blueberries or raspberries in the middle...delicious.  

So on an early Saturday morning, we dropped by.  Exterior was unassuming, we thought it was actually a tiny shop, but once we entered we saw a couple of long glass cases filled with goodies.  There was ample seating plus a cute patio in the back.

We picked up one sticky bun, almond croissant, plain croissant, apple gallette and sourdough boule.  All were absolutely wonderful.  The almond croissant was especially tasty with a thin layer of almond paste within....perfect.

Service was attentive and friendly.  Highly recommended.
author: A O.

description:
I don't know what to complain about this place.

their products are delicious, inexpensive and always fresh. It has a very nice back patio where you can enjoy some serenity especially in the morning.

Their almond croissant is something else, it's probably one of the best almond croissants i've ever had. perfectly balanced and delicious.
author: Sung C.

description:
The pastries are executed well in the classic style and reasonably priced.  They do lack a bit of flair in my opinion.  For example, the ham and cheese croissant ($2.75) was light and tender, but without many layers.  I also like my croissants flakier.  The chocolate biscotti ($0.75) had great texture and taste: tiny chips, extra crunchy, dense - but it would be even better with some nuts or something extra.  The flavors are standard - almond or chocolate.  I'd love to see something more unique like Meyer lemon.  The snickerdoodle ($0.75) was tender and buttery but barely had any cinnamon on top. 

What a great space with the outdoor patio seating in the back, a bit of seating out front, brick walls and more indoor seating.  The colors are warm and rustic; the worn floor has charming hand-painted quotes.  They have an open kitchen though the bread is baked at their school (San Francisco Baking Institute) because they don't have the proper ovens there.  The bread is delivered around 9 AM and they offer discounted day-old bread.

Morning pastries include scones, sticky buns, muffins, croissants, and Danish. I didn't see any brioche?  I wonder what types of sandwiches and soups they have - guess I have to come back in the afternoon to see.  The case had eclairs along with full sized and individual sized cakes.  I didn't see any cupcakes.  The coffee is supplied by SF's own House of Coffee and espresso drinks are available.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Whoever says that Tartine is the best bakery in San Francisco hasn't been to Thorough Bread.  

The chocolate bread is awesome.  So are the gourgettes.  Good prices too.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
I am a fan of this place! 
I passed by this bakery so many times in the past four years, and finally made it in. I like how many of the ppl who work there are culinary/pastry students-- makes me believe in the place a bit more (support the future!) 
I went in to get an almond croissant, but sadly, they were all out. Instead, I got the bread pudding and found it to be awesome! It was super chocolatey and satisfying. The coffee was pretty decent, but nothing to brag about. I was so tempted to buy their little package of mini macarons, but decided against it. Maybe next time. 
I like their outdoor patio in the back. Bring a book, hang out, enjoy some good french pastries.
author: Taryn S.

description:
Love the place - and I go there often and always enjoy the food.

But ... I am riding bikes with a group of people tomorrow and called to find out whether we could take our bikes in their back garden. I was told it's OK if you have 2 or 3 bikes, but a larger group with bikes would not be not welcome. 

Their place, their right to decide, but given the size of their back garden area, I think they could be a little more accommodating to cyclists.
author: David G.

description:
The pastries are so good.  I really wish this place took more business away from other local bakeries or at least got as much acclaim.

The service is outstanding.  The bread is delicious.  Please go here and support these folks.  I found recently that they train up and coming bakers as well.

BTW, the review on the bikes from David G.  I really agree with them.  There's not many places where over 3 bikes can be taken to anyway.  I certainly wouldn't call to find out if I could take my 5 dogs (I don't have 5 dogs) or if they'd validate my street parking.
author: Andy S.

description:
Here's the breakdown for you:

- French macarons - $1.25 each or $3.50 for 3. They were alright. 3.5 stars.
- Ham and cheese croissant - $2.75. Toasted, this is PHE-FRIGGIN'-NOMENAL. Seriously. 5-stars.
- Epi baguette - $1.25 for a footlong'ish one. I think it's a pretty good value and it's one of the better epi baguettes I've had (far better than La Boulange but not yet as good as Bouchon's). 5-stars anyway. SO GOOD. We had three like the French - just walking the streets of San Francisco eating loaves of bread. No need for butter, jam or anything - it's that good!

I'll definitely be back, if for no other reason than the epi baguette. Yum'tastic!
author: Chung N.

description:
The pastries and breads here all look so good! Their croissants are so flaky and wonderful. I also recommend their sticky bun which after being warmed is soft and luscious - yum!

Their sandwiches are mediocre so I would say, stick with their desserts!
author: Elaine L.

description: Holy cow! Dropped by to grab something for brunch. Saw that almond croissants were fresh out of the oven. Bought some and went home to eat them. They were out of this world good. The perfect amount of almond paste inside. Flaky on the outside but still very nice buttery and moist on the inside. If I were eating at the pastry shop I easily could've eaten another. NEED  to go back. I'd say best croissant I've ever had. Definitely better than Tartine's morning bun any day (dry and usually a bit burnt) !!!
author: Lily V.

description: Go for the almond croissant alone. Nice staff, comfy environment that invites you to linger. Great lattes. One star off for tough parking.
author: Ce Ce M.

description: Seriously some of the best pasties I've ever had. Clean, spacious interior. Friendly staff.
author: P G.

description:
They do many things well:

- Bread (multi-grain goodness)
- Turkey (generous portion on my sandwich)
- Dessert (whole wheat cookies!)
- Customer service (see below)

And one thing not so well:

- Caramelized onions

Actually, they don't really do the last one at all. At least I don't think. I've been twice now. First time was near the beginning of the month, and I was a bit perplexed to get to the top of Dolores Park only to find my sandwich had mayo but no caramelized onions, the exact opposite of what I asked for. I called, and a manager invited me to return for a remedy on the house (the customer service part from above). Today, I found myself back at the top of Dolores Park with sandwich #2. No mayo, but alas, no onions. Which, of course, I am now craving.

But it's all good. This is a bakery, not a caramelized onion factory, and the sandwich was pretty dope without them. Both sandwiches. And perfection was that whole wheat cookie.
author: Jason B.

description:
Amazing sticky buns!

The only bad thing is that they seem to run out of them. But they are the best sticky buns I've ever had.

The coffee, sandwiches, and other desserts are also good. I have yet to buy bread from here though. I'm sure it is good though.

Oh, and the bread pudding is also delicious too.
author: Melissa M.

description:
I believe when you go to heaven you will be greeted with an almond croissant (hot out of the oven) from this bakery.  

When I'm lucky, I arrive when the almond croissants are straight from the oven and I ask them to hold sprinkling the powdered sugar on mine (which they do to all their almond crossaints). Why mess with perfection? It has buttery, light layers of chewy pastry on the inside coupled with a delicate almond paste and a crisp perfect outside. 

I'm also a fan of their sweet chouquettes (mini pastry bites which are lightly sweetened - 4 for $1.25). These make a nice little a.m. snack.
author: Jean H.

description: I'd been here before for various desserts, which have always been delicious, but I'd never had lunch here until today. I kept it simple-- a caprese baguette-- and was not disappointed. I'll be back to try some of their other sandwiches in the future...
author: Brett W.

description:
Real french accents make for real french pastry. Real. French. Crossiants. 

Chocolate Sourdough. 

Homemade Kiwi jam, Pineapple jam, Cucumber marmalade. 

Are you drooling yet? 

Two kinds of quiche every day, one meat and one veggie. Rich, flakey, herbal, vegetal, eggy heaven. 

Whole wheat chocolate chip cookies: 1. they are the PERFECT size. 2. they have the most adorable teenytinyittbybitty chocolate chips. Millions of tiny chips. 3. They don't taste "healthy" like other whole wheat cookies. They don't remind you of your mother's 70's baking experiements. They just taste like chocolate chip cookies with a little more... earthly wisdom. 

Are you there yet? 

Go Here Now!

Now!!!

P.S. people say the expresso is the best in the neighborhood.
author: Alexandria N.

description: Had a wonderful potato bacon turnover for breakfast. That sucker was still warm when I got it too. It's really rich so that despite being a tiny pastry it's probably heavy enough to constitute an entire breakfast.
author: Misha T.

description: I will come here forever for the almond croissants or are they pastries? I gave my dad's ENT doctor one and he stated; " these things should be illegal."  The financiers are okay, but yah, those almond things.  Well done, well done. I'm glad I live close, but I hate to be tempted every time I walk back from the gym.
author: Marvin O.

description:
Like the name suggests, maybe I should've tried the bread or basic pastries, because I made the mistake of choosing a slice of mushroom 
and red bell pepper quiche and it was tasteless. The service, however, was friendly and delightful though. 

This shop is a nice and simple place to spend time in if you want to get some work done in the middle of the day. I really appreciate shops like these that not only have more than a handful of tables available, but also won't mind customers lounging around for hours and feeding off their self-serve water station. In the back, there's also a shady outdoor patio with pleasant foliage if you dig that. I enjoyed staying indoors to get some reading done when I was here recently and it was peaceful until they started playing some pop music, specifically Lady Gaga's Paper Gangster (which is one of my favorites from her first album, so it's all gooood). 

Nevertheless, I'd still come back and order something different next time since I do remember there being a million other treats behind the shiny glass that looked delish.
author: Bets Y.

description:
I have had very good visits to this bakery and very not good visits (not bad, but definitely not good). I love, love, LOVE their delicious cookies and cakes but despise their dry scones and croissants (especially the ham and cheese, which seems to be made with some sort of  bechamel-ish cheese sauce. Not a fan). The service is great when you're the only customer but chaotic when there are more than 2 people in line.

As much as I appreciate Thorough Bread's large daily selection of pastries I feel that they have sacrificed quantity for quality. Some things are great, like their double chocolate cookies, which are super decadent and ridiculously cheap ($0.75), while other things just don't live up to expectation.

Yelp describes it's three-star rating as "A-OK" so I will describe Thorough Bread & Pastry the same. A-OK.
author: Sophia D.

description:
Stick me with a fork, I am done, son. 

This place makes me realize how sh*tty american food is. Everything tastes fresh and amazing and delicious. You know, the way food should taste. I also love the staff, they get to know you by name if you frequent as much as I do. If you don't love the coffee, or they effed it up, sure no problem here is a brand new one which tastes amazing and delicious. Ham and cheese croissants.... holy lord. Mini creme puffs... oh mercy!!! Tuna egg sandwich thing? Who knew something like that would melt in my mouth the way it does. Forget "la boulonge" or however you spell it. This place is the real deal. 

But you best be saving me a ham and cheese croissant! don't make me regret writing such a good review that they are all gone by the time I get there ;-)
author: Rachel L.

description: Four mice scampering around on their patio looking for food. This is a  health hazard!
author: Rob M.

description:
It does not look like much from the outside. The bakery is almost hidden on this busy section of Church street near The Muni stop on Market street. (The same space that was once a nice vegetarian restaurant whose name escapes me.)

Once inside the door all the character of this bakery comes into focus... a much larger selection of baked goods than Tartine, and on a similar level of quality.

Worth knowing about and using when in this part of the city!
author: dan s.

description:
Let me start by saying that I grade on a curve.   Very few places get 5 stars from me.   I always find something to knock off a star or two. 
This place combines excellent product with genuinely nice staff.   Though I have to go a bit out of my way to get there,  Thorough Bread is quickly becoming a weekend tradition.   I wish I could point to one thing in particular for Yelpers to try,  but honestly everything from the croissants to the tarts to the olive bread has been excellent.
author: Kitty M.

description: Rude staff. No wi-fi. (I was deceived after seeing others on computers, and sadly didn't discover this until I had paid for 2 hours of parking and settled in with my bakery goods.) From the moment I walked in, my smiles were not returned. Not able to do my emailing as I had hoped, I had them pour my coffee from the ceramic mug into the to-go cup and I tried to give some feedback in a purposefully kind tone. I was taken aback by the rudeness shown and left disappointed. I only gave them a second star because their pastries were so pretty.
author: Haley W.

description:
I can't believe I was so fortunate to find Thorough Bread and Pastry just a few weeks before my wedding.  We wanted to have a special tower of macaroon instead of a wedding cake and had a very difficult time finding someone to make it.
I met with the chef and emailed with Miyuki to explain my vision.  They agreed to do it and absolutely made my day perfect.  
They perfectly wrapped it and when my brother picked it up to bring it to the wedding, they gave him perfect instructions for storage and service of the tower.

I did not see it until it was put on display at the wedding.  I was stunned, it was perfect, better than I could have ever imagined.  We were amazed by the detail and attention they put into this macaroon tower.  That detail and the fact that the macaroons were delish and people are still talking about the macaroons made our day perfect.

Thank you so much for making this perfect dessert for our wedding.
author: Tian D.

description: My friend told me to try this place - said it rivaled Tartine, according to his French friend.  You don't need to tell me twice to try a new bakery!  I got the almond croissant (even though I'm not usually a big almond fan, but my friend raved about it) and the chocolate croissant.  He was right - the almost croissant was AMAZING.  SOOOOOO good.  The chocolate croissant was good too but could have used more chocolate (what couldn't?).
author: B. Y.

description: Almond croissants: good, but tartine is so.close and there's really no comparison. Awesome apple galette with a deliciously light and flaky crust, yummy coffee cake too. Would be worth a trip by itself, but if you're in the area I see no reason to go here when tartine is so close and an order of magnitude better.
author: Jeff M.

description: On my way to the park, my friend and I stopped in here for some light pastries. I ordered the Blue Berry & Raspberry Danish and it was delicious! I enjoyed it very much. The next time I'm in town, I will be stopping by here again!
author: An S.

description:
Originally i went here to buy bread for my boss, she loves to get the epi's and the regular baguettes. But more and more i find myself going here too. This has become one of my favorite bread places.

I love their blueberry danishes and most importantly their delicious gougeres! omggggg, so cheesy, buttery and light!

if you haven't tried their bread or their pastries, you are missing out!
author: Liberty C.

description: If you do go, the best sandwich is the Pulled Pork -- in fact, I have been thinking about it for 2 years since I last had one there. And so I was disappointed yesterday, when I finally could go find my way there with a toddler in arms and a visiting grandfather by side (12/18 about 1pm) . When we entered , there was no line and yet about eight workers with their backs turned to us had us waiting to order for 5 min. When I did approach the front of house girl (note to whom it concerns, she had an upper lip piercing) if there was a menu we could see , she literally said" yes there is, you can find it by the tip jar by the register." And so we went to this location and there was no menu, and the girl rather pretended to be busy when I think she was rather idling! Then another girl came to the register when we were waiting and I said" hi, we would like to order some food? " and she said" somebody will be with you shortly." Then I approached the pierced front of house girl again and said "do you still have sandwiches here?" And she said," yes" and was silent. Finally I just said "can we order two pulled porks" and it finally went from there. Basically, disappointing service ... And it took us 40 min to drive there, $3 to park, and then to just stand around and have aloof service . Here's a news flash: if somebody comes in with a baby and old man and they are standing at the register for five min, Help them! If somebody asks for a menu, get it!! If somebody asks do you still serve sandwiches, perhaps tell them which sandwiches are available for the day! The whole experience left us a bit sad, and the grandfather was disappointed too -- which is a shame because he was just visiting the area for a few days and his impression of SF service will not be what it is was
author: Killian C.

description: Almond Croissant and Bokstok (spelling?) only things worth getting here, but disappointed today when I ordered two croissants and clerk gave me one that was fresh and another that had been re-baked and completely dried out and kinda burnt. You lost two stars for that. Payards who does make the best almond croissants would never do such a shameful thing, but they are not local. It would be better if you under-bake because most people take home and toast to make warm or customers could request to warm up if eating in-house without risk of drying out or burning.
author: Carrie W.

description: One of my favorite bakeries in San Francisco. If you go, definitely try the Almond Croissant!
author: Tiffany S.

description:
One of my favorite places where to get daily bread, pastries and have breakfast during the weekend.
The people are very nice, the food is excellent (sandwiches included), the back patio very charming, one of the best places I found in town.
author: Luca R.

description:
After my last review, a manager emailed me and apologized for the poor service I experienced on one of my visits. I really appreciate that they care enough about the customer to go out of their way to respond to any complaints!

The other day, I was across the street from Thorough Bread and decided to take my parents in for a treat, which turned out to be a fabulous idea. This time I tried their coffee, and I must say they make a great latte. The Chocolate Chip Bread is DIVINE and might be my new favorite thing. It tastes like a chocolate bagel mixed with a muffin. Amazing.

This time, the service was great, so no complaints there. The food was just as good as ever!
author: Geno B.

description: These are good people! I wrote to them because I was looking for ciabatta rolls for a sandwich recipe project. They quickly got back to me, fully answered my questions, and helped me place a pre-paid order. The rolls are great, and I'll gladly return for more (even though it takes two MUNI lines).
author: Brett N.

description: I tried chocolate croissant. Delicious and reasonable price. But i'm qurious how much calories it has. Because it's pretty big!
author: Mihwa S.

description:
To me, a place gets at least 2 stars for having no (or quick moving) lines. What can I say, when I want my food, I want it now. I'm surprised this place isn't more crowded, because the baked goods are excellent. Almond croissants, chocolate chip cookies, brioche, olive bread, country bread - most of it still warm and all of it was amazing. 

Beyond that, the coffee and espresso drinks were terrific, as was this freshly-made vegetable soup that was light but hearty and warmed me through and through.

The folks who work behind the counter are SO nice, informative and have a great sense of humor - you can tell they work damn hard, but can still crack jokes with gushing goofballs like myself. 

This is a charmer of a bakery, and if I could pitch a tent in their patio and eat hot almond croissants for breakfast every day and country bread and soup for dinner, I'd do it in a heartbeat.
author: Mary J.

description:
Today my friend surprised me by bringing me an almond croissant from this place.  OMG - it was a great reminder of my days in Paris!  Here are the details:

Good size, like 7 inches, a large amount of almond paste and almonds on the top, no empty unfilled space.  Then almond paste stuffed inside!  It was divine.  I had it in the afternoon, but it didn't even taste like it was made a few hours before.  Still fresh, not overly buttery, but the butter did come through the bag, not in a gross way.  

Worth it!  Will definitely go back.
author: Denice L.

description: Lovely space, even better pastries.  The chocolate macaroon is to die for, moist and full of coconuty goodness, with a quick dip in semisweet chocolate.  We didn't eat much or stay long, but really enjoyed the patio in the back, with the mishmash of tables and the beautiful lamppost in the middle of the space.  I'd definitely go back if I was in the area.  Just wish they had slightly more selection for people who can't just have pastry, something with a bit more protein would be nice.  I know it's a bakery, but not everybody can exist on carbs alone.
author: Rebecca H.

description: This is my favorite spot in the city for the best pastries and coffee. My friend and I both thought that the almond croissant was well worth the indulgence. If this place had wi-fi, it would be my favorite for grabbing a latte and checking e-mail during the week.
author: Jenn B.

description:
Am I the only one who has actually eaten the pastries from this place? 

Yes I think the berads are fine - I am not arguing that, but I definitely don't get the glowing references to the pastries???

I pass by this place 2+ times a day so I ahve been here a good number of times. The first time I had a pastry, I was greatly disappointed since it definitely looked much better than it tasted. The danishes were very dry and filling/topping had little flavor. The small cakes were mediocre tasting but beautiful to look at. 

I have given a variety of desserts here a try but have been let down every time. I figured that was not their specialty... I would recomment Urban Bread over this place for similarly priced bread and pastries.
author: Angelito R.

description: An update to a previous review -- the recipe for the chocolate bread changed -- or rather the shape of the bread changed.  It is no longer a round loaf with a nice crusty top.  The chocolate bread  set this place apart from other bakeries.  Now it's just a neighborhood bakery.  Stop by if you're in the neighborhood.  But a special trip to the bakery is not necessary.
author: Heather R.

description: Atmosphere is okay, whatever... the reason I go to this place is for the chocolate caramel tart. OH MY GOD!!!! I close my eyes when eating this tart, and eat the whole thing. It's perfect and not too crazy expensive for what you get.
author: A P.

description: I went there two times so far. The first time I had an almond croissant that was pretty darned good with a cafe Americano which was pretty darned weak. Several days later I ordered a cranberry walnut loaf and got a cafe Americano to go. The loaf was absolutely delicious but the Americano was weak which means that I'd have to be pretty dumb to order an Americano at this establishment but I will definitely go back for their croissants and cranberry walnut bread. In fact, I just might head on over there right now!
author: Clare H.

description:
These folks now how to treat food with love. They have amazing pastries,  yummy bread, good sandwiches/soup and serve it all with a happy face. 

And their espresso drinks are good too. And a couple of the staff are French which is fun.
author: Rob K.

description:
Gougeres. Gougeres. GOUGERES!

Also: bread pudding. Baguette. Chocolate bread. Olive fougasse.

HOWEVER:
They do not have proper black tea. They have some silly crap with berry flavors or caramel flavors or whatever. You may have to bring your own goddam teabag. Thorough Bread, please fix this!

If you are there with a child, just order them something delicious without asking what they'd like. If you order them a bagel with cheese, it'll be a dry, flavorless thing with a slice of American on it. Why would you do that to your child when you are otherwise surrounded by tasty options?
author: Liz H.

description:
After my Yelp review I was contacted by someone very nice at Thorough Bread and we chatted about baguette with cheese (a favorite topic), and what I would want to change.

The procedure to get an amazing baguette with cheese at Thorough Bread is now: ask for the sandwich (with butter if you are like me), and request a lot of cheese. That's it : ) Everyone apparently got the memo or whatnot, since the amount of cheese is now just right.

Sadly, I just moved to Rockridge from the Castro, and won't be a regular at Thorough Bread anymore. Goodbye, chocolate bread, goodbye.... and just as they have a significantly expanded Jam selection And are making the Chocolate bread every day...
author: Tom E.

description:
I love little hole in the wall bakeries. 

This place is great. Friendly service as soon as I walked in. 

The bakery is open so you can watch them make bread and pastries. 

Tried a fruit cheesecake and a snicker doodle with some some house coffee. 

Cheesecake was moist throughout and tasty. 

Snicker doodle was soft and tasty. 

It was SO good we grabbed a baguette to take home to have with some cheese. 

Clean seating area and good service makes this a great place to hang out. The great pastries help too.
author: Eric H.

description: I just wanted to post an update since this bakery has now become part of my weekly routine. Since the date of my previous post and first visit, I've made a Friday morning ritual of Thorough Bread and Pastry. Every week  I get something new and this place has yet to disappoint.  Sticky buns, muffins, scones. . .every single one has been perfect, without fail.  And, don't miss the truly unique offerings like the Bostok (OMG!), the Gibassier, or the macarons parisiens. This place remains my choice as tops in the City, and thank goodness it's close to home!
author: Mark N.

description:
I love their breads, especially olive bread. Cookies are excellent and my favorites are the little diamonds in vanilla and pistachio. My fave dessert there is chocolate mousse.

The only reason I'm not giving 5 stars is that I'm not crazy about their coffee, which is oh so necessary with pastries.
author: K C.

description:
The worst.  

Called ahead and asked them to hold  something for me. I have done this before.  They tell me they have 3 left and will hold one.  I told them I'd be there "in about an hour."  They didn't ask for a name, nothing. They never do. 

Pouring  rain and strong winds that afternoon. I walk there FROM NOB HILL, in rain and wind, arrive appx. 1.5 hours after my call, and blonde woman that seems to be there all the time unapologetically states "we sold it."  Wtf? I ask why she would sell it after saying they'd hold it for me.  Her response: "You said an hour. We couldn't contact you to see if you were coming." I was, at most, 30 minutes longer than my ESTIMATED time of arrival. She said someone wanted it, so she sold it.  ISN'T THAT THE PURPOSE OF HOLDING SOMETHING?  When I said I'd walked there from Nob Hill, her response was a smirking "oh, sorry."  She repeated they couldn't contact me to see if I was still coming. So, I ask, why didn't they ask for my contact info if they needed it?  "We were busy" says bizarrely unapologetic, unpleasant automaton.   I see, too busy to do your f'n job.  

The blonde woman has had an obnoxiously attitudinal affect in the past, which had put me off enough to stop coming very often, but today her affect was bordering pathological. 

Never again. The flies on the pastries, the bitchy counter chick, and the few things I used to like having better versions elsewhere (Pinkie's Bakery for much better chocolate bread. Without the attitude!), there is no reason to come here again. Hopefully the owners will send that employee back to whatever prison release program they hired her from.  There are way too many good bakeries around to waste my time and money here.
author: Allucaneat G.

description:
This is a great place.

I am from Paris and can tell you the "baba au rhum" and the "tarte au citron" are as divine as you would find them in a bakery in Paris.

I hope for the owners that this place will get as popular as the horrid Tartine.
author: Bobby T.

description: I go here almost every day.   It's embarrassing but they are that good.  Always excellent and the staff is wonderfully friendly and efficient besides.
author: Bob B.

description:
trust friends to bring you to the best places in the city. thorough bread and pastry rates amongst the best bakeries I've been to in the entire country. The pastries are well priced and looked amazing. We had a turkey sammich, a baguette, and the soup of the day. The soup was a bit bland but the tasty turkey sandwich made up for that. 

The place was clean and has a red-brick wall as well as lots of new track lighting. A very cozy feel to the place. Would def rec this place for sandwiches and bread. 

Oh yea, we got  a loaf of the cranberry bread to go and it was quite a tasty breakfast treat the next morning. There is indoor and outdoor (back patio) seating.
author: Amit K.

description:
Holy sweet Jesus.  I had been reminiscing about a trip to Paris my friends and I took 5 years ago, and we remember two things very clearly: 1) the almond croissants from the bakery(Boulanger Gana) near our apartment, and 2) the most amazing falafels we've ever had (L'As du Falafel in case you are wondering).  Anyway, I digress, I had been on a mission to find a comparable almond croissant close to home.

I had heard good things about this place from a friend, and so I decided on a whim to check it out.  I was not disappointed!  The topping was crunchy and had an amazing buttery flavor, and the inside was filled with the almond cream/paste.  So delicious.  Just in case, I made sure I bought a couple in case the first one was a fluke of goodness. (it wasn't)

I also tried the ham and cheese croissant which was also very good, but I couldn't tear myself away from the almond croissants.

Love is an understatement.

Thorough Bread, I'll see you again real soon. xoxo.
author: Lu E.

description:
More like 3.5. 

I seriously miss lining up for bread in a bakery with all the French housewives to buy a nice warm baguette for dinner. Those were the  good days and I wish I could find a place where I could get the same experience. 

This cutesy place has a lot of the same products, but feels Americanized. Not that I would expect it to feel completely French, I was just hoping that bread got baked all day long and there was a line of business folk waiting in line patiently for their turn to buy bread on their walk home. Oh well. 

Desserts looked yummy, but the bread selection was pretty low at the end of the day. Boo. 

The baguette had a nice color and flavor, but the texture seemed a bit too uniform. I was hoping it to be crisper on the outside and fluffy on the inside. 

There is some upcoming event with beer and pastry tasting that caught my eye!
author: Tina P.

description: As well as the almond croissant, chouquettes are awesome! chewy, moisty texture and having a full bodied scent of egg. yum~
author: Sukwon P.

description:
A friend introduced me to this place, and while I've only been here once, I highly recommend it.  

With both delicious sweet and savory options, it was hard to choose, but I went with a savory scone (something I'd never heard of!) -- it had goat cheese, sun dried tomatoes, and thyme.  Basically, a delicious savory orgasm in my mouth.

Service was quick, and I really appreciated that they had glasses and water already available, so you neither had to ask, nor wait for your food. It is a place where you order at the counter and then sit.

They also had rows and rows of delicious sweets. Alas, I only wanted something savory, so those will have to wait for next time!
author: Shanna K.

description: Hidden gem in that there are so many food places around easy to miss one of them. Across the street from Chow you will find this WONDERFUL!!!! little place with great yummy super tasty butter laced concoctions. Great price point. Great service. Great patio section in back of store, always been clean and inviting when ever I have eaten here. Get some of that good ish!
author: Johnfucious S.

description: I love this place! Amazing patio out back to indulge in a nice pastry (or 4) or a nice sandwich. Out of 4 pastries and 3 sandwiches they were all good. We bought a baguette for dinner on the way out, it was great as well. The only thing that was as delighted as my full tummy was my wallet (or mom's because she paid) it was priced very reasonably! That alone will keep me raving about this place!!! Though they can't make iced drinks because they have no ice, none. That's kind of weird, yeah? Great place, cute building, you won't be disappointed!
author: Jennifer H.

description: Pleasant & helpful staff. Excellent bread. Ham & cheese croissant... in a word? Delectable. Price is right. Outdoor patio is a nice touch.
author: Frank B.

description: THIS has been our go-to place since it opened; the service, ambience, and quality of the pastries and breads have always out shined the competition (though it is true that the beverage service can be amazingly chaotic at times...) and even though I never reviewed it before, I would certainly have given it five stars. But something is happening here of late that is unmistakable and disappointing; the service has fallen off noticeably and the pastry is often stale. Actually, that is not quite right; the almond croissants are almost always stale regardless of the day or time we consume them. And interestingly, the scones are now better than the croissants, which was never true before. It certainly appears that there have been some changes in the crew and perhaps we need to wait and see if this bodes well or ill, but it would be a terrible pity if this gem were to become just another hapless coffee place in the neighborhood....
author: Ken K.

description: We come here on Sundays after super early morning A/V setup at church. It's just the pick me up we need! Pastries galore. Many times the people in our group will get something savory and something sweet "for dessert". Because you really can't help it. Everything's so yummy!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
amazing if you order correctly!  here is my professional recommendations:

Almond Croissants

Muffins

Ham and Cheese Croissants



Don't order the following (not bad but not the best):

Coffee Cake

Danish Pastries

Scones

xo-P
author: Pammy S.

description:
Holy crap. Why did it take me so long to find this place??

This is now my official, after Zumba-at-24-hour-fitness treat.  (I'm not sweating for an hour for nothing!)
author: Anne D.

description:
When I come in here, at least three times a week, I twirl the end of my little mustache and laugh just so, "a hoh-hoh-hoh," because that's what they do in France, right? 

While that may not be what they really do in France, the pastries at this place are definitely authentic. They've got a wide selection, no long line like at some other places -- ahem, Tartine -- and there's a little patio out back.

And if you're on your way home before 7 pm, pick up a fresh baguette for dinner for $1.50.
author: Brent B.

description:
Wow, what a find! I had some time for a quick breakfast bite before my hair appointment across the street, so I popped in. I love French bakeries - everything about them - so finding a legit spot is a dream come true for me. Throrough Bread did not disappoint.

Everything about the joint feels authentic. I indulged in a chocolate croissant and a potato/bacon turnover. YUM. No offense to Crepevine a few doors down, but I really do not know how they stay in business with this place nearby. Do yourself a favor and try something different - you will be in for a treat.

Extra points for the friendly staff (yes, at a French place!)
author: Kiesha R.

description: Baba Au Rhum!! I love this little sweet alcohol filled  deliciousness, brings me back to the sunny peninsula of Southern Italy.....Baba Au Rhum is one of the greatest desserts invented for you rum infused dessert lovers. TRY IT
author: Devin S.

description:
Phenomenal neighborhood bakery.  Out of all the pastries I've had, my favorite will have to be the almond croissant.  It has the rich buttery texture of a great croissant, but with the added sweetness of the almond.  The chocolate croissant is good, but not the star of the show.  The chocolate bread is to die for, and the cookies (any of them really) strike the balance of chewy centers, but crunchy sides.  

There's a great garden area and sidewalk seating, so they give you great ways to enjoy your pastries.  

I haven't had the sandwiches, but if they bake their own bread, it can't be bad.

I will say, the coffee wasn't great-slightly too weak.
author: AJ L.

description:
Thorought Bread was one of those places whose window displays of beautiful loaves of bread always made me stop and stare. I thought, one day, I will try this place. 

On one Sunday morning, boyfriend and I were looking for a new coffee spot. We settled on Thorough Bread for a coffee and a croissant. There is plenty of indoor seating, although the back patio looked enticing, if the weather looked a bit better. 

The other night, I was looking for a quick snack for dinner. The previous block on Church Street was powerless (and subsequently, my fave spot Morning Due was out of commission.) I sat indoors, and nibbled on my tomatoe and mozzarella panini with a (slightly too small) side salad. I faced the window, and watched as pedestrian after pedestrian stopped, peered inside at the window display and smiled. They'll be in soon enough.
author: Bryan B.

description:
I got a message recently from the owner.. stating this place does take debit cards!!  Woohoo for not always have to run for an ATM.
And yes.. I will be back to get my hands on some of the beautiful confections this place has.
author: Alicia A.

description:
This place's pastries are on par with very nice boulangeries and patisseries that I have been to in different parts of France!

And they don't feel too fancy/pretentious even though they are on par with some of the haute qualité places!  Which makes them even better!

Staff are really kind, helpful and awesome even the barista was awesome even though  they were probably stressed out by a huge crowd orderingtheir morning coffee.
author: Space Cadet O.

description: Discovered this place because it is directly across the street from me, some how for the 2 months I've been there I didn't notice it. But I am so glad I walked in. We were greeted with a smile and great service. The girl that helped us was so sweet and candid, the way I love service to be. She helped me pick which pastry to get, I got the pain au raisin. I also got the garden sandwich and my boyfriend got the mozzarella, tomato, and basil one. A cup of tea for me and coffee for him we sat in the back patio and are the delicious raisin pastry (which had both golden and regular raisins, wasn't too sweet just how I like) and sipped our drinks. They had a nice selection of teas and not just your basic ones. I got the pearl jasmine, it was nice and light. Good quality tea. My boyfriend drank his coffee black and really enjoyed it. We both loved our sandwiches. The veggies in mine were grilled and seasoned very nicely. I will definitely be coming back often since it's so convenient but also delicious! The only downer is that the outside back patio isn't too peaceful because there are noises from machinery inside the bakery or something next door and it kind of kills the relaxing vibe. Other than that I really enjoyed the service and food here!
author: Skye F.

description: Fantastic almond croissant! the taste is unbelievable. their sandwiches are Ok but the latte is also good. Highly recommended
author: Hamid C.

description:
Had to get a selection of desserts for a surprise post wedding Champagne and Cake reception for a very small group.  Got a nice selection of their pastries/mini-cakes and it worked out perfectly.  

EVERYTHING was excellent!!!  Would highly recommend Thorough Bread & Pastry for these folks are the real deal and know what they are doing.
author: Bryan H.

description: I like this place a lot. This place is a bakery, but they also sell sandwiches. The place looks clean and modern. They have outdoor patio seating in the back. I like their croissants. My favorite is the chocolate croissant. Their regular croissants are also pretty good. I tried some other baked items they have, and they are usually fresh and well made. I have not been disappointed with anything I purchased.
author: Hiroshi K.

description:
I went here on Wednesday with a friend for coffee and some pastries. So much to choose from, 

I want to go back to try other baked goods. Prices seemed a bit high. But I still enjoyed the hazelnut chocolate cake bread I ate with a cup of coffee. 

My friend had a chocolate chip bread muffin, I thought it pretty good. 

Some of the dessert items look really fancy and very luxurious. As I say, I will have to go back some time and try at least one of them. 

I am happy Thorough Bread & Pastry has taken over  the space of what was once "Just Desserts." It is still very much the place to be for fine sweets and good coffee.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Noticed this place while walking back from Twin Peaks (not much need to worry about calories after walking 7 miles horizontally and 2000 feet vertically!).  My SO was attracted by the courtyard, but the bread, croissant and apple gallette were what we'll remember.

Croissant and french bread are my two favorite bakery items and this place got them both right.  My SO complained that the croissant crust wasn't *quite* crisp enough and that it only matched up with typical bakeries in France, but it's downright impossible to do better here in the states.  The french bread had good hole structure, a chewey crumb and a golden, crunchy crust.  Clear Flour is my fav bakery back home (we're visiting SF for 10 days) and I'd say CF has the slightly better croissant and slightly worse baguette, but it's hard to complain about anything this good.

The apple gallete was downright amazing---tender, yet crispy crust; carmelized, yet firm apple slices.  Yummy!  You must try one before you die!

We went for breakfast today and ended up staying for lunch (sandwiches were quite good!) after learning that Thorough is a satellite of the SF Baking Institute, reading the "Advanced" book, meeting the VP as a result and chatting with a bread expert who was on staff!  We'll be back tomorrow before we conclude our trip.

If you were wondering (as we were) where they bake the bread, they don't do it here (no ovens for it!).  They are supplied by SFBI.  Also, some of the employees are from SFBI.
author: Jason R.

description:
Loooove, this place! You have to go.
Babeth, Carla, Nay-Nay, Julie, Evelyn...these are my girls! I can't function without my morning cup of coffee and they always got my back. Try the ALMOND CROISSANT! In fact, try everything. You cannot go wrong there.
author: Erica B.

description:
I'm down with bread.  This spot has me thoroughly excited.  

Their breads are wonderful.  My favorites include 
Demi baguette - so light and fluffy on the inside with a delicious flaky crust.  
Multi-grain loaf - crispy crust with moist center filled with delicious grains.
Cranberry walnut - just right.

In addition to the tasty breads the staff is friendly and helpful.  The place is clean and bright.  The kitchen is open, I love watching the bakers at work.
author: Joey C.

description: Cute cafe and bakery. Ordered an everything bagel, loaf of sourdough, and cafe au lait. Haven't tried to loaf yet, but the bagel and coffee were both quite good. The service was really friendly and the atmosphere was calm (older folks and young families).
author: Amy H.

description:
love thorough bread!!
Their baguettes are quite delicious and they make tasty sandwiches!!
oh, and i can't forget about their pastries and cakes!!
opera cake is divine, napoleon is really delicious but messy to eat, the filling just falls right out with one cut, but that's what the spoon is for to sweep up all that creamy goodness up. mmm and i really enjoyed their gingerbread/persimmon cake, nice and light.
author: Tara B.

description:
Used to come here as it first opened. 

They have great pastry, cakes and croissants.

Most of all their baguette caprese sandwiches are very delicious.

CONS: a little overpriced and needs more outside seating.
author: NC B.

description: On vacation in The City and looking for some yumminess!  Lots of selections here.  Loved the gougeres, the cream puffs, the eclairs, the grasshopper cakes (?).  They make wonderful cappucinos, too!  Beautiful foam designs! Had some sandwiches - they were okay, but the pastries definitely won out.  They also have some delicious bottled iced teas that are hard to find.  Customer service is pretty good for this neck of the woods.  The only ding would be that they seem to run out of yummies too early.  Been here three times in the past week, and two of those three times they ran out of almost everything we were looking for.  Guess they get a lot of business, but it was a definite disappointment!
author: Susi M.

description: The quality of food at Thorough Bread & Pastry is just wonderful. The full-size ciabatta loaf is delicious - airy and chewy loaf of bread. The small tarts (rustic, rhubarb-strawberry) are melt-in-your-mouth pastries. Both sweet and tart, they are wonderful. It's a great staff, and a nice, casual place to relax.
author: Suzie C.

description: At first I was skeptical about the look of the chocolate chip cookie.  I've always liked this spot, the light, the vibe.  Great pastries and breads.  But only recently did I actually order a cookie and now I can't get it out of my head. I can't wait to go back for more!  (I'm always on the prowl for a great choc chip cookie so If anyone can recommend their favorite place, I'd be more than happy to give it a try:)
author: Jeffrey B.

description: Came here and had an eclair, a couple gougeres and an almond croissant.  They were all very good.  The eclair was the right amount of sweetness, while the gougeres were puffy and fresh.
