we seacrhed over looking for something to fill our stomachs

i got this turkey sandiwch

ugh one of the best sandiwches ive ever had

and i bought a delicious croissant

and some raspberry jelly

(the only thing i have to complain about is the fact that i had to pay for jelly 50 cents)

it was perfection on a plate

and i coupled it with a pomegranate izze

and it only cost me 12 dollars

which isnt bad for this city

or anyt place

and the outback patio

was divine

it was like enclosed by other houses and whatnot

but like there were trees and birds

it was beautiful

i am going back tomorrow to relax and eat and do my work

its the perfect place

to sit back and read a book

and fill your fat ass with the most delicious pastries youve ever had

chow down

X
author: Mateo X.

description: This place is the best! Aside from the pastries, the staff is awesome! Babette and Julie are super sweet and always treat my family very well. Must try: almond croissant, cinnamon almond scone, the fruit bar (delish!), quiches and macaroons are all to die for. Very reasonably prices and there is a patio out in back. Oh, I am forgetting the breads. Baguettes and the round loaves are delicious. I would go there again and again.......
author: City S.

description: Can I give them six stars? I love this place and these people. Wonderful food, good prices, friendly staff, cheerful decor, a patio...can't think what I would change.
author: Mike K.

description:
The place was a recent find when a friend an her family were visiting.  Bought some Easter macaroons, and the kids loved them.

Finally got around to trying the food ourselves this week.  Everything was wonderful: the smell, the taste, the visual cues.

Glad to have a good bakery that's closer than Tartine.
author: Joseph C.

description: Their blueberry tarts and coffee cake are out of this world !!!
author: Gregory C.

description:
if the word 'bread' is in your name, then the bread you serve better be damn good.  and it was!

i had the roasted chicken sandwich on ciabatta and the actual sandwich was just ok.  the bread really was perfect, and the portion-size was more than adequate, which I liked.  the main problem:  there were a lot of onions in it but the menu description didn't mention onions (just roasted garlic).  that just pisses me off.   i can't eat onions, so i spent more time picking out the onions with my fingers than eating the actual sandwich.  here's a suggestion to the owner:  make sure you list all ingredients on the menu.

as for the pastries:  don't judge a book by its cover.  they all looked fantastic, but the few i tried were very unimpressive taste-wise.
author: Christine R.

description: Love this place.  So glad its in my hood.  I work from home and taking a quick walk to pick up baguette and coffee makes my day.
author: Larissa W.

description: I recently found myself in this neighborhood and saw this cute little bread and pastry store.  They have floor-to-ceiling windows, beautiful flowers, and warm-looking people behind the counter.  I was hungry, so I decided to stop in.  Even though it was only about 10 am, they let me order a sandwich, so I got the Garden Sandwich.  It was well made.  The grilled eggplant and peppers were heavily drenched in olive oil (just the way I like it).  It also had huge chunks of creamy goat cheese in it.  All of this was placed on a big slab of focaccia bread.  It also came with a small side green salad.  On my way out, I got an oatmeal cookie (only 75 cents).  I shared it with a friend later and that was pretty good too.  Everything hit the spot for me when I needed them too.
author: sarisha h.

description: I was thinking the other day that what I really need on my commute home is a good bakery. And today, I stumbled upon this one. It looks fantastic. We didn't have time to actually stop and have tea with some of their amazing-looking pastries and sandwiches, but I bought a demi-baguette and a croissant to bring home, and these are delicious. And, they have a patio! They've been open for 4 months already, and I was completely clueless (since I was always choosing the other side of the road, to pop into the Aardvark books). But now I know, and I am definitely going back.
author: Maria B.

description: I want EVERYTHING from this place!  And it's a cute place (with nice outdoor patio too).  Plus, it's a good concept (baking students--top notch, mind you).
author: kyle w.

description: best little pastries and bread in a clean place and nice crowd ...and that on church street! Great service too
author: matthias B.

description: Thorough Bread has the best bread in the city. Don't waste your time ordering Tartine three days in advance when you can walk in and buy a loaf of the multigrain bread for $3.50. All those little flax seeds crunch in your teeth, and it's heaven. Chewy, moist, excellent crust. Pair with some Cowgirl Creamery cheese and you've got a perfect picnic.
author: Jossie I.

description: Really, REALLY, the bread here is hands down, the best quality in San Francisco.  I forgot how good they are, and was reminded when I unsuccessfully tried a few other local bread shops in the city.  The multi grain, and the baguette's continue to be my favorite.  On a trip to wine country, we grabbed a few loaves, bought some excellent cheese, and sundried tomatos.  Heaven!
author: Lauren M.

description: It was bad enough that I discovered Thourough Bread's multi-grain bread, but then I discovered their chocolate chip cookies. And THEN I saw that they were making peach jam last Saturday; I swear, I almost asked if I could come behind the counter and help. I settled for buying a jar of the peach and a jar of the blueberry.
author: Dan G.

description: I just discovered Thorough and their bread is just wonderful.  I've been trying different breads recently and theirs is one of the best I've tried and very reasonably priced.  Very fresh.  Can't wait to buy more.
author: Nora S.

description: This is my most favorite bakery in the city. Their baguettes tasted just like the ones in France. The bakery is operated by the San Francisco Baking Institute (www.sfbi.com).
author: Steve R.

description: This place is so cute! It's really conveniently located and the boys there are quite attractive. I highly recommend the multi-grain loaf. It's delicious and only $3.50!
author: Brock H.

description: I'm so fortunate to live near this place.  Everything looked delicious and I wanted to try all the pastries and breads and desserts but I had to use my will power to only order the blueberry scone....which was tasty.  I sat in the cute courtyard with a magazine and thought, this is the life!
author: Debbie Y.

description:
best service. excellent soups, sandwiches, and pastries. 
i love the macaroons, almond croissants, and shortbread cookies!
so delicious!
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
I've been coming here every visit to SF over the past 1.5 years or so.  Why aren't there bakery cafes like this in Manhattan?  Almost makes me want to move back to SF.  Three features that really make this bakery a standout; I didn't give it a five star as I have not visited it 30 times or more (statistical sampling).

1.  I love their almond croissants - easily as tasty as the ones from Boulange (Polk, Pine, Hayes, etc.) and Tartines. And dependable as I've had ones from the other bakeries that were burnt around the edges.  I could go on about the croissant's flaky, crispy layers of dough and just sweet enough almond paste filling.  I've taken them back to NY with me, and they keep well.  Just stick them in the toaster oven for a while and they crisp up nicely.  

2.  The blueberry scones really set them apart from other bakeries. They are tender and bursting with an insane amount of plump, still juicy blueberries.  At times, the scones look like a clump of berries stuck together with a bit of dough. Easily the best in SF.

3.  The patio is welcoming.  Serene.  My former fave patio was at Arlequin on Hayes until they expanded/landscaped the patio and it became the haunt of the bridge/tunnel pre-Symphony crowd.  Now they give you the vibe to leave the moment you've finished your cup of coffee.  If I want attitude, I'll stay in NY.
author: Jeff H.

description: Considering its a Bread and Pastry shop their selection was limited and unimpressive. The Focaccia was great, except they only serve it when ordered with a sandwich or in small squares. I expected more... and I feel there would be a number of better mom & pop pastry shops farther down on Valencia or in Noe Valley.
author: Francesca L.

description: Love love love this place.  Excellent banana bread, pastries, sandwiches, some of the best coffee I've had in the city.  But, the best part is the courtyard garden in the back of the shop: flowers, trees, tables, and QUIET.  It's great.
author: Elli F.

description: Nice selection of sandwiches, quiche, pastry and sticky buns. Service is a little disorganized but friendly. It's a nice little location with an outside sitting area.
author: R J.

description: Good pastries. Tasty sandwiches. Friendly staff. What pushed it to five stars is the lovely shaded patio in the back. Was a simply delightful place to enjoy a bit of warm weather. Have stopped by to get bread a few times and have to say that I love the sesame semolina. And as the friendly guy behind the counter put it "It's so cute, isn't it!? I love cute bread!"
author: E C.

description: Good lattes, great location...they have a nice back garden where you can enjoy your coffee / pastry. Friendly staff.
author: Shweta V.

description: This is an awesome bakery. I especially like their multi-grain multi-seed bread. It is a very well run local business -- feels very personal, not like a chain.  They need to get a bread slicing machine, though!
author: Meredith G.

description: Overall, I like this upstart-style bakery. The sandwiches (I've had the pork or the ham/cheese) are wholesome and tasty, the pastries are well made. The prices are reasonable for what you get. At the counter, the employees are thorough, if not always speedy.
author: Scott B.

description: On my visit, I found this place to be unpretentious and friendly.  The staff were helpful and accommodating.  Baked goods and sandwiches here aren't exotic or over-the-top, but that's fine, because they are executed very well.  The sandwich I had was excellent... fresh, tasty, and of course, with amazing bread.
author: Ryan L.

description: Wow!  I never had almond croissants and toasted bostock like these.
author: Tony L.

description: If you want bread, this is the place. I think that I could eat a sandwich here made of air ... that is, nothing inside. The bread is amazing, and the indoors patio adds such a touch of style and relax that you can easily forget which city you are.
author: Javi V.

description: The food is very good and authentic. Most baked goods are fresh daily.
author: Lucky S.

description: Awesome pastries and bread! Cheaper and better than most bakeries in France
author: Bad C.

description:
By far the closest you'll get to France for their bread and croissants. Their baguette was quite authentic. Did not try their sandwiches but they looked scrumptious. Pleasant place to meet with friends as you can hear yourself speak (quiet, pleasing music). What a delight. And we could practice our French with the very nice woman who was behind the counter. For example, ne raccrochez pas. (Don't hang up.) The only slight disappointment is that their espresso is not my favorite (Mr. Espresso). I would LOVE to see them use Blue Bottle. Now we're talkin'
Update: Try their chocolate baguette. You won't be disappointed. 
Encore: Just got back from Paris (again) and Thorough Bread est magnifique.
author: Minou V.

description: Our first time here, they were really friendly and let us try a few samples. Though the sandwiches are pretty basic, the stellar bread makes a significant difference. Add a tasty cup of soup for only a dollar. Great patio in the back!
author: Frank T.

description: Thorough Bread has become my "go to" neighborhood spot. The viennoiserie is top notch and the staff is very friendly, especially the charming French woman who is there in the morning. My only complaint is that they're not open on Monday!
author: Catherine P.

description: Good coffee and pastries. Would be nice if the girls were a little friendlier, a thank you when giving the change would go a long way.
author: brian d.

description: Hands down best bakery, and one of the top cafes, in the City. Hopefully, no one else finds out- but they deserve the credit. Best bakery- yes, much better than Tartine, because they aren't full of themselves, despite being super legit (they bake their bread in the oven behind the counter... and speak French which isn't a pretentious thing- the main lady running the show is French), and don't hire out same hair-colored women who look like model robots to serve you your bread/pastries. Everyone has always been extremely friendly there, every time I have gone in. They have the BEST baguette in the City, and it costs $1.50! Far better than Acme or Tartine, too. I will admit I like Firebrand's whole wheat breads more (because I like WW), but they are not in SF (in Oakland, but sold in SF, thankfully), and when it comes to French Baguettes Thorough still wins. Also, they have delicious challah (but get it before 1pm! and also after like 8am, on Fridays). Their pastries are fantastic, and you can watch them being prepped in front of you. My boyfriend says that Tartine's are better depending on the pastry, but that it's more or less the same (but minus the line, attitude, and lack of seating like at Tartine). Coffee is delicious as well, nice selection of teas, they also have wonderful sandwiches and soups. The bowl of soup (today was tomato&celery w/cumin, mmm) was so hot and fresh, and came with a sliced up baguette, all for less than $5. The back patio is also a huge plus, along with the wonderful customers who frequent the place- not the pretentious hipster crowd, but the normal people crowd- old and young, sewing clubs and cute couples and people practicing their Spanish over coffee and pastries. They are also very accommodating to cyclists, as I often bike here on my way home from a ride and leave my bike in the entrance while quickly grabbing bread for lunch. I've also spent hours in the back patio and brought my bike back there with me (I asked first and they were fine with it). I can imagine how they wouldn't want more than 6 bikes back there though, the space isn't really for that. Anyways, give these guys your love, they deserve it, and now are open Sundays 8-6pm too!
author: Amanda S.

description: I live right down the street from this place and it's fantastic for a quick pastry or sandwich. The coffee is cheap and good. My favorite is the chocolate croissant!
author: Holly S.

description: I have lived in SF for 5 years and I would have to say hands down Thorough Bread & Pastry has the best turkey sandwich I've ever had. I just took my mom who was visiting to Thorough Bread and she LOVED it. She even took a pastry back for my dad on the flight! Truly AMAZING!
author: Morgan S.

description: At the moment, Thorough Bread - the unassuming place on Church - has the BEST f-ing turkey sandwich I've ever had. From the thinly sliced turkey and pepper jack to the homemade sesame seed snail roll to the caramelized onions and special sauce.... mmm, mmm, gooooooood! I've made a special trip for this sandwich on many occasion. Friendly, accommodating staff too.
author: Lisa R.

description: Absolutely the best baguette in San Francisco ... and quite possibly the best baguette anywhere outside of France!!!!
author: Sally B.

description: This review is solely about the pastries. They're tasty and executed very well - way better than a place like Sweet Inspirations, for example. Downside is that they're uninspired and the same as every other cake offerings in the city.  A lemon tart is nothing to excite me. Neither is a cream-filled éclair - give me something decadent, something filled with custard or crème patisserie.  A gooseberry/marzipan Torte, or a Rhubarb Streusel Torte from Sowohl Als Auch in Berlin - that's the kind of shit that is exciting and induces one to travel halfway around the world.
author: Dan L.

description:
This is my favorite cafe in the city.  The people who work there are terrific and very friendly; there's a nice, mellow, neighborhoody vibe to the place, and you get the sense that the people working there -- most of them recent grads of the SF Baking Institute -- are there because they really enjoy the creative process.  When something new comes out of the oven they often come around with samples (rosewater macaroons, chocolate sourdough bread, etc), which is fun, and the frequently-changing pastry displays in the front window are works of art. 

I notice some reviewers found the service slow -- I haven't noticed that myself, and have gone there now at least 8 or 9 times.  As for the food, the scones are amazing.  (They're the best scones I've had in the US -- as good as any in England.  My mom tried them while visiting SF recently and has brought them up in several phone conversations since.)  Also delicious are the semolina rolls and multigrain bread, and I'm a fan of the tuna sandwich.  The prices are all very reasonable.  And the atmosphere is lovely -- especially the peaceful patio in the back.
author: Kate D.

description: This place is awesome. Rasberry muffin, small coffee: $3.45 and my day has begun. The boys who work here are adorable if not a little nervous. I have also tried the blueberry scone and the danish. Both were excellent. Ambience could be less...let's say, industrial noisy, but sometimes they play Bowie which is fun. The sandwich I had here was not the best but I'm willing to give it another shot.
author: Inigo M.

description: this little bakery has my favorite baked goods in the city.  try the ham and cheese croissant.  its perfect.  i also got what i think was called a potato bacon samosa.  fruit and cheese danishes are also not to be missed.  i think i also got a lemon tart that was fantastic.  coffee isnt bad either.
author: Robert S.

description: A great neighborhood cafe with very tasty bread and pastries. Doesn't get five starts from me only because the coffee drinks are just okay. Surprisingly for this neighborhood and the quality of the goods, there never seems to be a crowd. I particularly like that Thorough Bread extends its menu beyond the typical croissant and danish fare into lesser known baked goods, like gibassiers (an anise and orange flavored brioche from Provence). They have cute holiday decorations, like their christmas tree made of bread, and a sweet little patio in back where you can soak up the sunshine while eating your tart.
author: Jane R.

description: their baguettes are airy...as they should be that 'air' is actually gas that adds flavor. their price to quality ratio is also one of the best in the city. Michel wrote the book on bread in the bay area, he helped open acme and semifreddi's.
author: A D.

description: Their almond croissants are the best anywhere!  They're different than any others in SF and I have tasted them in all bakeries in SF.  I am totally addicted and would have them be my only object, if marooned on a desert island, etc.....
author: Joyce J.

description: tasty pastry, and prices are great! everything is fresh, you might learn a few things while shopping here, too. :) yum yum. get a chocolate croissant. you will not be disappointed.
author: Ashley M.

description: One of my favorite bakeries in the city, the staff is nice and helpful (for the most part). Decent prices and really nice patio in the back.
author: Boris A.

description: Thorough Bread and Pastry is conveniently located on Church not too far away from Market Street on the J-line. A very charming bakery indeed, there is even a small courtyard where you can sit and enjoy your pastries weather permitting. I came here on a Thursday evening nearing closing time. Bakers were busy rolling out dough behind the counter. I came here initially to try the baguette, at the suggestion of Nathalie L, so I asked if I could have a sample before I made my purchase. They were kind enough to slice me a piece of their crusty baguette, and I must admit it is quite good, definitely on par with acme rustics. Of course I couldn't leave just buying one baguette, so I decided on a lemon blackberry mousse tart which looked too beautiful to eat- yet somehow I managed to eat it anyway. The mousse was intensely lemon flavored, light and fluffy and the blackberry filling added a nice contrast. The thin layers of sponge cake sandwiching the mousse and blackberry gel was as airy as angel food cake (but not nearly as sweet). I will definitely be back to Thorough Bread for their baguettes (in the event that I cannot make it out to Berkeley for those from La Farine) and definitely to sample more of their magnificent pastries.
author: Kate A.

description: I had a great lunch here today - a garden sandwich and a snickerdoodle (which I definitely didn't need but I figured I had to buy some sort of baked good, it being a bakery and all). The vegetarian sandwich was excellent, on really fresh focaccia. But the cookie was the best part.  Seriously, it was a damn good cookie.
author: Hill J.

description: Best pumpkin pie EVER.  And I'm a pie lover.  It was beautiful, with little maple-leaf pie-crust embellishments, and the pie itself was delicious.  And seriously, when I say I love pies, I mean I have pumpkin pie in July and March.  So I know my pumpkin pies!  Plus, they donated recently to a charity I support.  So great!
author: sara m.

description: I feel so lucky to be able to pick up a freshly baked baguette around the corner anytime. I am particularly difficult with baguettes and croissants, and theirs are perfect to a French standard.
author: Aicha D.

description: i love food - especially bread. screw carb counting. the coffee is well prepared. the menu is simple, and the the sandwiches are delicious. i would recommend eating here when you want a tasty sandwich or savory pastry with coffee or tea. the service is great, which is nice to see these days. when i left the manager smiled at me and asked me if i liked it. somebody cares. woo. plus there's a quiet garden patio in the back. i give five stars because the food is really well done for a cafe - plus the portion size is right on the money. i love food.
author: tk o.

description: Every dessert and sandwich I've tried has been amazing. The bread is perfect, especially the ciabatta and sour dough.
author: Anna O.

description: The pastries are amazing and the employees were fun and upbeat and it was my everyday favorite until I began to notice changes in the employees and management. It seems like the employees aren't as upbeat and nice as they use to be. I stopped going and changed my everyday cafe. The atmosphere is dull and not of San Francisco. I miss the old Thorough Bread!!! GO if it's just for the pastries but if you're looking for a nice relaxing fun environment I wouldn't recommend it.
author: Peter S.

description: This has become my favorite bakery in the city now over Bay Bread and Tartine. They have so many good stuff. Vegetable sandwich is good, caramel napoleon is great and I found chocolate bread is excellent today. They can do a little better job on interior, but it is not pretentious and the staff are friendly. They had an amazing bread-christmas tree last holiday. It is a bit pricey for a bakery, but a great place!
author: Charlie S.

description: I hate this place. It's responsible for my weight gain. Ten pounds I think which I need to shed before summer. God, how I love the ham and cheese sandwich (just like in France), and the panetonni (better than the ones I've tried in Italy) which my whole family love. Brought home a couple of those for Christmas and they were a total hit! Another plus: the people behind the counter are polite and attentive.
author: Lee P.

description: i eat here at least once a week. their garden vegetable sandwich is wonderful: goat cheese with roasted red peppers and eggplant, pesto on awesome fresh bread! they also have amazing soup. the carrot soup is definitely my favorite. the back patio is adorable and everyone who works there is so nice!
author: Kelly Y.

description: this is a real artisan bakery, they have the only artisan bread and pastry school in the country. they have an amazing professional baking book (flip through some of the pages see what it takes to make what you are eating) they are also involved in the world cup of baking... these are serious bread people! this isn't your ordinary bakery! have you seen the amazing displays of bread sculptures? they use high quality ingredients. the price is reasonable. they have my respect.
author: melissa s.
